questions.text: The patient, a 45-year-old man, has been experiencing recurrent falls and dizziness for six weeks. He has no personal or family history of chronic illnesses and is exposed to industrial solvents at work. During the examination, he displays an unsteady gait, inability to stand with feet together, and tremors in his hands while gripping a pen. Despite normal muscle strength and sensation, his ability for rapid hand movements is impaired. His mental status examination shows no abnormalities. What is the blood supply to the affected structure in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Options C - Basilar Artery:

  • The basilar artery supplies the brainstem and cerebellum. The patient's symptoms, including impaired gait, wide-based stance, and tremors, are indicative of cerebellar dysfunction. The exposure to industrial solvents could have led to toxic effects on the cerebellum, making the basilar artery the likely source of the issue.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA): ACA supplies the medial aspects of the brain's hemispheres and is not directly associated with the symptoms described, such as tremors and impaired rapid hand movements.

Option B - Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA): PCA supplies the occipital lobe of the brain and is more related to visual processing. The symptoms described, like wide-based gait and tremors, are not primarily associated with PCA territory.

Option D - Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA): MCA supplies lateral aspects of the cerebral hemispheres. Symptoms such as impaired gait, tremors, and rapid alternating hand movements are not typically associated with MCA territory.

questions.text: In gluconeogenesis, the metabolic pathway responsible for synthesizing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources, various enzymes are involved in bypassing the irreversible steps of glycolysis. One of these enzymes holds a pivotal role in controlling the overall flux through the pathway, serving as the rate-limiting step. Determine which statement regarding the rate-limiting enzyme of gluconeogenesis is incorrect.

choices.text: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is an allosteric activator of this enzyme

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is an allosteric activator of this enzyme:

  • The rate-limiting enzyme of gluconeogenesis is fructose-1-6-bisphosphatase.
  • It converts fructose-1-6-bisphosphate to fructose-6-phosphate.
  • It is regulated by fructose-2,6-bisphosphate, which is produced from fructose-6-phosphate by the enzyme PFK-II (phosphofructokinase-II) in the fed state.
  • Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is a potent allosteric activator of PFK-1 and increases glycolysis.
  • Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate, is also an allosteric inhibitor of fructose-1-6-bisphosphatase and acts by reducing its affinity for its substrate and hence decreasing gluconeogenesis (see fig below).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Key glucogenic enzyme:

  • It is a key glucogenic enzyme because it favors gluconeogenesis.
  • It is one of the three enzymes of gluconeogenesis that are different from glycolysis enzymes.

Option C - Catalyzes the hydrolysis reaction:

  • Fructose 1,6 bisphosphatase is a hydrolase that catalyzes the removal of Pi from fructose 1,6-bisphosphate to form fructose 6-P by adding H2O.

Options D - Requires magnesium for the catalysis:

  • This enzyme is an Mg2+ dependent hydrolase (usually kinase requires Mg2+).

questions.text: What structures are responsible for creating the angle depicted in the image below within the rectum, a section of the large intestine located in the pelvis, as it traverses through the pelvic diaphragm and extends toward the anus?

choices.text: The circular muscle layer of the rectum
The longitudinal muscle layer of the rectum

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Puborectalis:

  • The angle shown in the image is the anorectal angle (ARA).
  • It is the angle between the longitudinal axis of the rectum (represented by the posterior rectal line) and the longitudinal axis of the anal canal. The puborectalis muscle forms this angle.
  • The anorectal angle is an indirect indicator of puborectalis muscle activity.
  • During muscle contraction, the anorectal angle becomes more acute, while during the relaxing phase, it becomes obtuse.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Internal anal sphincter:

  • The internal anal sphincter is a smooth muscle ring that surrounds the anal canal. It is responsible for maintaining involuntary constriction of the anal canal, helping to control fecal continence.
  • While it plays a role in anal function, it does not directly form the anorectal angle seen in the image.
  • It is a thickening of the circular smooth muscle providing involuntary fecal continence.

Option B - The circular muscle layer of the rectum:

  • The circular muscle layer of the rectum is also known as the inner layer of the rectal muscles.
  • This muscle layer is responsible for aiding in the expulsion of feces from the rectum during defecation.
  • It does not form the anorectal angle; instead, it contributes to the overall structure and function of the rectum.

Option C - The longitudinal muscle layer of the rectum:

  • The longitudinal muscle layer is another component of the rectal muscle layers.
  • It runs along the length of the rectum and aids in the rectal contractions that propel feces toward the anus.
  • Similar to the circular muscle layer, it does not directly form the anorectal angle.

questions.text: What is the expected physiological response when both carotid arteries are occluded proximal to the carotid bifurcation?

choices.text: An increase in blood pressure (BP) and an increase in heart rate (HR).
A decrease in blood pressure (BP) and a decrease in heart rate (HR).
No change in blood pressure (BP) and an increase in heart rate (HR).
An increase in blood pressure (BP) and a decrease in heart rate (HR)

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ↑ BP and ↑ heart rate:

  • Baroreceptors are located above the carotid bifurcation.
  • When carotid arteries are occluded below the bifurcation, there would be a fall of pressure in the carotid sinus.
  • This will reduce the stretch on its wall, and the baroreceptors, stretch receptors, decrease their discharge.
  • The normal tonic effect of this discharge on the medullary VMC is inhibitory; the medullary vasoconstrictor area now escapes from that tonic inhibitory discharge.
  • Carotid arteries supply blood to the brain; their occlusion may result in cerebral ischemia.
  • However, increased BP and heart rate seen after their occlusion is NOT a result of VMC ischemia or CNS ischemic response.
  • This may be concluded from two observations:
    • If the carotid sinus nerves (IXth Nerve) have been previously cut, abolishing the discharge of baroreceptors to VMC, a rise in BP is not seen after carotid occlusion, although there is cerebral ischemia.
    • If the carotids are clamped beyond the carotid sinus baroreceptors, it produces cerebral ischemia but no rise in BP.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D: All these are wrong options.

questions.text: Chromatography is a technique used to separate a mixture into its components. Which of the following types of column chromatography is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Size exclusion chromatography:

  • Size exclusion chromatography is shown in the above image.
  • In size exclusion or gel filtration chromatography method:
    • A gel is taken in the column. In gel permeation, the separation takes place according to gel size. The gel size is such that smaller proteins can enter the gel, but bigger proteins cannot.
    • The mixture of proteins to be separated is poured onto the top of the column. Both proteins start coming down with gravity. But smaller proteins take time to come down as it enters the gel. But bigger proteins are eluted first as they don't enter the gel particles. This way, the separation of proteins can be done.
    • The advantages of this method include good separation of large molecules from the small molecules with a minimal volume of eluate and that various solutions can be mixed without interfering with the filtration process while preserving the biological activity of the particles to separate.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Affinity chromatography:

  • Affinity chromatography is a separation method based on a specific binding interaction between a ligand and its binding partner. It does not separate based on size. Examples include antibody/antigen and enzyme/substrate.

Option C - HPLC:

  • High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) is a technique of separating components in a liquid mixture based on differential adsorption of compounds between material of column and solvent phase.

Option D - Ion exchange chromatography:

  • In ion exchange chromatography, a positively charged and negatively charged column exists.
  • Carboxymethyl cellulose is negatively charged because of its COOH group and is used in the negatively charged column.
  • The positively charged column has DEAE cellulose (Di Ethyl Amino Ethyl cellulose)
  • This figure shows a single column with no positively or negatively charged columns

questions.text:
Afferent arteriolar constriction causes all except:

A. Decrease in GFR

B. Increases Glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure

C. Decreases Afferent arteriolar resistance

D. Increases Renal blood flow
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - B and D:

  • The effect of afferent arteriolar constriction is :
    • Decrease in Renal blood flow.
    • Decrease in GFR
    • Decrease in Glomerular hydrostatic pressure
    • Increase in Afferent arteriolar resistance

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A only:

  • Afferent arteriolar constriction leads to a decrease in GFR.

Option B - A and C:

  • Afferent arteriolar constriction leads to:
    • Decrease in GFR
    • Increase in  Afferent arteriolar resistance

Option C - A and B:

  • Afferent arteriolar constriction leads to:
    • Decrease in GFR
    • Decrease in Glomerular hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: Cranial nerves carry the motor and sensory fibers, and their injury can occur at various levels resulting in a broad range of symptoms. Which of the following is incorrectly paired, considering the features of cranial nerves?

choices.text: Anterior basal skull fracture: Olfactory nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Intracranial aneurysm: Optic Nerve:

  • The most common nerve involved in the intracranial aneurysm is the Oculomotor nerve.
  • The most common cause of optic nerve injury is orbital trauma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior basal skull fracture: Olfactory nerve: It is correctly paired, as the most common nerve involved in anterior skull base fracture is the olfactory nerve

Option B -Orbital floor fracture: Infraorbital nerve: It is correctly paired, as the infraorbital nerve is most commonly involved in orbital floor fracture

Option C -Spinal anesthesia: Abducens nerve: It is correctly paired, as the most common nerve affected during spinal anesthesia is the Abducens nerve.

questions.text:
Assertion: The conversion of homocysteine to methionine is dependent on the presence of folate and vitamin B12 as cofactors, and this biochemical transformation constitutes a transmethylation process.

Reason: This enzymatic conversion is facilitated by the enzyme homocysteine methyl transferase, which relies on a methyl group donation from methylcobalamin. Methylcobalamin, in turn, obtains the methyl group from methyl-tetrahydrofolate (methyl-THF).

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but Reason is independently a true/correct statement.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the assertion:

Methionine synthase:

  • A big monomeric protein with four distinct modules, methionine synthase, has 1227 amino acid residues in the enzyme from E. coli.
  • Homocysteine is bound and activated by the N-terminal module, and its thiol coordinates to a zinc metal ion necessary for catalysis.
  • Methyl tetrahydrofolate is bound and activated by the following module in the sequence.
  • To move methyl groups to and from the base-off cofactor, each of these substrate-binding modules communicates with the B12-binding module, the third module in the sequence.
  • Methionine synthase must be activated by the C-terminal module when the cobalamin cofactor is oxidized during turnover (1 in 2000 turnovers results in oxidation in vitro).
  • A methyl donor and an electron donor are necessary for the cofactor's inactive cobalamin form to become active.
  • S-adenosylmethionine serves as the methyl donor.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D: Refer to explanation of A

questions.text: Which of the following receptor types functions through G protein-coupled receptors:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ach muscarinic receptors:

  • Ach muscarinic receptors are metamorphic ion gated channels, cyclin nucleotide gateway, or GPCR-associated channels. M1, M2, M3, M4, and M5 are Ach muscarinic receptors.
  • G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are called seven-helix or serpentine receptors.
  • These receptors assemble into a barrel-like structure. Upon ligand binding, a conformational change activates a resting heterotrimeric G-protein associated with the cytoplasmic leaf of the plasma membrane.
  • GPCRs are prime targets for drug discov­ery.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Insulin receptors:

  • The insulin receptor is a member of the ligand-activated receptor and tyrosine kinase family of transmembrane signaling proteins.
  • Receptor tyrosine kinase: When a hormone binds with the receptor, the receptor phosphorylates tyrosine residues on themselves and other proteins. E.g., Receptors for insulin and insulin-like growth factors (IGFs).

Option C - Ach nicotinic receptors:

  • Ach nicotinic receptors (N1, N2) are ligand-gated ion channels found in ganglia, neuromuscular junctions (NMJ), and central nervous system (CNS) neurons.

Option D - GABA-A receptors:

  • GABA-A receptors are ligand-gated ion channels (also known as ionotropic receptors).

questions.text: Which of the following options best describes the correct sequential order of events for skeletal muscle contraction?

choices.text: Ca2+ binding to troponin → myosin head binding to actin → ATP hydrolyzation
ATP hydrolyzation → myosin head binding to actin → Ca2+binding to troponin
Myosin head binding to actin → ATP hydrolyzation → Ca2+binding to troponin
ATP hydrolyzation → Ca2+ binding to troponin → myosin head binding to actin

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ca+2 binding to troponin →myosin head binding to actin → ATP hydrolyzation:

  1. Ca2+ binding to troponin:
    • Muscle contraction is initiated when an action potential travels along a motor neuron and reaches the neuromuscular junction.
    • This action potential triggers the release of calcium ions (Ca2+) from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm of the muscle cell.
    • Calcium ions then bind to the protein troponin, which is part of the actin filaments in the muscle cell.
  2. Myosin head binding to actin:
    • When calcium ions bind to troponin, it causes a conformational change in the troponin-tropomyosin complex.
    • This change exposes the binding sites on actin filaments.
    • Myosin heads, which are part of the myosin filaments, can now bind to these exposed binding sites on actin.
  3. ATP hydrolyzation:
    • ATP (adenosine triphosphate) is required for the energy needed for muscle contraction.
    • Before myosin can exert force and move the actin filaments, ATP is hydrolyzed to ADP (adenosine diphosphate) and inorganic phosphate (Pi).
    • The energy released from ATP hydrolysis is used to "cock" the myosin head, putting it in a high-energy state, ready to bind to actin.
  • So, option A correctly describes the sequential order of events during skeletal muscle contraction: Ca2+ binding to troponin comes first, followed by myosin head binding to actin, and then ATP hydrolyzation to provide the energy for muscle contraction.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - ATP hydrolyzation → myosin head binding to actin → Ca+2 binding to troponin:

  • ATP hydrolyzation occurs at the end, returning to the original state of rigour.

Option C - myosin head binding to actin → ATP hydrolyzation → Ca+2 binding to troponin:

  • Ca+2 binding to troponin occurs, which results in myosin binding to the actin.

Option D - ATP hydrolyzation → Ca+2 binding to troponin → myosin head binding to actin:

  • Ca+2 binding to troponin occurs, which results in myosin binding to the actin.

questions.text: Which structure in the oral cavity exhibits keratinized epithelium and is commonly affected when a 5-year-old child experiences a burning sensation after consuming hot tea, leading to erythema on examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hard palate:

  • Hard palate lined by a stratified squamous keratinized epithelium. The keratin layer protects the oral mucosa from damage during the masticatory function. The soft palate, lips, cheeks, and the floor of the mouth are covered by the non-keratinized squamous epithelium.
  • Depending on the oral cavity region, it is lined with stratified squamous Epithelium, keratinized, or non-keratinized Epithelium. The keratinized epithelium lines the hard palate.
  • Oral cavity
    • Tongue (keratinized anteriorly)
    • Hard palate (keratinized)
    • Ortho + para keratinization
    • Body tubes do not have keratin due to wet mucosa except at the surface openings for e.g., oral cavity, anal canal etc
  • The hard palate forms the anterior two-thirds of the roof of the oral cavity.
  • Stratified Squamous Epithelium is Present at places where protection is needed. It contains several layers of squamous cells called keratinocytes.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Soft palate:

  • The soft palate, lips, cheeks, and the floor of the mouth are covered by the non-keratinized squamous epithelium.

Option C - Oropharynx:

  • The non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium lines the Oropharynx.

Option D - Nasopharynx:

  • Pseudo-stratified Ciliated Columnar Epithelium(respiratory) lines the Nasopharynx.
  • It is not lined by keratinized epithelium

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of events that occur during vomiting for a woman who experiences nausea after consuming spicy food.


	LES is open and UES is closed.
	Strong contractions in the stomach.
	Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter.
	Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine.
	Inspiration against a closed glottis.
	LES opens and UES opens.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 4, 3, 2, 5, 1, 6:

  • 4: Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine: The process of vomiting begins with the reverse peristalsis in the small intestine, which pushes the stomach contents back up into the esophagus.
  • 3: Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter: The pyloric sphincter, which normally separates the stomach from the small intestine, must relax to allow the stomach contents to flow back up into the esophagus.
  • 2: Strong contractions in the stomach: Strong contractions in the stomach help to propel the stomach contents up toward the esophagus.
  • 5: Inspiration against a closed glottis: As the stomach contents reach the pharynx, the glottis, or the opening of the windpipe, closes to prevent the contents from entering the lungs.
  • 1: At the same time, the diaphragm contracts and the chest wall muscles contract, creating negative pressure in the chest cavity and allowing the contents to be forced out of the mouth.
  • 6: LES opens and UES opens: The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxes to allow the stomach contents to enter the esophagus, while the upper esophageal sphincter (UES) opens to allow the contents to be expelled out of the mouth.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C and D: All these options are wrong. Explanation is given above

questions.text:
Arrange the components of the electron transport chain in the correct sequence, starting from FADH2. Which of the following represents the accurate order of events in the electron transport chain?

i. Succinate dehydrogenase 

ii. Cytochrome c oxidase 

iii. ATP synthase 

iv. Cytochrome c Reductase
questions.solution:
Correct Option A -i→ iv→ ii→ iii:

Electron transport chain:

  • It is located in the inner mitochondrion membrane and transfer electron from reducing equivalents NADH and FADH2 to final electron acceptor Oxygen.
  • In this process, an electrochemical proton gradient is created which is used for chemiosmotic ATP synthesis.

Sequence of electron flow in electron transport chain from FADH2:

  1. Succinate dehydrogenase
  2. Cytochrome c Reductase
  3. Cytochrome c oxidase
  4. ATP synthase

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D: Refer to explanation of  A

questions.text: At what vertebral level does the inferior angle of the scapula typically align with the vertebral body?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - T8:

  • The scapula or shoulder blade is the bone that connects the clavicle to the humerus. It is a sturdy, flat, triangular bone that forms the shoulder girdle's posterior.
  • The scapula, along with the clavicle and the manubrium of the sternum, makes up the pectoral (shoulder) girdle, which connects the upper limb of the appendicular skeleton to the axial skeleton.
  • The scapula overlies the second to seventh ribs.
  • The inferior angle of the scapula lies at the level of the spine of the T7 vertebra (vertebral body T8).
  • The body of vertebra T7 articulates with the head of the seventh and eighth ribs. At this level lies the lower border of the heart; the inferior vena cava passes through the diaphragm's central tendon to enter the heart's right atrium.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - T3:

  • The spine process of the scapula lies at the level of the spinous process of T3.

Option B - T4:

  • Nipples lie at the level of T4

Option C - T7:

  • The inferior scapular angle lies at the spinous process level, not the body of the T7.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is presented with difficulty in breathing and chest pain that worsens with deep inspiration. Upon examination, decreased breath sounds are noted, and percussion reveals hyperresonance on the left side of the chest. A chest x-ray confirms tracheal deviation toward the right. Which of the following statements best describes the changes in lung and thoracic volume in this patient compared to normal?

choices.text: Lung volume ↓ and Thoracic Volume remains same

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lung volume ↓ and Thoracic Volume ↑:

  • This patient has developed pneumothorax on the left side after a stab wound.
  • It happens when air leaks into the pleural space.
  • The elastic tendency of the lungs to collapse is exactly equal to the elastic tendency of the thoracic cage to expand under normal conditions.
  • But when air enters pleural space, the pleural pressure becomes equal to atmospheric pressure. Hence, the chest wall will expand, i.e., thoracic volume increases, and lungs will collapse, i.e., lung volume decreases in pneumothorax

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lung volume ↓ and Thoracic Volume ↓:

  • Lung volume is decreased in atelectasis, in which the lung tissue is collapsed, the trachea moves towards the same side, the diaphragm also moves up, and thoracic volume is decreased

Option C - Lung volume ↑ and Thoracic Volume ↓:

  • In pneumothorax, the lung volume is decreased, and thoracic volume is increased. Hence, this option is incorrect.

Option D - Lung volume ↓ and Thoracic Volume remains same:

  • The lung volume is increased in emphysema, and chronic emphysema also increases the anteroposterior diameter of the chest (barrel-shaped chest.)

questions.text:
During the first well-child visit, a newborn is presented by her mother. Upon examination, the healthcare provider observes signs of microcephaly and hepatomegaly. Due to these clinical findings, the physician suspects a cytomegalovirus infection and decides to order a CT scan of the baby's brain. The CT scan results reveal periventricular calcification.

In this clinical context, what is the most appropriate site or specimen source for obtaining a sample to diagnose CMV infection using the PCR technique?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Urine:

  • The standard laboratory test for diagnosing congenital CMV is polymerase chain reaction (PCR) on saliva, with urine usually collected and tested for confirmation.
  • The reason for the confirmatory test on urine is that most CMV seropositive mothers shed CMV in their breast milk.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B- Blood: According to CDC, the confirmatory test for CMV is urine PCR.

Option C- Liver biopsy: According to CDC, the confirmatory test for CMV is urine PCR.

Option D- Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF): According to CDC, the confirmatory test for CMV is urine PCR.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman visits the dermatology clinic with complaints of an intensely pruritic rash on her forehead and the area where she typically applies a bindi. The rash is characterized by erythema, vesicles, and papules, and she reports wearing the bindi regularly for the past three weeks. Upon further examination, patch testing is conducted to identify the causative allergen. Which of the following allergens is most likely responsible for this patient's allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) related to the use of a bindi?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- PTPB:

  • In this clinical scenario, the most likely allergen responsible for the patient's allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) related to the use of a bindi is PTBP. PTBP is a resin found in some adhesive components of bindis. When the patient wears the bindi regularly on her forehead, there is prolonged and repeated contact with PTBP, leading to sensitization of the skin's immune system.
  • In allergic individuals, exposure to PTBP can trigger an immune response, resulting in the development of a pruritic rash with erythema, vesicles, and papules at the site of contact. This type of reaction is known as allergic contact dermatitis (ACD).

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B- Nickel : While nickel is a common allergen that can cause contact dermatitis in some individuals, it is not typically present in bindis. Therefore, nickel is an unlikely cause of ACD in this specific case.

Option C- Fragrance mix: Fragrances can be allergenic and cause contact dermatitis in certain individuals. However, fragrances are not commonly present in bindis, making this choice less likely in this scenario.

Option D-Rubber accelerants: Rubber accelerants are chemicals used in the manufacturing of rubber products and may trigger contact dermatitis in some individuals. However, bindis do not usually contain rubber, making this choice less likely to be the causative allergen in this particular case.

questions.text: In patients with hip joint injuries or instability, which anatomical structure plays the most significant role in preventing excessive hyperextension of the hip joint?"
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Iliofemoral ligament:

  • The iliofemoral ligament, also known as the Y-shaped ligament of the hip, is the strongest of the three hip ligaments.
  • It prevents excessive hyperextension and hyperabduction of the hip joint.
  • It is particularly important for stabilizing the hip joint in a standing position and during weight-bearing activities. Its tensile strength helps maintain the hip in a stable position.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pubofemoral ligament:

  • The pubofemoral ligament is one of the three ligaments that help stabilize the hip joint.
  • It primarily restricts excessive abduction and extension of the hip joint.
  • While it plays a role in preventing hyperextension, the iliofemoral ligament is more effective in this regard.

Option B - Ischiofemoral ligament:

  • The ischiofemoral ligament is another of the three ligaments that support the hip joint.
  • It mainly limits excessive internal rotation and extension of the hip.
  • While it helps prevent hyperextension to some extent, the iliofemoral ligament is the primary structure for this purpose.

Option D - Gluteus maximus muscle:

  • The gluteus maximus is a large muscle of the buttocks that extends the hip joint.
  • While it contributes to hip joint function, it does not primarily play a role in preventing excessive hyperextension. Instead, it is responsible for hip extension, such as when standing up from a seated position or climbing stairs.

questions.text: At what age does a child typically achieve this significant fine motor milestone, as illustrated in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- 9 months:

  • This is a case of a well-child examination in which a boy presents at the age of 8 months. The baby can now sit without any support and uses the whole hand to grasp objects.
  • The given picture shows an ‘immature pincer grasp’.
  • As the baby is taking the help of the other fingers while picking up a small pellet.
  • It develops at 9 months.

4 months

grasps a rattle when placed in the hand

4 -6months

mouthing of objects

6 months

Unidextrous or palmar grasp

6-7 months

Transfer objects from 1 hand to another

7 months

palmar grasp

9 months

immature/ assisted pincer grasp

12 months

Mature/unassisted pincer grasp

'Casting'

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- 3 months:

  • At the age of 3 months, the baby lifts his head and the chest above the couch using the forearm as support.
  • The head is in the midline; the limbs move symmetrically.

Option B- 6 months:

  • At 6 months, the child is able to lift his head from the pillow.
  • Lifts legs to vertical and grasps feet.

Option D- 12 months:

  • Can walk holding onto objects.
  • Walks like a bear.
  • Picks up a pellet with finger and thumb.

questions.text: Which of the following sensory receptor is responsible for tactile discrimination?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Meissner's corpuscles:

  • Tactile discrimination refers to the ability to perceive fine details and textures through touch.
  • Meissner's corpuscles, located in the dermal papillae of the skin, are the sensory receptors responsible for this function.
  • They are particularly abundant in areas of the skin that require high tactile sensitivity, such as the fingertips, lips, and palms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Merkel discs (also known as Merkel cells) are located in the epidermis and are responsible for light touch and pressure sensation.

Option B. Ruffini end organs are found in the deep layers of the skin and are sensitive to skin stretch and sustained pressure.

Option C. Pacinian corpuscles are deep receptors found in the subcutaneous tissue and respond to deep pressure and vibration.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with severe nodulocystic acne has been undergoing treatment with isotretinoin for the past six months. However, she is now planning to start a family and wants to ensure a safe conception. How long should she wait after stopping isotretinoin treatment before attempting to get pregnant to ensure a safe pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- 1 month: 

  • The appropriate wash-off period before attempting to conceive after stopping isotretinoin treatment is at least one month (30 days). This duration allows sufficient time for the drug to be cleared from the body, significantly reducing the risk of teratogenic effects on the fetus during pregnancy.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A-1 day: One day is insufficient as a wash-off period for isotretinoin. It is essential to wait longer to ensure the drug has been fully eliminated from the body before trying to conceive.

Option B-1 week: One week is insufficient as a wash-off period for isotretinoin. It is essential to wait longer to ensure the drug has been fully eliminated from the body before trying to conceive.

Option D- 6 months: Six months period is more than the recommended was-off period. It is more than enough time to ensure the complete elimination of isotretinoin from the body. The recommended wash-off period is 30 days to 90 days.

questions.text: A 12 year old child presenting with symptoms of photodermatitis, ataxia, and neuropsychiatric disturbances, what specific genetic mutation should be investigated in order to understand the underlying metabolic disorder affecting the absorption of neutral amino acids in the intestines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - SLC6A19 gene mutation:

  • Mutations in the SLC6A19 gene, which encodes a neutral amino acid transporter, are associated with Hartnup disease. This mutation impairs the absorption of neutral amino acids in the intestines, leading to the symptoms mentioned in the question.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - ABCB6 gene mutation: Mutations in the ABCB6 gene are associated with a different condition called X-linked dominant dyschromatosis universalis hereditaria (DUH). DUH primarily affects skin pigmentation and does not involve the absorption of amino acids in the intestines.

Option C - HFE gene mutation: Mutations in the HFE gene are associated with hereditary hemochromatosis, a disorder characterized by excessive absorption of dietary iron. This condition leads to iron overload in the body and can cause various complications, but it is not related to the symptoms described in the question.

Option D - SLC22A5 gene mutation: Mutations in the SLC22A5 gene are associated with systemic primary carnitine deficiency, a disorder that affects the transport of carnitine, an essential molecule for fatty acid metabolism, into cells. This deficiency can lead to muscle weakness, hypoglycemia, and heart problems, but it does not cause the specific symptoms described in the question.

questions.text: In the realm of molecular biology and clinical diagnostics, the invaluable technique of gel electrophoresis serves as an indispensable tool. It enables the discrimination and separation of various macromolecules by exploiting their inherent disparities in size and electrical charge. Among the isoenzymes of particular interest in this context, one question looms: which isoenzyme among them boasts the maximum electrophoretic mobility?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - LDH-1:

  • Gel electrophoresis is a technique that allows macromolecules (DNA, RNA, and proteins) to be detected and separated.
  • Samples are cleaved enzymatically into smaller pieces, then applied on a gel media that is connected to positive and negative electrodes, enabling further segregation of the sample based on size and electrical charge of molecules.
  • LDH isozyme testing helps to assess the type, location, and severity of tissue damage.
  • LDH is a tetrameric enzyme made of H and M subunits.
  • The assembly of the enzymes occurs in a defined ratio through a tissue-specific synthesis of subunits, hence providing tissue specificity, i.e., heart-specific LDH (LDH-1) preferentially synthesizes all four H subunits, while liver LDH (LDH-5) is exclusively made of all M-subunits.
  • Based on the electrophoretic mobility, always number ‘1’ is given to the isozyme form having maximum electrophoretic mobility and last number is given to the form with least mobility.
  • In a typical LDH isozyme electrophoretic pattern, LDH-1 moves as a fast band, followed by LDH-2, LDH-3, LDH-4, and LDH-5 being the slowest band.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D: Refer to explanation of A

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with sudden episodes of spinning vertigo, triggered by changes in head position such as turning in bed or looking up. These episodes last for a brief period and are accompanied by nausea. She had a recent upper respiratory tract infection. During the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, a brief episode of nystagmus is elicited. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Epley’s manoeuvre:

  • The above given is the case of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).
  • Attacks of vertigo are usually episodic and less than one minute.
  • The symptoms are due to defect of semi-circular canal defect.
  • BPPV patients usually do not have cochlear symptoms like hearing loss and tinnitus.
  • The patient has episodes of vertigo lying down and reclining, which are typical for BPPV.
  • The dix-hall pike method is used to diagnose BPPV.
  • In refractory cases, patients undergo surgery.
  • Epley's maneuver can also be used for symptomatic treatment. It is based on the theory of 'sialolithiasis' in order to move the particles from the posterior canal into the utricle via the common crus.
  • Vertigo: Few seconds to minutes.
  • Positional: Due to change in head position → Due to displacement of otoconia into posterior semi-circular canal → Otolith.
  • Diagnosis confirmed by → Dix-Hallpike’s maneuver.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Intralabyrinthine streptomycin: Streptomycin sulfate is a well-known ototoxic drug used to treat Meniere's disease.

Option B- Intralabyrinthine steroids: It is sometimes used in a refractory type of vestibulitis.

Option C-Valsalva maneuver:

  • The Valsalva maneuver is performed by moderately forceful attempted exhalation against a closed airway, usually done by closing one's mouth and pinching one's nose while expelling air through the ear.
  • Used to see the mobility of the tympanic membrane or to check the patency of the eustachian tube.

questions.text: Which diagram illustrates the alterations in extracellular and intracellular fluid volumes as well as osmolarities once osmotic equilibrium has been established following the administration of a 3% NaCl infusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – C:

  • 3% NaCl is hypertonic (0.9% NaCl is isotonic).
  • Infusion (intravenous, part of Extracellular fluid volume) increases the osmolality of plasma and blood volume.
  • Increased plasma osmolality will draw water from the intracellular compartment by osmosis, leading to increased osmolality and decreased volume of the intracellular compartment.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A:

  • This is a graph for the infusion of isotonic normal saline.
  • Because intracellular volume is unchanged while extracellular volume increases by isotonic saline infusion.
  • The Plasma osmolality remains the same as normal saline is isotonic.

Option B - B:

  • This is a graph for SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone).
  • Excess anti-diuretic hormone cause free water retention, which causes an increase in both extracellular and intracellular volume.
  • An increase in both extracellular and intracellular volume decreases plasma osmolarity.

Option D - D:

  • This graph depicts intracellular and extracellular volume depletion.
  • Causes are sweating fever and diabetes insipidus.
  • Volume depletion causes increased plasma osmolarity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of chronic kidney disease presents to the emergency department with muscle weakness and palpitations. His initial electrocardiogram (ECG) shows tall peaked T waves and a widened QRS complex. Laboratory tests reveal a serum potassium level of 6.8 mEq/L. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient's hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Initiate Hemodialysis: Hemodialysis is the most appropriate initial management for this patient's severe hyperkalemia (serum potassium level of 6.8 mEq/L) due to his chronic kidney disease. Hemodialysis efficiently removes excess potassium from the bloodstream, quickly lowering the potassium levels. It is especially crucial when hyperkalemia is severe and associated with ECG changes, muscle weakness, or cardiac arrhythmias. This approach provides rapid and effective correction of hyperkalemia, addressing the underlying cause.

Causes of Hyperkalemia:

  1. Release of potassium from tissues: acidosis, tissue/cell breakdown (rhabdomyolysis, hemolysis, tumour lysis syndrome), decreased insulin (insulin normally drives potassium into cells), beta blockers and digoxin (inhibit the Na/K ATPase pump pump that normally brings potassium into the cells).
  2. Pseudohyperkalemia (falsely elevated levels): hemolysis, repeated fist clenching with a tourniquet in place, thrombocytosis or leukocytosis will leak out of cells.
  3. Decreased excretion: renal failure, aldosterone decrease (ACE inhibitors, ARB’s, Type 4 renal tubular acidosis, aldosterone inhibitors (spironolactone, eplerenone), potassium-sparing diuretics (triamterene, amiloride) and Addison disease.

Diagnosis:

  • ECG findings: Peaked T waves, widened QRS, short QT or prolonged PR

Treatment/Management of hyperkalemia:

  • If the hyperkalemia is severe or if ECG changes are present, give IV calcium gluconate (10mL of 10% solution). Calcium stabilizes the resting membrane potential of the myocardial membrane
  • Shift potassium into the intracellular compartment.
    1. Glucose and insulin
    2. Inhaled Beta 2 agonist, e.g. salbutamol, albuterol
    3. IV Sodium bicarbonate. Increase pH level, which shifts K+ into cells.
  • Remove potassium from the body.
    1. Kayexalate-GI potassium exchange resin (Na+/K+ exchange in the GI tract) absorbs K+ in the colon, preventing absorption (passed in stool).
    2. Hemodialysis: for intractable hyperkalemia and renal failure.
    3. Loop Diuretics (furosemide)
  • Treatment of the underlying cause

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Administer calcium gluconate:

  • Calcium gluconate can be used in hyperkalemia, but it primarily stabilizes the cardiac membrane and does not lower serum potassium levels. It is used to counteract the cardiac effects of hyperkalemia but does not address the underlying problem.

Option B - Start insulin and glucose infusion:

  • Insulin and glucose infusion can help shift potassium from the extracellular space into the intracellular space, temporarily lowering serum potassium levels. However, in cases of severe hyperkalemia, such as in this scenario, insulin and glucose infusion alone may not be sufficient, and it is not considered the most appropriate initial management.

Option D - Administer oral potassium supplements:

  • Administering oral potassium supplements would be contraindicated in a patient with hyperkalemia, especially when potassium levels are critically high. This option could worsen the condition and is not appropriate for managing acute hyperkalemia.

questions.text:
Which of the following statement is correct regarding the development of the clavicle?


	It is the first limb bone to complete ossification
	It is the last upper limb bone to begin ossification
	It develops through intramembranous ossification except for its medial end
	It ossifies by two ossification centers
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 3 only:

Clavicle:

  • The clavicle lies almost horizontally at the root of the neck. It is a crank-shaped cantilever that carries the scapula, so enabling the limb to swing clear of the trunk.
  • It transmits part of the weight of the limb to the axial skeleton. The lateral or acromial end of the bone is flattened and articulates with the medial side of the acromion, whereas the medial or sternal end is enlarged and articulates with the clavicular notch of the manubrium sterni and first costal cartilage.
  • The shaft is gently curved, being convex forwards in its medial two-thirds and concave forwards in its lateral third. The inferior aspect of the intermediate two-fifth is grooved in its long axis for the attachment of the subclavius; Laterally, the internal architecture of the clavicle is trabecular; there is a medullary cavity in its medial two-thirds.
  • The lateral two-fifths of the clavicle are flattened and have a superior and an inferior surface limited by an anterior and a posterior border.
  • The medial three-fifths of the shaft are cylindrical or prismoid in form and have four surfaces.
  • The sternal end of the clavicle is directed medially, downwards, and forwards and articulates with the clavicular notch of the manubrium sterni.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 3 only:

  • It is the first bone to begin ossification during the fifth and sixth weeks of gestation.
  • It is the last bone to complete ossification at about 21–25 years of age.

Option C - 1 & 2 only:

  • The clavicle begins to ossify before any other bone in the body by intramembranous ossification.
  • The shaft is ossified in condensed mesenchyme from two primary centers, medial and lateral, that appear between the fifth and sixth weeks of intrauterine life and fuse about the fourth to fifth day.
  • Cartilage then develops at both ends of the clavicle. The medial cartilaginous mass contributes more to growth in length than does the lateral mass; the two centers of ossification meet between the medial three-fifths and lateral two-fifths of the clavicle.
  • A secondary center for the sternal end appears in the late teens or even early twenties, usually 2 years earlier in females.
  • An acromial secondary center sometimes develops at around 18 to 20 years, but this epiphysis is always small and rudimentary and rapidly joins the shaft. Growth is usually complete by 23 years in both sexes.
  • The clavicle is the only long bone that has intramembranous ossification except for its medial end, which has endochondral ossification.

Option D - 2 & 3 only:

  • It develops from somatic (dorsal) lateral plate mesoderm, and the associated muscles develop from somatic mesoderm (from somites).
  • It has four ossification centers – two primary centers for the shaft and two secondary centers, one for each end.

questions.text: A 16-month-old male infant is admitted to the hospital with the following clinical findings: bone deformities, jaundice with pallor, recurrent episodes of fever, difficulty breathing for seven days, retardation in growth, indicative of grade 2 Protein-calorie malnutrition, no notable family history of any specific disease. Which medical condition this skull X-ray findings could be indicative of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Thalassemia:

  • In this case, the given X-ray shows ''Hair on End''' or "Crew Cut appearance, which is a characteristic feature of Thalassemia.
  • The hair-on-end appearance of the skull is a characteristic feature of chronic haemolysis in patients with thalassaemia and sickle cell anaemia.
  • Accentuated vertical trabeculae between the inner and outer tables of the skull cause this appearance.
  • It is because of excessive bone marrow hyperplasia.
  • Thalassemia can make the bone marrow expand and widens the bones.
  • This causes abnormal bone structure, especially in the face and skull region. It also makes bone more fragile, thin and brittle.
  • The skull manifestations of thalassaemia include:
    • Widening of the diploic space
    • Thinning of the inner and outer tables
    • Prominent secondary trabeculae.
    • The occipital bone is spared (lack of haemopoietic bone marrow)
  • Investigation into Thalassemia includes:
    • Microcytosis (Low MCV)
    • Hypochromia (low MCH)
    • Targeting of the red cells
    • Nucleated red cells
    • Marked anisopoikilocytosis
    • Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia
    • Elevated LDH
    • Reduced osmotic fragility
    • Lateral x-ray skull- Hair on end appearance or crew-cut appearance

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Acute Myeloid Leukemia:

  • It is a DNA mutation in the bone marrow stem cell that produces red blood cells, platelets and white blood cells.
  • This mutation causes the stem cells to produce excessive white blood cells that are needed.

Option B- Iron deficiency anaemia:

  • Iron deficiency anaemia is a common type of anaemia that affects red blood cells
  • The patient's blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells.
  • As the name implies, iron deficiency anaemia is due to insufficient iron.

Option C- Megaloblastic Anemia:

  • It is a blood disorder in which bone marrow produces stem cells that make abnormally large red blood cells.
  • It is caused by vitamin B12 or folate deficiency and results in anaemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with progressive muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing, and slurred speech. He has a family history of a similar condition. Physical examination reveals muscle wasting and weakness. Neurological assessment suggests a peripheral neuropathy. You suspect a sphingolipidosis and consider possible diagnoses.Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is MOST LIKELY associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
C) Glucocerebrosidase (Correct Option):

  • Glucocerebrosidase deficiency is associated with Gaucher's disease, a type of sphingolipidosis.
  • Gaucher's disease is characterized by the accumulation of glucocerebroside (a type of sphingolipid) in various organs, particularly the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.
  • Common clinical manifestations of Gaucher's disease include hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, pancytopenia, bone pain, and fatigue.
  • The accumulation of glucocerebroside in macrophages leads to the formation of Gaucher cells, which are seen in affected tissues.

Now, let's explain the incorrect options:

A) Alpha-galactosidase A (Incorrect Option):

  • Alpha-galactosidase A deficiency is associated with Fabry disease, another sphingolipidosis.
  • Fabry disease primarily affects the kidneys, heart, and skin. Clinical features include renal dysfunction, cardiomyopathy, and skin lesions, such as angiokeratomas.

B) Acid sphingomyelinase (Incorrect Option):

  • Acid sphingomyelinase deficiency is associated with Niemann-Pick disease, a sphingolipidosis.
  • Niemann-Pick disease can present with hepatosplenomegaly, neurologic symptoms, and a cherry-red macula on eye examination.

D) Beta-hexosaminidase A (Incorrect Option):

  • Beta-hexosaminidase A deficiency is associated with Tay-Sachs disease, yet another sphingolipidosis.
  • Tay-Sachs disease primarily affects the nervous system and results in progressive neurodegeneration, particularly in infancy and early childhood. It does not typically involve muscle weakness, muscle wasting, or peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: In the evaluation of renal function in a 35-year-old woman with a long-standing history of type 1 diabetes mellitus since childhood, urinary proteins are found to be positive. A comprehensive assessment of her renal function reveals a creatinine clearance measurement of 135 ml/min. What is the most likely estimate of her glomerular filtration rate (GFR)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 125 mL/min:

  • The creatinine clearance from the plasma is used in clinical settings to get an approximate measurement of GFR. However, the creatinine clearance is an overestimate of the actual GFR by about 5%-10%.
  • As creatinine clearance is given as 135 ml/min in the above case, correction of the overestimate by a value of 5-10% would give an approximate value of 120ml/min to 128ml/min. Hence 125 ml/min is the closest answer in this range.
  • Creatinine clearance = (U X V) /P ≈ GFR
  • Where U= creatinine concentration in urine
  • V= rate of urine flow in mL/min (volume/time)
  • P= creatinine concentration in plasma
  • The urinary excretion rate of creatinine is an overestimate of GFR by 10%-15%, as some creatinine in urine comes by tubular secretion.
  • Contrarily, plasma creatinine value is also a false overestimate by about 5%-10% due to the Jaffe reaction. These two errors cancel out to some extent.
  • Hence, the clearance of creatinine (U*V/P) is overestimated by about 5%-10%.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - 100 mL/min:

  • Although the creatinine clearance overestimates the GFR, the magnitude of the overestimation is generally 5 to 10 %.
  • Such a large overestimation is unlikely to be true.

Option C - 135 mL/min:

  • The creatinine clearance overestimates GFR. Hence, the GFR must be slightly lower than the creatinine clearance.

Option D - 140 mL/min:

  • The creatinine clearance overestimates GFR. Hence, the GFR must be slightly lower than the creatinine clearance.

questions.text: In the emergency room, a 67-year-old male patient presents with the abrupt onset of right hemiplegia and dysarthria. Upon evaluation, he is diagnosed with intracranial hemorrhage located in the left basal ganglia and temporal lobe. Given the involvement of the temporal lobe, there is suspicion of injury to the primary auditory cortex. In which specific area of the brain is the primary auditory cortex located?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Superior Temporal Gyrus:

  • The auditory cortex is an integral part of the temporal lobe that can process auditory information in humans. The superior temporal gyrus is an important part of the auditory system performing functions in hearing, such as relations to language switching.
  • The Primary Auditory Cortex is a structure located in the superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe and receives point-to-point input from the medial geniculate complex.
  • The primary Auditory Cortex is found bilaterally, roughly at the top sides of the temporal lobes in humans, on the superior temporal plane, within the lateral fissure, and containing sections of Heschl’s gyrus and the superior temporal gyrus, which includes planum polare and planum temporale (Brodmann areas 41, 42, and partially 22).

Functions of auditory cortex:

  • The auditory cortex is involved in activities such as identifying and segregating auditory objects and identifying the location of a sound in space.
  • Damage to the auditory cortex results in the loss of awareness of sound. Still, the ability to react reflexively to sounds remains intact as there is subcortical processing in the auditory brainstem and midbrain.
  • Auditory neural pathways and their nuclei hair cells are innervated by dendrites of bipolar cells of spiral ganglion, which is situated in Rosenthal's canal (the canal running along the osseous spiral lamina). Axons of these bipolar cells form the cochlear division of CN VIII and end in the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei on each side of the medulla. Further course of auditory pathways is complex. From cochlear nuclei, the main nuclei in the ascending auditory pathways, sequentially, from below upwards, are:
  1. Superior olivary complex
  2. The nucleus of the lateral lemniscus
  3. Inferior colliculus
  4. Medial geniculate body
  5. Auditory cortex
  • The auditory fibers travel via the ipsilateral and contralateral routes and have multiple decussation points. Thus, each ear is represented in both cerebral hemispheres. The area of the cerebral cortex concerned with hearing is situated in the superior temporal gyrus (Brodmann's area 41).
  • For auditory pathways, remember the mnemonic E. COLI-MA: Eighth nerve, Cochlear nuclei, Olivary complex, Lateral lemniscus, Inferior colliculus, Medial geniculate body, and Auditory cortex.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B- Inferior Temporal Gyrus:

  • It is a false statement.
  • The inferior temporal gyrus is one of the three gyri of the temporal lobe and is present below the middle temporal gyrus, connected behind the inferior occipital gyrus; it also extends around the inferolateral border onto the inferior surface of the temporal lobe, where the inferior sulcus limits it. The middle temporal gyrus and inferior temporal gyrussubserve language and semantic memory processing, visual perception, and multimodal sensory integration.

Option C- Area 3,1,2:

  • It is a false statement.
  • The primary somatosensory cortex is numbered rostral to caudal as 3 1, 2. The region is associated with several senses, such as the ones for localization of touch, temperature, vibration, pain, sensory perception (two-point discrimination), and proprioception.

Option D- Cingulate Gyrus:

  • It is a false statement.
  • It is an important part of the limbic system. It helps regulate emotions and pain. It is also involved in predicting and avoiding negative consequences.

questions.text: The newborn requires immediate resuscitation, and a bag and mask are employed for this purpose. What is the function of the specific part pointed out by the black arrow in the accompanying picture?

choices.text: Increase pressure delivered to the baby
Increase O2 delivered to the baby

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Increase O2 delivered to the baby:

  • In this scenario, the mother has gestational diabetes, which is a risk factor for premature birth.
  • Prolonged and obstructed labour leads to fetal distress.
  • Intraoperatively there is a double loop of cord around the neck.
  • Immediate resuscitation is required as the baby is premature.
  • The non-rebreather masks are used for flushing oxygen in emergencies.
  • A black arrow is pointed at the reservoir bag.
  • Reservoir increases the FiO2 delivered to the baby..
  • This reservoir bag is attached to the oxygen tank.
  • One-way valves don’t let the exhaled air re-enter the oxygen reservoir.
  • These non-rebreather masks provide 60-80% of oxygen at a flow rate of 10-15 litres/minute.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Increase pressure delivered to the baby:

  • Increased pressure is delivered to the baby by positive pressure ventilation.
  • Positive pressure ventilation is provided by the umbo-bag.
  • Positive pressure ventilation requires continuous positive pressure manually.

Option B - Maintain PEEP:

  • PEEP positive end-expiratory pressure exists at the end of expiration.
  • It is provided by a mechanical ventilator.

Option D- Coordinate ventilation with chest compressions:

  • The oxygen reservoir is not used to coordinate ventilation with chest compressions.
  • It has nothing to do with chest compressions.
  • It is only reserved oxygen in the form of a reservoir.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms plays a role in facilitating the absorption of glucose from the gut?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Secondary active transport:

  • Glucose absorption from the gut occurs as co-transport (secondary active transport) with Na+ via transporter SGLT-1 (sodium-glucose transporter).
  • SGLT1 mediates almost all sodium-dependent glucose uptake in the small intestine.
  • All SGLT proteins have 14 transmembrane helices in topology.
  • SGLT1 is the prime intestinal glucose transporter unequivocally, even at high luminal glucose concentrations.
  • This mechanism determines the rate of glucose entry into the bloodstream under both low and high carbohydrate loads in the gut.
  • SGLT1 mediates glucose-induced incretin secretion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Simple diffusion:

  • It is the process in which solutes are passed through the concentration gradient in a solution across a semipermeable membrane.
  • The assistance of membrane proteins is not required in this diffusion process wherein substances move from higher concentration to lower.
  • Due to its polar nature and large size, glucose molecules cannot traverse the cell's lipid membrane by simple diffusion.
  • After digestion, a few monosaccharides diffuse into the blood based on the concentration gradient. Example: Glucose, amino acids and ions like chloride.
  • Simple diffusion does not require energy:

Option B - Facilitated diffusion:

  • Glucose exits the cell to the bloodstream via GLUT -2 (facilitated diffusion).
  • In facilitated diffusion, molecules diffuse across the plasma membrane with assistance from membrane proteins, such as channels and carriers.
  • A concentration gradient exists for these molecules, so they have the potential to diffuse into (or out of) the cell by moving down it.
  • Facilitated diffusion requires a source of ATP.

Option C - Primary active transport:

  • Primary active transport, also called direct active transport, directly uses chemical energy (such as from adenosine triphosphate or ATP in the case of the cell membrane) to transport all species of solutes across a membrane against their concentration gradient.
  • In primary active transport, the energy is derived directly from the breakdown of ATP.
  • Primary active transport moves ions across a membrane and creates a difference in charge across that membrane.
  • The cells along the small intestine use primary active transport to ensure that glucose only flows one way: From digested food to the inside of the cells.
  • The sodium-potassium pump is an example of an active transport pump.

questions.text:
Non-essential amino acids are synthesized from different substrates within our body. Match the non-essential amino acids and their synthesizing substrate pair.


	
		
			
			1. Serine
			
			
			a. Phenylalanine
			
		
		
			
			2. Cysteine
			
			
			b. Pyruvate
			
		
		
			
			3. Tyrosine
			
			
			c. Methionine
			
		
		
			
			4. Proline
			
			
			d. Glycine
			
		
		
			 
			
			e. Oxaloacetate
			
		
		
			 
			
			f. Ornithine
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- 1d, 2c, 3a, 4f:

  • Non-essential amino acids are synthesized in our body through from various substrates.
  • Glycine can be synthesized from:
    • CO2 and NH4 by glycine synthase (N5, N10 methylene THF involved).
    • Glyoxylate by glycine aminotransferase or glycine transaminase (PLP required).
    • Serine by serine hydroxyl methyl transferase (reversible) – (PLP and folic acid required) –N5, N10 methylene THF involved.
    • Threonine – by threonine aldolase glycine cleavage.
  • Cysteine is synthesized from methionine involving the following enzymes:
    • Cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) and
    • Cystathionine gamma-lyase (CSE).

  • Tyrosine is synthesized in the body from phenylalanine by the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase.

  • Proline can be synthesized from ornithine and glutamate.
    • Ornithine to proline conversion is mediated by the enzyme OAT (Ornithine aminotransferase)

​​​​​​​

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C and D: Refer to explanation of B

questions.text: In the emergency department, a 70-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of visual and balance disturbances. He reports that while sitting in his chair at home earlier in the evening, he experienced a sensation of the room spinning around him. When he attempted to stand up, he felt dizzy and had difficulty navigating, leading to unintentional collisions with furniture. Upon examination, he exhibits nystagmus and left homonymous hemianopia. The patient's blood pressure is measured at 170/80 mmHg, and all other vital signs are within normal limits. A head MRI scan reveals evidence of an acute ischemic infarct. What type of stroke has occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Posterior circulation stroke (POCS):

  • Posterior circulation stroke is caused by occlusion of vertebral, basilar, cerebellar, or posterior cerebral vessels.
  • POCS affects the brainstem, cerebellum, and occipital lobe.
  • Its symptoms include:
    • Vertigo
    • Nystagmus
    • Homonymous Hemianopia
    • Ataxia
    • Blurry vision
    • Headache
    • Dysarthria
  • Oxfordshire community stroke project (OCSP) classification: syndromes and imaging examples

OCSP term

Clinical features

Vascular basis

Example CT

Example MRI

Total anterior circulation syndrome (TACS)
  • Hemiparesis AND
  • Higher cortical dysfunction (dysphasia or viscuospatial neglect) AND
  • Homonymous hemianopia

Usually proximal middle cerebral artery (MCA) or ICA occlusion

Partial anterior circulation syndrome (PACS)
  • Isolated higher cortical dysfunction or
  • Any two of hemiparesis, higher cortical dysfunction, hemianopia

Usually branch MCA occlusion

Posterior circulation syndrome (POCS)

Isolated hemiaanopia (posterior cerebral artery (PCA) brainstem or cerebellar syndromes

Occlusion of vertebral, basilar, cerebellar or PCA vessels

Lacunar syndrome (LACS)
  • Pure motor stroke or
  • Pure sensory stroke
  • Sensorimotor stroke
  • Ataxic hemiparesis
  • Clumsy hand-dysarthria

Small penetrating artery occlusion, usually in lenticulostriate branches of MCA, or supply to brainstem or deep white matter

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Lacunar stroke (LACS):

  • The following types of lacunar stroke can occur:
  • Pure motor
  • Pure sensory
  • Sensorimotor
  • Ataxic hemiparesis
  • Clumsy hand-dysarthria

Option B- Partial anterior circulation stroke (PACS):

  • A partial anterior circulation stroke (PACS) is a less severe form of TACS, in which less than two-thirds of symptoms of TACS are seen because only part of the anterior circulation has been compromised.
  • In PACS, only a branch of the middle cerebral artery is occluded.

Option D- Total anterior circulation stroke (TACS):

  • TACS is caused by occlusion of the proximal middle cerebral artery or internal carotid artery.
  • It is associated with unilateral hemiplegia, homonymous hemianopia, and higher cortical dysfunction (aphasia/apraxia).

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient is scheduled for an elective hip replacement surgery. Before the procedure, a pre-operative electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed, and the ECG tracing is provided below. Based on the ECG findings, what is the most likely jugular venous pressure (JVP) abnormality that may be present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Absent A wave:

Jugular venous pressure (JVP)

  • The JVP consists of the "a" wave, "c" wave and "v" waves. Also, it has the "x" descent and "y" descents.
  • “A” wave in the JVP defines the Atrial contraction leading to blood being pumped into the right ventricle through the tricuspid valve. As the right atrium contracts, some blood gets pumped back into the internal jugular vein leading to the formation of “A” waves in the JVP.
  • In atrial fibrillation, the electrical activity is distorted due to the fibrillatory currents from multiple foci leading to loss of coordinated atrial contraction.
  • ECG shows irregular RR interval in the later part of ECG of Atrial fibrillation.
  • Thus, the ECG shows an Absent A wave in Atrial fibrillation

Incorrect Options: 

Option B- Cannon A waves:

  • Cannon A waves were found in Complete Heart Block & Junctional tachycardia.
  • These are seen in the atria and ventricles contract simultaneously, and the right atrium contracts against a closed tricuspid valve resulting in back pressure into the venous system. This back pressure is seen as a high-amplitude "cannon wave".

Option C- Giant V wave:

  • A Giant V wave is seen in Tricuspid Regurgitation due to increased backflow of blood into the right atrium.

Option D- Rise in JVP during Inspiration:

  • A rise in JVP during Inspiration is the Kussmaul sign seen in constrictive pericarditis or restrictive cardiomyopathy. As the cardiac chambers are being compressed from the outside (by the pericardium and thickened restrictive myocardium), it causes impaired ventricular filling and back pressure towards the veins leading to increased JVP.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient presents to OPD with complaints of breathlessness and fatigue. On examination, there is the left-side displacement of the apex beat and anacrotic shudder present. What is the dynamic auscultation murmur finding that occurs in this patient?

choices.text: Hand grip – Decreased intensity, On Valsalva – phase II – Increased Intensity, Rapid squatting – increased intensity.
Hand grip – Increased intensity, On Valsalva – phase II – Increased Intensity, Rapid squatting – Decreased intensity.
Hand grip – Decreased intensity, On Valsalva – phase II – Decreased Intensity, Rapid squatting – Increased intensity.
Hand grip – Increased intensity, On Valsalva – phase II – Decreased Intensity, Rapid squatting – Increased intensity.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Hand grip – Decreased intensity, On Valsalva – phase II – Decreased Intensity, Rapid squatting – Increased intensity:

  • The presence of an anacrotic shudder/ carotid thrill and left-side displacement of the apex beat is suggestive of aortic stenosis.
  • On hand grip manoeuver, there is an increase in afterload which results in a decrease in the intensity of murmur in aortic stenosis.
  • On Valsalva- phase II standing up, there is a decrease in preload which results in a decrease in the intensity of murmur in aortic stenosis.
  • On rapid Squatting, there an increase in venous return, increase in preload, and afterload which results in an increase in the intensity of murmur in aortic stenosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and D are incorrect

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of diabetes and hypertension discontinues her hypertension medication and subsequently experiences breathlessness. A chest X-ray is ordered to investigate her symptoms. In the chest radiograph, where are Kerley B lines typically located?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Location D:

  • Kerley B Lines are Short horizontal lines perpendicular to the pleural surface at lung bases and represent oedema of the interlobular septa.
  • It is seen in Location D in the given chest X-ray

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Location C:

  • Location C in the given chest X-ray is Kerley C Lines
  • Kerley C Lines are Reticular opacities at the lung base.

Option C - Location B:

  • Location B in the given chest X-ray is Dilated Pulmonary Vessels

Option D - Location A:

  • Location A in the given chest X-ray is Kerley A lines
  • Kerley A lines are Linear opacities extending from the periphery to the hila

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is NOT commonly associated with late congenital syphilis in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Mulberry molars:

  • Mulberry molars are not a common feature of congenital syphilis. They are characteristic dental abnormalities seen in congenital syphilis, specifically in the early congenital form, affecting the first molars. These teeth have multiple poorly developed cusps, giving them a rough, irregular appearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hutchinson's teeth: Hutchinson's teeth are a characteristic dental sign seen in late congenital syphilis. It refers to notched, widely spaced, and peg-shaped permanent upper central incisors. This dental abnormality is due to the effect of syphilis on tooth development.

Option B - Saber shins: Saber shins are a deformity of the shinbone (tibia) seen in congenital syphilis. The tibia becomes curved forward, resembling a saber or sword, hence the name. This condition is caused by inflammation and thickening of the bone's periosteum due to syphilis infection.

Option D - Saddle nose deformity: Saddle nose deformity occurs when the bridge of the nose collapses, resulting in a flat, broad appearance. This deformity can be seen in congenital syphilis, particularly in the later stages, due to the destruction of the nasal cartilage by the syphilis infection.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female with a history of epilepsy is prescribed a new antiepileptic drug (AED) to manage her seizures. She has been previously treated with carbamazepine, which was effective but resulted in troublesome side effects. She is now started on a second-line AED, lamotrigine. After a few weeks on lamotrigine, she presents with a diffuse, erythematous, and maculopapular rash on her trunk, limbs, and face, accompanied by mild fever. Her vital signs are stable, and she reports no other symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this adverse event?

choices.text: Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS): This clinical scenario describes an adverse reaction to lamotrigine, a commonly used antiepileptic drug. The patient's presentation is suggestive of Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS), also known as drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome (DIHS). DRESS is characterized by a diffuse rash, fever, lymphadenopathy, and internal organ involvement, typically occurring 2-6 weeks after starting the offending medication. It can be caused by various drugs, including antiepileptic drugs.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS):

  • While Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a severe and potentially life-threatening skin condition characterized by blistering and mucous membrane involvement, the presentation in the scenario does not align with SJS. DRESS typically involves a maculopapular rash, fever, lymphadenopathy, and internal organ involvement, whereas SJS presents with painful blistering and mucous membrane erosions.

Option B - Drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE):

  • Drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE) is associated with various medications, including some antiepileptic drugs, but it typically presents with symptoms similar to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), such as arthralgia, myalgia, skin rash, and serositis. It does not typically present with a diffuse maculopapular rash or eosinophilia seen in the scenario.

Option D - Urticaria:

  • Urticaria is characterized by the sudden appearance of raised, red, and itchy skin lesions (hives). It is usually transient and does not involve a diffuse, erythematous, and maculopapular rash seen in the scenario. Additionally, urticaria is not typically associated with fever or eosinophilia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a complaint of a foul-smelling nasal discharge, nasal congestion, and a diminished sense of smell for the past few weeks. On examination, you notice yellowish-green nasal discharge and swelling of the nasal mucosa. Nasal endoscopy reveals the presence of polyps in the nasal cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Allergic Rhinitis with Nasal Polyps:

  • Allergic rhinitis can lead to the formation of nasal polyps, causing nasal congestion, foul-smelling discharge, and reduced sense of smell. This condition often presents with chronic symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute Bacterial Sinusitis: Acute sinusitis can cause nasal congestion and purulent nasal discharge, but the presence of polyps and chronic symptoms makes acute sinusitis less likely.

Option C - Viral Upper Respiratory Infection: Viral infections can cause nasal congestion and discharge, but the persistence of symptoms for weeks and the presence of polyps are not typical of a viral infection.

Option D - Nasal Foreign Body: Nasal foreign bodies can cause foul-smelling discharge and nasal symptoms, but the presence of polyps and chronicity of symptoms make this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text:
In a 43-year-old woman, a routine self-examination revealed a small, firm, painless lump in her left breast. Subsequent tests, including a biopsy, confirmed the presence of malignant cells in the breast. A surgical procedure removed a tumor measuring 1.5 cm in size, along with the excision of five lymph nodes, two of which were found to contain malignant cells. No other metastases were detected, but the patient has a family history of breast cancer on her maternal side.

What is an indication for considering adjuvant chemotherapy following mastectomy in this patient's case?

choices.text: Presence of malignant cells in biopsy
Adjuvant chemotherapy is not advisable for this patient

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Size > 1cm & lymph node positive:

  • Chemotherapy given after mastectomy is called adjuvant Chemotherapy.
  • Not all patients with breast cancer need Chemotherapy, but several factors play a role in deciding Chemotherapy.
  • Indications of Adjuvant therapy:
    • Size > 1cm
    • Lymph node positive
    • Size > 0.5cm and lymph node negative with adverse prognostic factor
  • Adverse prognostic factors are
    • High histological grade
    • Lymphovascular
    • HER-2-NEU positive.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Presence of malignant cells in biopsy:

  • The presence of malignant cells in biopsy is indicative of neoplasm.
  • It gives no clue whether the patient will benefit from adjuvant Chemotherapy.

Option C - Family history of breast cancer:

  • Multiple family members with a history of breast cancer indicate familial breast cancer.

Option D - Adjuvant Chemotherapy is not advisable for this patient:

  • Adjuvant Chemotherapy is indicated in patients with positive lymph nodes post-surgery.
  • It is also indicated in patients who are at high risk for recurrence.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with a 6-month history of progressive fatigue, urinary frequency, oliguria, facial puffiness, and growth delay. . Laboratory studies reveal low Na+, low K+, low phosphorus, low albumin, decreased bicarbonate levels, increased urine sodium, and positive glucose. A blood smear shows hypochromic, microcytic cells with basophilic stippling. The altered function of which of the following transporters is the most likely cause of this patient's abnormal laboratory studies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Symport:

  • The patient presents with symptoms of oliguria, and facial puffiness is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. It is caused due to dysfunction of transporters of renal tubules.
  • The altered function of symport is the most likely cause of these abnormal laboratory findings.

  • A symporter is a membrane protein that is involved in the transport of two different types of molecules across the cell membrane in the same direction.
  • Symports are present in renal tubules. Symports move sodium and chloride across tubular membranes.
  • Impaired absorption and different levels of tubules can cause different diseases. In the above-given case, there is impaired reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule due to the failure of symport, causing Fanconi syndrome.
  • Poor reabsorption of sodium, glucose, bicarbonate, potassium, and amino acid results in laboratory findings consistent with type 2 renal tubular acidosis and clinical symptoms of glycosuria, polyuria, dehydration, fatigue, and failure to thrive.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Antiport:

  • Antiport is the transfer of molecules in the opposite direction.
  • In the proximal convoluted transfer of molecule is in the same direction simultaneously. So, the antiport transport method is not applicable here.

Option C - Uniport:

  • Uniport is the transfer of one molecule. As we know, in renal tubules, there is a transfer of Na+ and Cl- simultaneously. So uniport transport method is not an option in the proximal convoluted tubule.

Option D - Endocytosis:

  • Endocytosis is when cells take substances from outside the cell by engulfing them in a vesicle. So, according to our case, which is related to the transport mechanism of the proximal convoluted tubule, this is a false answer.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with a persistent, non-resolving cough, fever, and chest pain. A bronchoscopy with biopsy is performed, and the findings are shown in the image below :



What is the most likely diagnosis based on the histological findings, and what is the primary clinical concern associated with this condition?

choices.text: Aspergillosis; risk of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis
Candidiasis; risk of systemic fungal dissemination

questions.solution:
