Correct Option A - Aspergillosis; risk of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis :

  • Aspergillus fumigatus is a fungus that causes invasive disease in immunocompromised human beings. It can cause a variety of clinical syndromes:
    • Allergic bronchi pulmonary aspergillosis is a condition in which inhaled spores provoke a hypersensitivity reaction.
    • Bronchopulmonary aspergillosis: In this condition, the fungus grows within the bronchioles' lumen, where fungal plugs may occur.
    • Aspergilloma: A fungal ball that grows within and is usually restricted to an existing lung cavity, for example, due to old tuberculosis or bronchiectasis.
    • Invasive aspergillosis: The fungus first causes pneumonia and later disseminates to involve other organs, for example, the brain, kidney or heart. Patients who develop this disease are usually immunocompromised, and it could be fatal.
  • The most concerning clinical manifestation of Aspergillus infection in the lungs is invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.
  • Tissue sections biopsy: Septate dichotomously branching hyphae at an acute angle (45 degrees) is characteristic of aspergillus infection.
  • The arrows in the picture below show the v-shaped branching of septate hyphae in the aspergillus.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Candidiasis; risk of systemic fungal dissemination:

  • When the candida is microscopically examined in KOH: pseudohyphae, true hyphae and budding yeasts are seen in tissue culture.
  • They form pseudohyphae and budding yeasts at 20°C while germ tubes at 37°C.

Option C - Mucormycosis; risk of tissue necrosis:

  • Mucormycosis is caused by Mucorales fungi.
  • In biopsy specimens of tissues infected with mucor: organisms are seen microscopically as non-septate hyphae with broad, irregular walls and branches that form more or less at right angles (about 90 degrees).

Option D - Histoplasmosis; risk of pleural effusion:

  • Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum and is associated with granulomatous inflammation in the lungs.
  • The histological appearance consists of mall oval-to-round yeast cells within macrophages; granulomatous inflammation may be present.

questions.text:
In a clinical setting, a 45-year-old patient with a history of chronic smoking seeks medical attention due to persistent hoarseness and a sensation of a foreign body in the neck that has been present for several weeks. A laryngoscopic examination is conducted, revealing specific findings captured in the provided image.

What is the most common site of distant metastasis associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Lung:

Laryngeal carcinoma:

  • Laryngeal carcinoma is the commonest head and neck malignancy comprising 30%-40% of all cases, the vast majority being squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Most commonly present with hoarseness of voice; less commonly with a neck mass, dysphagia, stridor, or hemoptysis.
  • Around 80% of tumors are glottic from the vocal cords, 15% are supraglottic, arising from the epiglottis, false cords, or aryepiglottic folds, and 5% are subglottic.
  • Local spread is along tissue planes, while the lymphatic spread is at the free edge of the glottis.
  • The most common site of loco-regional metastasis from laryngeal carcinoma is lymph nodes.
  • The most common site of distant metastasis from laryngeal carcinoma is the lungs.
  • The most common site of laryngeal carcinoma is the glottis.
  • The most common type of laryngeal carcinoma is squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Laryngeal cancer metastases are most typically noted in the loco-regional cervical lymph nodes. Distant metastases are seen mostly in the lungs (66%), bone (22%), liver (10%), mediastinum, and bone marrow.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Liver:

  • Distant metastasis occurs in the lungs, liver, and bone; however, the most common site of distant metastasis is the lungs.

Option C- Brain:

  • Distant metastasis occurs in the lungs, liver, bones, and brain; however, the most common site of distant metastasis is the lungs.

Option D- Bone:

  • Distant metastasis occurs in the lungs, liver, and bone; however, the most common site of distant metastasis is the lungs.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the gastroenterology clinic with complaints of fatigue and abdominal discomfort. On physical examination, he has mild hepatomegaly, and laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes. Further evaluation reveals chronic hepatitis C infection.Which of the following autoantibodies is MOST likely to be associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - LKM antibody:

  • Anti-LKM autoantibodies are differentiated from anti-mitochondrial antibodies using indirect immunofluorescence on stomach, kidney and liver tissue. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies stain distal renal tubules, whereas anti-LKM antibodies do not – both stain proximal tubules. Anti-LKM antibody is not a unique entity, and it compasses 3 types of anti-LKM antibody, namely anti-LKM-1, anti-LKM-2, and anti-LKM-3 (δ agent). These can be distinguished from each other by unique immunofluorescent staining patterns.LKM-1 is found on cells in the third portion of the proximal renal tubules and on hepatocytes. (May also react with cells in bronchial, oesophageal and duodenal epithelium).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Autoimmune cirrhosis:

  • Autoimmune hepatitis is liver inflammation that occurs when your body's immune system turns against liver cells. The exact cause of autoimmune hepatitis is unclear, but genetic and environmental factors appear to interact over time in triggering the disease.
  • Untreated autoimmune hepatitis can lead to scarring of the liver (cirrhosis) and eventually to liver failure. When diagnosed and treated early, however, autoimmune hepatitis often can be controlled with drugs that suppress the immune system.
  • A liver transplant may be an option when autoimmune hepatitis doesn't respond to drug treatments or in cases of advanced liver disease.

Option C - Antimitochondrial antibody:

  • Antimitochondrial antibodies (AMAs) is an example of an autoimmune response that occurs when the body turns against its own cells, tissues, and organs. When this happens, the immune system attacks the body as though it were an infection.
  • The AMA test identifies elevated levels of these antibodies in your blood. The test is most often used to detect an autoimmune condition known as primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), previously known as primary biliary cirrhosis.

Option D - None:

  • LKM antibodies are associated with Hepatitis C

questions.text: In the neonatal intensive care unit, a 2-week-old female neonate is brought in with a history of rapid breathing, minimal grunting during breathing, and a pale complexion for the past 4 hours. The mother reports that the neonate was born prematurely at the 29th week of gestation. Upon examination, the neonate exhibits significant nasal flaring, audible grunting sounds during respiration, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and a see-saw movement in the upper chest. The medical team uses the Silverman score to assess the neonate's condition. What should be the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Start continuous positive airway pressure CPAP

questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Start CPAP:

  • In this case, a 2-week-old female neonate presents to the neonatal intensive care unit with rapid breathing, minimal grunting with breathing, and pale colour. The mother gives the history of preterm birth at the 29th week. On examination, there is maximum nasal flaring, grunting sound audible with a stethoscope, heart rate is 110/min, and see-saw movement in the upper chest. Silverman score is used to determine the condition of neonates. This scenario indicates that the neonate is suffering from respiratory distress syndrome.
  • The Silverman-Andersen score is used to evaluate the severity of respiratory distress in newborn and preterm neonates without the help of respiratory support.
  • Almost 10% of babies at birth require some respiratory assistance. In respiratory distress syndrome, it is hard for babies to breathe properly. It can happen due to a genetic mutation that affects proper lung development.
  • CPAP is the most important step in managing neonates with respiratory distress syndrome. It is a simple, cost-effective, and non-invasive procedure, especially for neonates.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Give IV fluids:

  • IV fluids are given to neonates when the patient's blood pressure drops. IV fluids help to maintain the haemodynamic state of the patient.
  • Neonates who present with severe diarrhoea have dehydration, and IV fluids are given to compensate for the loss.

Option B- Give phototherapy:

  • It is a treatment that involves using a special type of light. Neonates who present with jaundice are suggested with phototherapy.
  • The whole body is exposed to light which helps to break down the bilirubin and excrete it out of the body through urine or stool.

Option C- Administer epinephrine via IV:

  • Epinephrine is an adrenaline medicine and hormone. It is used to increase the heart rate of the neonate.
  • Patients with a heart rate lower than 60 beats per min should be given IV epinephrine with proper protocol.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, seizures since birth, and distinctive physical features including a tall forehead, a flat facial appearance, and posterior flattening of the occiput. The infant also exhibits significantly reduced muscle tone and weak or absent deep tendon reflexes. Diagnostic tests reveal an increased accumulation of which specific substrate in the brain, contributing to this rare genetic disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Long chain fatty acids:

Zellweger syndrome

  • It is also called as Cerebro-Hepato-Renal Syndrome.
  • It is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder that is caused by mutations in genes encoding certain proteins – the PEX family of genes, also called peroxins that are involved in various steps of peroxisome biogenesis or genes encoding certain peroxisomal enzymes.
  • It results in an inherited absence of peroxisomes in almost all tissues.
  • Peroxisomes are responsible for the oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA), which contain more than 22 carbons. Therefore, accumulation of VLCFA (C > 22) occurs especially in the brain, as brain sphingomyelins are rich in long-chain fatty acids.
  • Biochemical findings include an accumulation of VLCFA, abnormalities in the synthesis of bile acids, and a marked reduction of plasmalogens.

Clinical features

  • Severe neurological symptoms due to impaired neuronal migration and hypomyelination (impaired intellectual development, hypotonia, seizures, decreased/absent tendon reflexes).
  • Feeding difficulties and failure to thrive.
  • Flat facies, posterior flattening of the occiput.
  • Hepatomegaly and formation of renal cysts.
  • Most patients die within the first year of life.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Glucose:

  • Glucose metabolism occurs in the cytoplasm and does not involve the peroxisomes. Hence, the glucose metabolism will remain normal.

Options B - Lactic Acid:

  • Lactic acid metabolism occurs in the cytoplasm and does not involve the peroxisomes. Hence, the lactic acid metabolism will remain normal.

Option D - Triglycerides (TG):

  • Here TG refers to stored adipose tissue TG.
  • Peroxisomes are involved in α-oxidation for branched-chain amino acids and oxidation of VLCFA.
  • As adipose tissue, TG generally does not contain either of these two types of fatty acids, so the metabolism of TG will not be affected.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms would typically demonstrate the following characteristics in a hair perforation test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Trichophyton mentagrophytes:

  • Trichophyton mentagrophytes is known to invade the hair follicle, leading to a positive hair perforation test. This test involves the penetration of fungal hyphae into the hair shaft, resulting in its perforation or invasion. T. mentagrophytes is a common dermatophyte that can cause various skin and nail infections, including tinea corporis (ringworm) and tinea pedis (athlete's foot).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Microsporum canis: Microsporum canis primarily invades the hair shaft, not the hair follicle, and would typically result in a negative hair perforation test.

Option C - Trichophyton rubrum: Trichophyton rubrum typically shows a negative hair perforation test, as it primarily infects the hair shaft and not the hair follicle.

Option D -Epidermophyton floccosum: Epidermophyton floccosum primarily affects the skin's superficial layers and does not invade the hair, leading to a negative hair perforation test.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of injuries after falling off a ladder. He describes falling about 5 feet off the ground and suffering blunt trauma to his perineum and penis, resulting in immediate pain lasting 5 minutes. Following the injury, the patient experienced burning with urination and noted large amounts of hematuria. He denies pain with ambulation and does not recall any trauma to the pelvis during the fall. Genitourinary examination reveals blood at the urethral meatus. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Observation and admission to the hospital

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Placement of a suprapubic catheter:

  • Suprapubic catheterization is the best initial treatment for patients suffering from urethral injury following blunt pelvic trauma. Surgical intervention is delayed days or weeks after the initial injury.
  • An understanding of the anatomy and physiology of the male reproductive system is important to understand the need for this intervention.
  • Patients who present following urethral trauma should be initially managed in the context of other injuries. The best initial approach involves the placement of a suprapubic catheter for urinary drainage, which does not require urethral manipulation or invasion into the pelvic hematoma if one happens to be present. Ideally, surgical repair of posterior urethral injury is performed 6-12 weeks after injury, after stabilization of injuries an

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Antibiotic therapy: Although antibiotic therapy is often required, it is important to first take measures to preserve organ function. It is paramount to establish bladder drainage, so suprapubic catheterization should take precedence.

Option B - Endoscopic transurethral realignment: Early endoscopic realignment using a transurethral, percutaneous transvesical, or combined approach may be attempted, but this should be done 5-7 days post-injury. By this time, the patient's overall condition has usually improved, and sepsis is less of a concern.

Option C - Observation and admission to the hospital: Observation with admission to the hospital is not adequate for the treatment of urethral injury and places the patient at risk for severe sequelae.

questions.text: The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is designed to assess the overall quality of life or well-being of a country. It includes measurements of various components. However, which of the following components is NOT measured in the PQLI?

choices.text: Life expectancy at 1 year of age

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Income (real GDP per capita):

  • Income (real GDP per capita) is not a component of PQLI.
  • PQLI does not measure economic growth.
  • Whereas, it is a component of HDI.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Life expectancy at 1 year of age:

  • The life expectancy at 1 year of age is one of the three components of PQLI.
  • The PQLI measures social, political, and economical policies.

Option B - Infant mortality rate:

  • The infant mortality rate is one of the three components of PQLI.

Option D - Literacy rate:

  • The literacy rate is also a component of PQLI.

questions.text: In the process of lipid metabolism, HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein) plays a crucial role by receiving cholesterol from peripheral tissues and converting it into cholesterol ester. Additionally, it exchanges lipids with LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein) through a protein known as Cholesterol Ester Transfer Protein (CETP) while circulating in the bloodstream. All of the following are true about CETP, except:

choices.text: Facilitates the transfer of cholesterol ester from HDL to LDL
Facilitates the transfer of triacylglycerol from LDL to HDL
Facilitates the transfer of triacylglycerol from HDL to LDL

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Facilitates the transfer of triacylglycerol from HDL to LDL:

Cholesterol ester transfer protein (CETP):

  • CETP, also known as plasma lipid transfer protein, is a transport protein synthesized in the liver and released in the blood and bound to HDL (option A is true).
  • It facilitates the transfer of cholesterol ester from HDL to VLDL, IDL and LDL in exchange for triacylglycerol (option B is true).
  • This helps in relieving the product inhibition of the LCAT (lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase) enzyme as LCAT is inhibited by its product cholesterol esters. So, CETP, by removing cholesterol esters from HDL, relives this inhibition.
  • It also transfers TG from VLDL, IDL and LDL to the HDL (option C is true but D is false)

  • A deficiency of CETP is associated with increased HDL levels and decreased LDL levels, a profile that is typically antiatherogenic.

Incorrect options:

Option A, B and C: Refer to explanation of Option D.

questions.text: A newborn boy is evaluated in the labour room due to respiratory distress. The born was born full term 2 hours ago to a 25-year-old primigravida, who did not seek prenatal care. On examination, his temperature is 37.2°C (98.9F), heart rate is 140/min, and respiratory rate is 36/min. The pulse oximeter shows an oxygen saturation of 83%. Physical examination reveals a diffusely cyanosed newborn with grunting and subcostal retractions. The abdomen appears scaphoid, while the chest appears round in shape. Auscultation reveals an absent breath sound on the left side of the chest, along with a gurgling sound. Right-sided chest auscultation is normal. A cardiac examination reveals clear heart sounds best appreciated on the right chest. Chest x-ray reveals displaced cardiac silhouette and air-fluid levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Diaphragmatic hernia:

  • Diaphragmatic hernia: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) occurs when the diaphragm, the muscle that separates the chest from the abdomen, fails to close during prenatal development due to incomplete fusion of pleuroperitoneal folds.
  • Clinical features include cyanosis, respiratory distress, absent breath sounds ipsilateral to defect etc.
  • The defect is left-sided in most cases.
  • It can result in herniation of the bowel into the chest cavity, which can lead to pulmonary hypoplasia. Herniation into the chest causes a concave (flat) shaped abdomen with a barrel-shaped chest.
  • Chest x-ray shows intrathoracic bowel loops and displaced cardiac silhouette.

  • Management:
    • Endotracheal intubation is the initial step of management.
    • Gastric decompression by nasogastric tube.
    • Bag-and-mask ventilation is contraindicated because it pumps air into the gastrointestinal tract and can further deteriorate the condition.
    • Definitive management is surgical correction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Umbilical hernia: A congenital umbilical hernia occurs due to incomplete closure of abdominal muscles. Physical examination reveals a soft, non-tender bulge at the umbilicus, covered by skin and protrudes with increased intraabdominal pressure such as coughing, crying, straining etc.

Option B - Epigastric hernia: An epigastric hernia is a type of hernia that causes fat to push through a weakened area in the walls of the abdomen. It presents as a bulge in the epigastric area.

Option C - Pneumonia: Pneumonia presents with fever, productive cough, and crepitations on lung auscultation. Chest x-ray typically shows consolidation.

questions.text: In the pediatric outpatient department, a 9-month-old male infant is presented with symptoms of irritability, inadequate feeding, vomiting, and a complaint from his mother that his urine has an unusual odor resembling burnt sugar. Following a thorough physical examination, a urine sample from the infant is sent to the laboratory for analysis. Which of the following amino acids would not be detected in the urine test of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Phenylalanine:

  • This patient is suffering from maple syrup urine disease. A burnt sugar-like smell is a characteristic feature of this disease.
  • Valine, isoleucine, and leucine will be found in urine tests, but not phenylalanine.
  • Phenylalaine is present in the urine in case of phenylketonuria patients which also show musty body odor.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C and D - Leucine, Isoleucine, Valine:

Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD):

  • It is a rare autosomal recessive disease.
  • Typically present in children between 5 months to 7 years of age.
  • It occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched-chain keto-acid decarboxylase resulting in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids - valine, isoleucine, and leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in the urine.
  • It may cause increased alfa-ketoacid in blood, especially leucine.
  • Typical clinical presentation includes poor feeding, irritability, vomiting, loss of appetite, and poor muscle tone.
  • Urine smells like maple syrup or burnt sugar.
  • It may cause progressive neurological decline.
  • Mental retardation may occur due to increased isoleucine.
  • In untreated cases, the disease may progress to life-threatening coma or respiratory failure, and death can occur within a few months.
  • Treatment: Isoleucine, leucine, and valine restriction in diet and thiamine supplement.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a burn injury 2 hours ago. He was working in the kitchen his shirt caught fire accidentally. Examination reveals second-degree burns covering 20% of the total body surface area. The patient is immediately resuscitated with fluids. Which of the following fluids is most used in the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ringer lactate:

  • Ringer Lactate is the most commonly used fluid in burn patients.
  • Some centres use human albumin, fresh frozen plasma (FFP), or hypertonic saline
  • Intravenous resuscitation is appropriate for any child with a burn greater than 10% of total body surface area (TBSA) and 15% TBSA for adults
  • Rule of 9 is used to calculate the body surface area with a burn.
  • The most widely used and simplest formula to calculate fluid requirement is the Parkland formula

Volume = total percentage body surface area x weight (kg) x 4

Half this volume is given in the first 8 hours, and the second half is given in the subsequent 16 hours

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dextrose 5%:

  • Dextrose 5 % is a hypotonic fluid.
  • It is used to cover the free water deficit. It is not the best choice for burn patients.

Option B - Normal saline:

  • Normal saline is not used in burn patients as it contains chloride in an increased amount, and it can lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
  • Normal saline also increases the risk for hypercoagulability.

Option D - Albumin 5%:

  • Albumin 5% is a colloid. It is used in patients with hepatorenal syndrome and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
  • Although it can be used in burn patients, it is not the fluid of choice

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism of drug resistance in MRSA (Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus) as depicted in the provided figure illustrating biochemical resistance mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – A:

  • Resistance in MRSA occurs mainly because of altered penicillin-binding proteins.
  • This is marked as "A" in this scenario, wherein the modification of the target site is how MRSA commonly develops resistance.
  • The penicillin-binding proteins like transpeptidase are responsible for linking the peptidoglycan chains in the cell wall of the bacteria

Incorrect Options:

Option B - B:

  • Decreased permeability is the mode of resistance of some gonococci to penicillins

Option C - C:

  • Some organisms produce Beta lactamases, also known as penicillinase, that degrade the Beta lactate ring if the penicillin

Option D - D:

  • Bypass of the metabolism and forming the alternate pathway is a mode of resistance of some organisms to few drugs, not penicillin

Option E - E:

  • Efflux pumps are the property of resistance of some organisms to tetracyclines. The efflux pumps cause the efflux of the tetracycline before it can act on the protein synthesis

questions.text: A 28-year-old female is brought to the emergency department by her husband due to complaints of drowsiness, pinpoint pupils, and difficulty breathing. Physical examination reveals miosis, bluish discoloration of her fingers and nails, decreased body temperature, a pulse rate of 56bpm, and a blood pressure reading of 100/70 mmHg. Her Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is assessed at 9/15. The patient has a recent history of a leg fracture. What is the most likely cause of the patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Morphine:

  • This is a case of morphine poisoning in which the patient is brought to the emergency department with complaints of drowsiness and pinpoint pupils.
  • She had a history of leg fractures and was using excessive painkillers.
  • Due to the excessive use of morphine as a painkiller for a leg fracture, it got toxic.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Naloxone:

  • Naloxone is an opioid antagonist.
  • It is an antidote for Morphine overdose.

Option B - Flumazenil:

  • Flumazenil doesn't cause miosis.
  • It is used as an antidote to benzodiazepine.

Option D - Naltrexone:

  • Naltrexone is mainly used to reduce the craving in excessive alcohol users.
  • It can be combined given with morphine for the treatment of moderate to severe pain relief for a long period of time.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male with a history of hypertension and coronary heart disease presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset symptoms of difficulty swallowing, dizziness, and an inability to stand up, which have been occurring for the past 2 hours. On examination, the patient has a temperature of 37°C, blood pressure of 159/92 mmHg, pulse rate of 88 beats/min, and respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min. Neurological findings include diplopia, nystagmus, decreased sensation in the left face, right arm, and a change in voice.What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Lateral medullary syndrome:

  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) supplies the lateral medulla
  • Loss of blood supply to the lateral medullary structures produces different symptoms depending on the functions of the nuclei and pathways.
  • Limb ataxia, falling on the side of the lesion due to cerebellar hemisphere, cerebellar fibres, spinocerebellar tract
  • Nystagmus, diplopia, oscillopsia, vertigo, nausea, and vomiting due to vestibular nucleus
  • Horner's syndrome (miosis, ptosis, decreased sweating) due to the descending sympathetic tract
  • Dysphagia, hoarseness, palatal paralysis, vocal fold paralysis, decreased gag reflex
  • On the opposite side of the lesion:
    • Disturbance of pain and thermal perception on the contralateral half of the body and face due to the spinothalamic tract

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Medial medullary syndrome:

  • The medial medullary syndrome is manifested by paralysis and atrophy of half of the tongue on the side of the lesion.
  • Paralysis of the arm and leg (sparing the face), impaired sensation and proprioception contralateral to the lesion.

Option C- Midbrain syndrome:

  • The following findings manifest midbrain syndrome:
  • On the side of the lesion
    • Third nerve lesion: Eye down and out with dilated and unresponsive pupils
  • On the other side
    • Corticobulbar and corticospinal tract lesions
    • Paralysis of the face, arms and legs

Option D- Lateral midbrain syndrome:

  • The following findings manifest lateral midbrain syndrome,
  • On the side of the lesion:
    • Third nerve and nucleus lesions: Eye down and out with unresponsive and dilated pupils.
    • On the other side:
      • The red nucleus and the dentatorubrothalamic pathway: Tremor, hyperkinesia, and hemiataxia.

questions.text: What of the following is true regarding Ringertz tumor?

choices.text: Arises from the lateral wall of the nose.
Tumor of the olfactory mucosa of the nose.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Arises from the lateral wall of the nose:

  • The Ringertz tumor, also called transitional cell papilloma or inverted papilloma arises from the lateral wall of the nose (middle turbinate or ethmoid recess).
  • It can extend into the paranasal sinuses.

Inverted papilloma:

  • Inverted papilloma is a benign but locally invasive tumor that develops in the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavities.
  • Patients with a history of sinonasal infections are most likely diagnosed with it.
  • Inverted papilloma should be treated aggressively since they can develop into malignant tumors even if they are benign Tumors in about 5–12% of cases.
  • Patients usually complain of symptoms reminiscent of chronic rhinosinusitis, such as nasal congestion, discharge, headaches, and postnasal drip.
  • An inverted papilloma diagnosis is typically confirmed by a biopsy based on concerning features on C.T., M.R.I. or endoscopic appearance.
  • Surgery is the basis of treatment for inverted papilloma.
  • Inverted papilloma has a high likelihood of recurrence if not entirely removed.
  • Endoscopic procedures are primarily used for surgical resection.
  • Patients may require a wider resection or other therapies like chemotherapy or radiation therapy if any troubling characteristics appear after surgical resection, such as the emergence of a potentially malignant tumor.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Tumor of the olfactory mucosa of the nose:

  • Tumor of the non-olfactory mucosa of the nose (Schneiderian membrane) & PNS.
  • Olfactory neuroblastoma is a tumor that arises from the olfactory mucosa of the nose.

Option C - Treated by radiotherapy: Endoscopic excision is the treatment of choice for Ringertz tumor.

Option D- Age of onset 20-30 years: The age of onset of Ringertz tumor is 40-60 years, and it has a preference for males.

questions.text:
An eight-month-old male infant is brought to the emergency department by his mother, who reports episodes of tachypnea, irritability, and cyanosis around the mouth and hands during feeding. These episodes have been happening more frequently, but they tend to resolve on their own. After evaluating the presentation and suspecting Tetralogy of Fallot, the physician looks for a specific clinical sign to help identify a "cyanotic spell."

What clinical sign helps identify a "cyanotic spell" in this patient?

choices.text: Holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border

questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Disappearance of murmur:

Tetralogy of Fallot:

  • Most common congenital cyanotic heart disease in children that contains four components:
    • Large, unrestricted VSD
    • Pulmonary infundibular stenosis
    • Overriding aorta
    • Right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Clinical features of Tetralogy of Fallot:
    • Cyanosis
    • Clubbing
    • Polycythemia
    • Cyanotic spells
    • Heart failure is not seen in TOF unless it is complicated by Anemia /Infective endocarditis /Myocarditis / Systemic hypertension

A murmur in TOF:

  • A murmur in TOF is a systolic ejection murmur in the pulmonary area due to right ventricular outflow obstruction, i.e. sub-pulmonic stenosis and not due to the ventricular septal defect.
  • Thus, the murmur of TOF depends on the following:
    • Degree of pulmonary artery obstruction
    • Amount of flow across the obstruction
    • If an obstruction is less à more flow of blood --> increased intensity of the murmur
    • If an obstruction is more --> less flow of blood, --> murmur becomes softer
  • Therefore, during the cyanotic spell, there is a presence of severe obstruction causing a right to left shunt, which significantly decreases the amount of blood flow, and the murmur disappears.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B- Wide-fixed split of S2:

  • Wide-fixed splitting of S2 is seen in Atrial septal defect. ASD is not a part of anomalies seen in TOF.

Option C- Continuous machine-like murmur:

  • The murmur of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a continuous machine-like murmur heard at the left upper sternal border. PDA is not seen in TOF.

Option D- Holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border:

  • Holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border is seen in VSD. It is associated with TOF. However, it is the disappearance of the most common murmur of pulmonary stenosis that is specific to cyanotic spells.

questions.text:
Match the following weapons with their corresponding types of injuries.


	
		
			A. Lathi
			1. Incised wound
		
		
			B. Axe
			2. Tram track bruise
		
		
			C. Blade
			3. Grazed abrasion
		
		
			D. RTA
			4. Chop wound
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3:

A - Axe:

  • The correct match is option 4 - Chop wound.
  • An axe is a cutting tool with a sharp blade on one side and a handle on the other. When an axe is used forcefully to strike a person, it can cause a deep, wide, and often irregular wound known as a chop wound. This type of wound is characterized by ragged edges and a combination of sharp and blunt force injury.

B - RTA (Road Traffic Accident):

  • The correct match is option 3 - Grazed abrasion.
  • RTA refers to a Road Traffic Accident. In accidents involving vehicles, a person may slide or be dragged along the road surface, leading to abrasions. Grazed abrasions are shallow injuries where the outer layer of the skin is scraped off due to friction against the road surface. They usually appear as superficial scrapes or grazes.

C - Blade:

  • The correct match is option 1 - Incised wound.
  • A blade is a sharp-edged instrument, typically used for cutting. When a blade cuts through the skin, it creates an incised wound. Incised wounds have clean, smooth edges, and they are usually longer than they are deep.

D - Lathi:

  • The correct match is option 2 - Tram track bruise.
  • A lathi is a long, heavy stick often used as a weapon or tool. When a lathi strikes a person, it can cause a patterned bruise known as a tram track bruise. Tram track bruises are characterized by parallel linear marks that resemble the tracks of a tram. They occur due to the impact of the cylindrical shape of the lathi.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents with lower urinary tract symptoms, including increased frequency, nocturia, and hesitancy. A digital rectal examination reveals a hard, irregular, enlarged prostate gland. The serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level is elevated at 22 ng/mL. A prostate biopsy confirms the diagnosis of prostatic adenocarcinoma. You plan to evaluate the patient for metastatic disease and consider treatment options. Which of the following tumor markers should be assessed to evaluate the extent of the disease and its aggressiveness in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- AMACR:

  • Alpha-methylacyl-CoA-racemase (AMACR) is a molecular marker for prostatic adenocarcinoma - identified by complementary DNA microarray technology.
  • AMACR, also known as P504S, is an integral component of the immunohistochemistry (IHC) cocktail - used on H&E-stained prostatic tissue specimens when a diagnostic uncertainty is encountered with prostate biopsy.
  • AMACR is positive in prostate adenocarcinoma.

  • Low-power photomicrographs of serial tissue sections of the prostate gland, stained with hematoxylin and eosin (panel A), alpha-methyl acyl-CoA racemase (AMACR/P504S) (panel B), and 34bE12 (panel C).
  • The prostate adenocarcinoma stains positively for AMACR (brown stain) and negatively for 34bE12.
  • In contrast, the peripheral benign glands adjacent to the cancer stain negatively for AMACR but positively for 34bE12.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B- AFP:

  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is characteristic of a yolk sac tumour and may also be elevated in hepatocellular carcinomas.

Option C- Podoplanin:

  • Podoplanin is a useful marker for mesotheliomas and germ cell tumours, especially seminomas and dysgerminomas.

Option D- OCT ¾:

  • OCT ¾ is an important informative marker in germ cell tumours, especially gonadoblastoma, invasive embryonal carcinoma and seminomatous tumours.

questions.text: A 47-year-old patient arrives in an unconscious state. Upon clinical examination, the patient's heartbeat is irregular, and there is a discrepancy between the heartbeat and the pulse rate, indicating a pulse deficit. An ECG reveals findings consistent with atrial fibrillation. Following appropriate intervention and stabilization, the patient is discharged with a prescription for the anticoagulant dabigatran to prevent strokes. Which of the following anti-arrhythmic agents is typically utilized in such emergency situations?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Esmolol:

  • In the case of recent-onset atrial fibrillation (RAF) drug with short-term efficacy is required for immediate effect. For this purpose, esmolol is used.
  • Atrial fibrillation is an arrhythmia or irregular heartbeat with uncoordinated atrial activation, and ineffective atrial contraction results in inadequate blood flow into the ventricles.
  • Symptoms may include
    • Irregular heartbeat
    • Heart palpitations
    • Extreme fatigue
    • Shortness of breath
    • Chest pain
  • Esmolol is a beta blocker with ultrashort acting; it is devoid of partial agonistic or membrane stabilising actions.
  • Esterases in blood inactivate it.
  • Action disappears within 15–20 min after terminating intravenous infusion—the degree of β blockade can be titrated by regulating the infusion rate.
  • It has been used to terminate the following:
    • Supraventricular tachycardia
    • Episodic atrial fibrillation or flutter
    • Arrhythmia during anaesthesia
    • To reduce heart rate and blood pressure during and after cardiac surgery
    • In the early treatment of myocardial infarction

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Amiodarone:

  • Amiodarone is the longest-acting anti-arrhythmic drug.
  • It is recommended for the long-term suppression of arrhythmias.
  • It even takes several weeks to begin action.

Option C - Quinidine:

  • It is used to help prevent and treat atrial fibrillation and ventricular arrhythmias. When other medications have been tried but didn't work to treat the condition, Quinidine is prescribed.
  • It is proven safe and effective in pharmacological cardioversion of long-lasting Atrial fibrillation.

Option D - Verapamil:

  • Verapamil is a vital and considered safe modality of treatment for the long-term control of heart rate in chronic atrial fibrillation.
  • Chronic oral treatment with verapamil may result in relieving the subjective sensation of palpitations in patients with atrial fibrillation.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female patient presented with a gradually increasing midline neck swelling over the past 2 months. Upon physical examination, a 3 cm × 2 cm × 2 cm swelling was observed on the right side of her neck, extending from the midline to the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The swelling was firm and mobile to touch. Additionally, the patient had enlarged lymph nodes in the right levels II and III, measuring 1 cm × 1 cm. A serum calcitonin test revealed levels 100 times higher than the normal range. A neck ultrasound (USG) showed the presence of two hypoechoic lesions in the right lobe of the thyroid, along with macrocalcifications.

Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis is incorrect?

choices.text: Both hematogenous and lymphatic spread is seen

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It is dependent on TSH:

  • The diagnosis is medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). MTC is TSH independent, so it does not take radioactive iodine (hence, radioactive iodine ablation is not effective for MTC)
  • Thyroid gland parafollicular 'C' cells are the source of medullary cancer. It is a calcitonin-secreting structure that originates from the ultimobranchial bodies and is situated at the superolateral region of the thyroid lobes. As a result, while calcium levels are normal, calcitonin levels are elevated in medullary thyroid cancer.
  • Most cases are sporadic; however, occasionally, it is part of the MEN 2A and MEN 2B syndrome, whereby the patients have a positive family history.

Sporadic

Familial
  • 80% of cases
  • 20% of cases
 
  • Associated with MEN/ Non-MEN
  • If associated with MEN, it is MEN 2A/2B
  • Seen in 6th decade
  • Young patients
  • Single
  • Multiple
  • Unilateral
  • Bilateral

→ The similarity between sporadic and familial MTC - Both have RET Proto-oncogene mutation

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It arises from Parafollicular ‘C’ cells:

  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma arises from the parafollicular 'C' cells of the thyroid gland.

Option B - Both hematogenous and lymphatic spread is seen:

  • It spreads by local invasion, hematogenous and lymphatic routes causing disease propagation; distant metastasis is most frequently seen in the liver, bone, and lungs.

Option D - Most cases are sporadic:

  • Medullary thyroid cancers are mostly sporadic, as up to 80% of cases are sporadic and just 20% of cases are familial in origin. The sporadic cases arise in the sixth decade and most present as unilateral masses.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient with recent-onset fatigue, dizziness, dark-colored urine, and splenomegaly is found to have anemia, elevated MCV, reticulocytosis, and a positive DAT for IgG and C3d antibodies that activate at warm temperatures. What disease is most likely associated with these antibodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE):

  • This is the case of warm agglutinin hemolytic anemia (WAHA) in a patient presenting with complaints of fatigue, dizziness, palpitations, and mild dyspnea, along with dark-colored urine, during warm weather.
  • The medical history of tuberculosis is important because one of the drugs used for its treatment, rifampin, is indicated for autoimmune hemolytic anemia, especially in warm temperatures.
  • Examination findings of pallor, jaundice, and splenomegaly, along with the presenting complaints, suggest an ongoing hemolytic crisis.
  • Investigation findings of anemia, increased MCV, reticulocytosis, and increased indirect bilirubin levels show the picture of increased RBC destruction.
  • Positive DAT and abundant spherocytes on PBS confirm the diagnosis.
  • WAHA usually results from the binding of erythrocytes to the heat-sensitive autoantibodies, which are mostly IgG antibodies which leads to increased extravascular hemolysis by the reticuloendothelial system. This is usually triggered by a body temperature of >37°C.
  • The formation of autoantibodies is mostly idiopathic; however, it may be caused by secondary causes in some cases like CLL, SLE, and certain drugs like rifampin and penicillin.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection:

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae usually causes the release of IgM autoantibodies that bind to red cells avidly at low temperatures.
  • DAT is usually negative for IgG, and PBS shows mild spherocytosis.

Option B- Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia:

  • It is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that is associated with abnormal production of IgM antibodies which can bind to RBCs at low temperatures resulting in RBC fragmentation.
  • It is usually associated with cold agglutinin haemolytic anaemia with negative DAT for IgG.

Option D- EBV infection:

  • EBV infection is usually seen as an etiological factor in cold-sensitive autoantibody-mediated haemolytic anaemia.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed negative/weakly positive DAT for IgG and cold agglutinin titer >64 at 4°C.

questions.text: In the pediatric neurology outpatient clinic, a 3-year-old girl is accompanied by her parents due to her presenting symptoms of severe headache and fever. The child has a medical history of hydrocephalus and underwent a ventricular-peritoneal shunt revision just one month ago. The attending neurologist suspects the possibility of an infection involving the shunt tubing. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be isolated in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Staphylococcus epidermidis:

  • Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most likely organism to be isolated from shunt tubing.
  • CONS (Coagulase-negative Staphylococcus) which is a less pathogenic and normal flora of the skin.
  • It is associated with post-intervention infections such as IV cannula, CSF shunts, prosthetic valve surgery, and catheters.
  • Causes early prosthetic valve endocarditis [<1yr].
  • Produces biofilms that adhere to the surface of shunts with the help of these biofilms.
  • Novobiocin sensitive.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bacteroides fragilis:

  • Bacteroides fragilis is the normal commensal of the human colon.
  • It is involved in peritoneal infections and is a common cause of intra-abdominal infections.

Option B - Corynebacterium diphtheria:

  • Corynebacterium diphtheria causes diphtheria, in which mucous membranes are affected and leading to difficulty in breathing, arrhythmia, and can cause death.

Option C - Escherichia coli:

  • Escherichia coli is commonly known to cause diarrhoea and cramps and it is the most common cause of urinary tract infections.
  • Women are at increased risk of UTI caused by E. coli due to the shorter distance between the urethra and anus.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient with hypertension and paroxysmal episodes of palpitations and headaches is diagnosed with a phaeochromocytoma located in the left adrenal gland. Which of the following symptoms experienced by the patient can complicate surgical intervention due to the presence of phaeochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hypertension:

  • Patients with pheochromocytoma often experience severe hypertension due to excessive catecholamine secretion. During surgical intervention, controlling blood pressure is critical to prevent hypertensive crises, which can lead to complications such as stroke or myocardial infarction. Precise management of hypertension before and during surgery is essential to ensure a safe and successful procedure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hypotension: Hypotension is not a common symptom of pheochromocytoma. Patients typically present with severe hypertension due to the excessive release of catecholamines.

Option B - Hypoglycemia: Hypoglycemia is not a characteristic symptom of pheochromocytoma. Symptoms are primarily related to excess catecholamine production, leading to hypertension, palpitations, and headaches.

Option C - Tachycardia: Tachycardia is often observed in patients with pheochromocytoma due to increased sympathetic activity. While it is a symptom, controlling blood pressure is of greater concern during surgery due to the risk of hypertensive crises.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has been admitted to the hospital due to a febrile coma that has lasted for the past 2 hours. Prior to admission, he had been experiencing headaches, fever, and chills for several days. Additionally, he exhibited behavioral disturbances and seizures. During the clinical examination, bilateral miosis and a stiff neck were observed. A (CSF) analysis was performed, revealing purulent CSF with pleocytosis (9200 cells/mm3, primarily neutrophils), elevated CSF protein (3.50 g/L), hypoglycorrhachia (1.16 mmol/L; CSF/serum glucose ratio: 0.14). Which infectious agent is responsible for this condition, considering the patient's age and the clinical and laboratory findings described?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Streptococcus pneumoniae:

  • The bacteria streptococcus pneumoniae is what causes pneumococcal meningitis (also called pneumococcus or S pneumoniae).
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in adults.
  • If a child is older than two, it is the second most typical reason for meningitis.
  • Listeria is an important cause of meningitis in the neonatal period but not in older children.
  • MCC of acute bacterial meningitis in children is streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitides, and H. influenza

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Escherichia coli:

  • Meningitis risk is increased in premature and low birth weight infants.
  • When E. coli and related bacteria infect a newborn or within the first two days after birth, septicaemia (blood poisoning) is more likely to occur.
  • Meningitis is more likely to develop in infants older than 48 hours when it does.

Option C - Klebsiella pneumonia:

  • Both early-onset infections and those with a late onset seem to be dominated by Klebsiella pneumoniae.
  • Equal amounts of each sex died, with a 48% fatality rate.
  • According to the report, Serratia sp. and Klebsiella pneumoniae are the main bacteria that cause newborn Meningitis in our environment

Option D - L. Monocytogenes:

  • A food-borne virus called listeria monocytogenes (Lm) has a significant risk of infecting young children, pregnant women, the elderly, and people with impaired immune systems.
  • Neonatal Lm infection can result in neonatal Meningitis, sepsis, severe neurological and developmental consequences, and high mortality rates.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient came to the OPD with complaints of fever, sore throat, enlarged lymph nodes, tonsillar swelling, and night sweats. During abdominal examination, a significantly enlarged spleen is noted. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and liver transaminases. A peripheral blood smear displayed lymphocytosis. Further diagnostic testing confirmed the presence of the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) as the causative organism. which of the following conditions should be excluded as not typically associated with EBV?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Epidermodysplasia:

  • All are associated with EBV except epidermodysplasia.
  • EBV causes Burkitt's lymphoma (a tumour of the jaw seen in children and young adults).
  • EBV is associated with 90% of African and 20% of non-African cases of Burkitt’s lymphoma.
  • Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma: It is seen among Chinese having a history of intake of salted fish.
  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma (especially the mixed-cellularity type), B cells lymphoma, NHL (Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma): Almost all central nervous system non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas and 50% of systemic non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas are EBV positive. Epidermodysplasia verruciformis /Tree man syndrome: It is caused by HPV 5, 8.
  • It is a rare, heritable>EBV spreads through saliva and body secretions.
  • Clinically patient presented with high-grade fever malaise and other symptoms of acute pharyngitis.
  • In later stages patient also shows up with lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Infectious mononucleosis:

  • EBV causes infectious mononucleosis in which the patient presents with fever, chills, body aches and later signs of acute pharyngitis and lymphadenopathy.

Option B - Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is caused by EBV, in which the patient presents with painless lymphadenopathy.
  • There is unilateral nasal discharge with nasal bleeding on and off.

Option C - Hodgkin's lymphoma:

  • EBV causes infectious mononucleosis in which the patient presents with fever, chills, body aches and later signs of acute pharyngitis and lymphadenopathy.
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is caused by EBV, in which the patient presents with painless lymphadenopathy.
  • There is unilateral nasal discharge with nasal bleeding on and off.
  • It is also caused by EBV, especially mixed cellularity type.

questions.text: A patient who is a chronic alcoholic present to the hospital after experiencing intractable vomiting for the past two days, along with diarrhea. Due to reduced food intake and changes in consciousness, the medical team aggressively corrects fluid loss and electrolyte imbalances through fluid infusion. However, following the treatment, the patient develops quadriplegia and mutism. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Osmotic demyelination syndrome:

  • Chronic hyponatremia management is significantly complicated by the asymmetry of the cellular response to the correction of plasma Na+ concentration.
  • Specifically, brain cells' reaccumulation of organic osmolytes is attenuated and delayed as osmolality increases after correcting hyponatremia, sometimes resulting in degenerative loss of oligodendrocytes and an osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS).
  • Overly rapid correction of hyponatremia (>8–10 mM in 24 h or 18 mM in 48 h) is also associated with a disruption in the integrity of the blood-brain barrier, allowing the entry of immune mediators that may contribute to demyelination.
  • The lesions of ODS classically affect the pons.
  • Patients with central pontine myelinolysis can present 1 or more days after overcorrection of hyponatremia with paraparesis or quadriparesis, dysphagia, dysarthria, diplopia, a "locked-in syndrome," and/or loss of consciousness.
  • Other regions of the brain can also be involved in ODS, most commonly in association with lesions of the pons but occasionally in isolation; in order of frequency, the lesions of extrapontine myelinolysis can occur in the cerebellum, lateral geniculate body, thalamus, putamen, and cerebral cortex or subcortex.
  • Therefore, the clinical presentation of ODS can vary as a function of the extent and localization of extrapontine myelinolysis, with the reported development of ataxia, mutism, parkinsonism, dystonia, and catatonia.
  • Relowering of plasma Na+ concentration after overly rapid correction can prevent or attenuate ODS.
  • However, even appropriately slow correction can be associated with ODS, particularly in patients with additional risk factors; these include alcoholism, malnutrition, hypokalemia, and liver transplantation.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Syndrome of inappropriate ADH production:

  • SIADH is caused by various drugs, such as SSRIs and disorders of the pulmonary system and CNS.
  • It causes euvolemic hyponatremia.
  • However, it is not associated with mutism or quadriparesis.

Option C - Brainstem infarct:

  • Brainstem infarcts may present with quadriplegia.
  • Coma can occur.
  • However, the risk factors are hypertension, diabetes and chronic atherosclerotic diseases.

Option D - Meningitis:

  • Meningitis presents with headache, fever and signs of meningeal irritation.
  • Meningitis complicated by brain abscess can cause a focal neurologic deficit.

questions.text: A 34-year-old primigravida woman presented at 32 weeks of gestation and is experiencing seizures. LSCS is planned for her, and she has been initiated on magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) therapy. Which one is NOT a contraindication for the use of MgSO4 therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Imminent eclampsia:

  • This patient presenting with seizures at 32 weeks of gestation suffers from eclampsia.
  • Both imminent and presenting eclampsia are indications of giving MgSO4 therapy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Renal Failure:

  • It decreases MgSO4 clearance from the body, increasing the risk of its toxicity.
  • It is, therefore, a contraindication to MgSO4 therapy.

Option B - Hypocalcemia:

  • It is also a contraindication to MgSO4 therapy as it increases the risk of respiratory paralysis.

Option C - Myasthenia gravis:

  • There is an increased risk of respiratory paralysis in a patient with myasthenia gravis due to MgSO4 therapy.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient visits your clinic, reporting symptoms of a runny nose and throat pain. He had recently been diagnosed with Tuberculosis and had commenced antitubercular therapy. His current symptoms emerged shortly after initiating treatment. Which of the following antitubercular medications is likely responsible for the patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C  - Rifampicin:

  • Rifampicin is a derivative of rifamycin (other derivatives are rifabutin and rifapentine).
  • It is bactericidal and acts against dividing and non-dividing mycobacterium by inhibiting DNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
  • Its metabolites are coloured and can cause orange discolouration of the urine and secretions.
  • It can also cause orange staining of contact lenses.
  • It is eliminated mainly in the faeces and can be used safely in renal dysfunction.
  • Food interferes with its absorption.
  • It penetrates all membranes, including the blood-brain and the placental barrier.
  • It is equally effective against intra- and extra-cellular bacilli.
  • It is the only bactericidal drug active against dormant bacteria in solid caseous lesions.
  • It is the most effective and fastest-acting drug for leprosy.
  • It can cause light chain proteinuria and may impair antibody responses.
  • It is also hepatotoxic and may cause skin rash, flu-like syndrome (more prominent with intermittent regimen) and anaemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Para amino salicylic acid (PAS):

  • PAS is a second-line antitubercular drug.
  • It is a prodrug and acts by getting incorporated into the folate pathway and therefore inhibits dihydrofolate reductase enzymatic activity.
  • Side effects of PAS include:
    • Kidney and liver dysfunction
    • Thyroid dysfunction.

Option B - Pyrazinamide:

  • Pyrazinamide is a first-line antitubercular drug used for the treatment of TB.
  • It is a prodrug that blocks the synthesis of coenzyme A.
  • Pyrazinamide acts against slowly dividing bacteria inside macrophages.
  • Side effects of pyrazinamide include:
    • Hepatotoxicity.
    • Hyperuricemia

Option D - Streptomycin:

  1. Streptomycin is a first-line drug used for the treatment of TB
  2. Streptomycin irreversibly binds to the small 16S rRNA of the 30S ribosomal subunit.
  3. This interferes with the binding of formyl-methionyl-tRNA to the 30S ribosomal subunit.
  4. Adverse effects of streptomycin include:
    • Tinnitus
    • Vertigo
    • Ataxia
    • Nephrotoxicity

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presented with a painful and erythematous nodular skin lesion on her chin for the past 3 months associated with cervical and submandibular lymphadenopathy on the same side. The patient's medical history includes focal onset seizures for which she is currently receiving treatment with an anti-epileptic drug. Upon evaluation, the physician recommended a biopsy of the chin lesion, and the results confirmed the presence of a pseudolymphoma. Which of the following drugs, when chronically used, is most likely responsible for causing this lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Phenytoin:

  • Pseudolymphomata are skin lesions that range in size from nodules to papules and are brought on by persistent antigenic stimulation. Insect bites and medication reactions are the two most prevalent antigenic triggers.
  • Drugs, including anticonvulsants, antidepressants, and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, are among the factors that cause pseudolymphoma. Existing research indicates that T cells typically predominate in phenytoin-induced cutaneous pseudolymphomas.
  • Benign lymphoid hyperplasia, pseudolymphoma, pseudo-pseudolymphoma, and malignant lymphoma are cutaneous lymphoproliferative disorders brought on by phenytoin. Drug-induced pseudolymphoma presents with predominate or exclusive skin involvement without any constitutional symptoms or systemic involvement.
  • Typically, pseudolymphomata develop on the head and trunk. Each lesion is distinct and has a raised, hairy surface. Symptoms include fever, lymphadenopathy and generalised rash.
  • The histology feature that distinguishes pseudolymphoma from other benign cutaneous inflammatory cell infiltrates is cited as the presence of medium- to large-sized lymphocytes, some of which may appear atypical, with many ordinary small lymphocytes. True lymphomas and pseudolymphomas can both exhibit atypical cells and mitotic figures.
  • Resolution of the lesions takes longer than other drug reactions, with some cases continuing for 6 months or more following discontinuation of the offending substance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Levetiracetam:

  • Levetiracetam causes weight gain, double vision, double dipping, GI distress or nausea, agitation, disorientation, anxiety, and imbalance.
  • Independent of a clinical history of a psychiatric illness, adverse behavioural reactions such as anger, violence, and suicidal thoughts and behaviours are also observed.

Option B - Phenobarbital:

  • Coma, decreased struggle to breathe, and low blood pressure is all side effects of phenobarbital use. The more frequent negative effects include sleepiness, decreased balance, and lack of coordination.
  • Long-term use is associated with undesirable side effects, including irritation, lack of appetite, muscle pain, joints or bones, depression, and liver damage. However, liver damage is very uncommon.

Option D - Primidone:

  • Primidone, a deoxybarbiturate, is partially converted to phenobarbital, accounting for most of its pharmacological actions.
  • Primidone may initially result in a brief intolerance reaction that includes fatigue, wooziness, nausea, vomiting, headache, and other symptoms.
  • Primidone can result in several uncommon side effects, including oedema, lymphadenopathy, toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), thyroid hypertrophy, and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This condition resembles diabetes insipidus (DI).

questions.text: What is the indication for performing a high tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Laryngeal carcinoma:

  • High tracheostomy is done above the level of the thyroid isthmus. The only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx. In such cases, the entire larynx would ultimately be removed, and a fresh tracheostomy made in a clean area lower down.

High Tracheostomy

  • A high tracheostomy is the one that is at the level of the first tracheal ring.
  • In high tracheostomy, the cricothyroid membrane is pierced.

Indications and contraindications

  • It is done only in emergencies, e.g., airway obstruction that is life-threatening.
  • It is contraindicated in obese individuals.
  • In this case, the entire larynx would ultimately be removed, and a fresh tracheostomy made in a clean area lower down.

Complications

  • One of the complications of high tracheostomy is laryngeal obstruction.
  • As high tracheostomy is nearer to the larynx, laryngeal edema may develop due to injury leading to an obstruction that can be life-threatening.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Vocal cord palsy:

  • Treatment of vocal cord paralysis depends on the cause, the severity of symptoms, and the time from the onset of symptoms.
  • High tracheostomy is not generally done for vocal paralysis

Note: Vocal cord paralysis can be caused by recurrent laryngeal nerve injury. If both nerves are involved, vocal cords may obstruct the airway.

Option C - Subglottic stenosis:

  • Subglottic stenosis is airway narrowing below the vocal folds.
  • Treatment for subglottis stenosis is mostly conservative.
  • A high tracheostomy is not done for sub glottis stenosis.

Option D - Laryngomalacia:

  • Laryngoscopy is done to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Treatment: Conservative treatment
  • Disappears on its own by 2 years of age
  • Surgery: SUPRAGLOTTOPLASTY

questions.text: "An elderly man presents with lower limb weakness, urinary and fecal retention, and altered sensations below L1 dermatome. Neurological examination reveals increased tone, exaggerated reflexes, and a positive Babinski reflex. MRI shows a mass effect in the right fronto-parieto-occipital region, indicating uncus compression. What neurological deficits can be expected due to this compression?"
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cheyne -stokes respiration:

  • Clinical signs in the fronto-parieto-occipital region and capsulated extra-axial chronic hemorrhages suggest brain herniation, which could be anywhere in the brain depending on the sign and symptoms.
  • Uncal/Transtentorial Herniation:
    • Uncus and Temporal lobes are forced through the cerebellar tentorium.
    • Sequential compression of ipsilateral 3rd nerve followed by the brainstem.
    • Early signs - Ipsilateral dilated pupil
    • Late Signs:
      • Ipsilateral Hemiplegia
      • Progressive Ptosis
      • 3rd Nerve Palsy
      • Cheyne-Stoke Respiration
    • Very Late Sign
      • Quadriparesis
      • Bilateral Dilated and fixed pupil
      • Erratic Respiration and Death

Kernohan's notch phenomenon:

  • It is cerebral peduncle indentation associated with transtentorial or uncal herniation.
  • Compression of the contralateral cerebral peduncle against the free edge of the tentorium.
  • Kernohans's notch causes ipsilateral hemiparesis and ipsilateral 3rd nerve Palsy.
  • Kernohan's woltman sign
    • Lateral displacement of the midbrain compresses the opposite cerebral peduncle, causes Babinski sign, and hemiparesis contralateral to original hemiparesis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bilaterally dilated pupils: In the uncal compression, there is ipsilateral dilation of pupils, not bilateral, as it's the compression of one side, not both.

Option B - Bilateral hemiplegia: Just as with pupillary dilatation, the same is true with hemiplegia. It's also ipsilateral, not bilateral.

Option D - Decorticate rigidity: Decorticate posture is an aberrant posture that features rigid, bent arms, clenched fists, and straight legs. These are not found in uncal compression.

The arms are tucked close to the torso, with the fingers and wrists bent and resting on the chest. This kind of posture indicates a significant brain injury.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient complains of wrist swelling that has been present for several weeks. Based on the X-ray findings, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's wrist condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Giant cell tumor:

The above patient with a soap bubble appearance on the X-ray most likely has a giant cell tumor.

  • A benign but locally aggressive tumor composed of giant cells that arise from the bone marrow
  • Peak incidence between 20 and 40 years
  • Clinical features
  • Found in the epiphysis or metaphysis of long bones (especially the knee region). Pathological fractures
  • Local pain and swelling
  • Limited range of motion
  • It is the only tumor to involve the joint.
  • Diagnostics :
  • X-ray: multicystic osteolytic lesions (soap-bubble appearance)
  • Histopathology :
  • Mononuclear, RANKL-expressing cells (neoplastic)
  • Multinucleated giant cells (are reactive and resemble osteoclasts)
  • Treatment: curettage and bone grafting or en-bloc resection to minimize recurrence rate
  • Prognosis: risk of malignant degeneration increases with age; it may spread to the lungs

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Ewing's sarcoma:

  • Ewing’s sarcoma usually occurs in the diaphysis of the bone (middle of the shaft).
  • Origin: Marrow cells (marrow biopsy useful to see the extent of the disease)
  • Localizes in the diaphysis

Option C- Osteosarcoma:

  • Osteosarcoma aggressive presentation and found in the metaphysis.
  • <1% Paget's, also known as Osteitis deformans, will have Osteosarcoma
  • Feature: Pain / Night pain

Option D- Aneurysmal Bone cyst:

  • It occurs in the metaphysis and is seen in skeletally immature individuals (11-20 years).

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of uncontrolled diabetes presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of difficulty in breathing and persistent cough for several days. On examination, he has a black lesion on the upper bridge of the nose. His chest x-ray showed irregular solitary nodules. The physician recommended a tissue biopsy with H&E staining to ascertain the cause. The results of which showed Aseptate hyphae. Which of the following is the characteristic of the biopsy finding?
questions.solution:
Option B: Absidia

  • Aseptate hyphae characterize Absidia and Apophysomyces.
  • Absidia is a genus of zygote fungi in the family Cunninghamellaceae. Absidia species are ubiquitous in most environments, where they are often associated with warm decaying plant matter, such as compost heaps.
  • Absidia genus belonging to the Mucorales group of the Zygomycetes class is a ubiquitous saprophyte in the ground which may cause Zygomycosis.
  • Mucormycosis (Zygomycosis) is a fungal infection caused by Zygomycetes. Symptoms include fever, headache, coughing, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, bloody vomit, and possible altered mental status.

  • Hyphae may be septate or aseptate (coenocytic).
  • Aseptate hyphae are seen in:
    • Rhizopus (Image below)

    • Mucor (Image below)

    • Rhizomucor
    • Absidia
    • Basidiobolus
    • Conidiobolus
    • Saksanea
    • Cunninghamella
    • Apophysomyces
  • The image below: Broad aseptate hyphae of Mucormycosis

Option A: Aspergillus

  • It has septate hyphae.
  • Aspergillus: acute angle branching with septate hyphae (Image below)

Option C: Scedosporium

  • It has septate hyphae.
  • Superficial soft tissue infections after trauma.
  • Fungal keratitis (Image below).

Option D: Acremonium

  • It has septate hyphae.

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient arrives at the emergency department with a chief complaint of experiencing shortness of breath and palpitations over the past two hours. The patient is visibly distressed and is sweating profusely. Upon examination, the patient's heart rate is measured at 180 beats per minute, and their systolic blood pressure is only 70 mmHg. Cardiac auscultation reveals no significant abnormalities. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is conducted and indicates narrow QRS complexes. What is the next best step in managing this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Synchronised cardioversion:

  • This is the case of Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), a group of arrhythmias presenting with a sudden, abrupt onset and sudden termination. It includes atrioventricular re-entrant tachyarrhythmia (AVRT), AV nodal re-entrant tachyarrhythmia (AVNRT), ectopic junctional tachycardia (JET), and unifocal/multifocal atrial tachycardia.
  • Most PSVTs result in tachycardia with a narrow QRS complex and regular rhythm. The clinical features include dizziness, dyspnea, chest pain, and syncope.
  • A 12-lead ECG should be performed in every patient with suspected PSVT.
  • The management aims to initiate continuous cardiac monitoring and ECG recording for all patients.
  • A defibrillator should be kept at the bedside in case rhythm and hemodynamics change.
  • In case of pulseless patients: Start CPR. Defibrillate any wide-complex tachycardia
  • Patients with unstable tachycardia with a pulse: perform synchronised electrical cardioversion for most SVTs.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IV diltiazem: IV diltiazem is an acceptable treatment option for hemodynamically stable patients suffering from PSVT. However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable. Hence instead of diltiazem, synchronised cardioversion should be used.

Option B - IV adenosine: IV adenosine is the drug of choice for the termination of PSVT. However, it is an ineffective treatment in cases where the patient is hemodynamically unstable, like the case in this clinical vignette.

Option D - IV fluids: IV fluids are widely used to manage hemodynamically unstable patients suffering from hypovolemia. This patient's hemodynamic instability is because of arrhythmia, not hypovolemia, and the patient needs urgent treatment to reverse arrhythmia.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male patient presents with chief complaints of watery, non-bloody diarrhea and generalized abdominal pain, which has been progressively worsening over the past 2 days. The patient has no known co-morbidities but was recently admitted for pneumonia, for which he received intravenous antibiotics. On physical examination, the patient exhibits dry mucous membranes, sunken eyes, and abdominal tenderness.

His vital signs are as follows: BP- 110/70 mmHg, HR- 88bpm, Temp101°F and RR18bpm.

The findings of endoscopy are given below. Which organism is most likely responsible for causing this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Clostridium difficile:

  • The patient in question has antibiotic-associated pseudomembranous colitis- yellowish plaque-like lesions in the colon caused by colonization with Clostridium difficile after his hospital stay.
  • C. difficile is a spore-forming gram-positive obligate anaerobe that is normally present in the colon of up to 3% of the general population but doesn’t cause disease due to competition with normal flora. After prolonged antibiotic use, the normal flora is diminished, which enables C. difficile to flourish and cause symptoms, e.g. fever, diarrhoea and abdominal pain.
  • Risk factors include antibiotic use (usually taken in the last 2 months), cancer, chemotherapy, and enteral feeding.
  • Investigations include testing for exotoxins in stool via ELISA, PCR for genes coding for the exotoxins, and colonoscopy.
  • Treatment includes oral metronidazole or vancomycin faecal transplant from the healthy donor via NG or enema.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Staphylococcus Aureus:

  • S. aureus is a non spore forming a gram positive cocci.
  • It causes food poisoning via an enterotoxin that is performed in improperly stored foods, hence has a short incubation period (1-8hrs)
  • Vomiting is typically more prominent than diarrhoea in gastroenteritis caused by S. aureus.
  • Other diseases caused by S. aureus include skin and soft tissue infections, septicemia, toxic shock syndrome and endocarditis.

Option C - Clostridium perferingens:

  • C. perferingens is a spore-forming gram-positive rod that causes gas gangrene and food poisoning
  • Diagnosis: C. perferingens is cultured anaerobically and identified by sugar fermentation reactions
  • Food poisoning: Heat-resistant spores can contaminate food and cause diarrhoea via enterotoxins; the incubation period is 8-16hrs. It causes watery diarrhoea with cramps that resolve in 24hrs usually without treatment.

Option D - Pseudomonas:

  • Gram-negative rods, strict aerobes
  • P. aeruginosa usually causes infections in immune-compromised hosts. It is the most common cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia.
  • Other diseases caused by pseudomonas include UTIs, cellulitis in burn patients, malignant otitis externa in diabetics, and chronic respiratory tract infections in patients with cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: What is the optimal treatment plan for managing the complex condition of a 39-year-old male with advanced liver cirrhosis due to chronic alcohol abuse, complicated by alcohol-induced encephalopathy, delirium tremens, portal hypertension, arrhythmia, abdominal ascites, pedal edema, clammy skin, and esophageal varices, categorized as Child-Turcotte-Pugh class C?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Liver transplantation:

  • This patient has cirrhosis; the complication is portal hypertension manifested in variceal bleeding with ascites.
  • The child's class 'C' score means no surgical intervention should be done → Best treatment is liver transplantation.
  • Patients with variceal bleeding who are transplantation candidates include
    • Alcoholic cirrhotic patients with limited hepatic functional reserve (Child-Pugh class B and C).
    • There is poor quality of life secondary to the disease (encephalopathy, fatigue, bone pain ), and intervention should be done.
  • Child-Pugh classification:

Clinical and lab criteria

Point 1

Point 2

Point 3

Encephalopathy

None

Grade 1 or 2

Grade 3 or 4

Ascites

None

Mild to moderate (diuretic responsive)

Severe (diuretic refractory)

Bilirubin (mg/dL)

<2

2-3

>3

Albumin (g/dL)

>3.5

2.8 - 3.5

<2.8

Prothrombin time

      

Seconds prolonged

<4

4 - 6

>6

International normalized ratio

<1.7

1.7 - 2.3

>2.3

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Medical management and supportive care: While medical management is essential for symptom relief and supportive care, it does not address the underlying liver failure in advanced cases. Medical management may include diuretics for ascites, medications for encephalopathy, and lifestyle modifications, but it does not provide a curative solution.

Option C - Palliative care: While palliative care focuses on symptom management and improving the patient's quality of life, it does not address the possibility of curative treatment. In a relatively young patient, especially one without significant comorbidities, pursuing curative options such as transplantation is more appropriate.

Option D - TIPS:

  • TIPS is a transjugular intrahepatic portal-systemic shunt.
  • This procedure is used to relieve portal hypertension.
  • Hepatic encephalopathy is a notorious complication of TIPS.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female with a history of asthma presents to the emergency room with increasing shortness of breath, wheezing, and chest tightness for the past 12 hours. She is using her albuterol inhaler frequently but is finding little relief. On examination, she appears anxious, with increased respiratory effort and bilateral wheezing on auscultation.An arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is performed with the following results:


	
		
			pH
			7.29
		
		
			Partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2)
			55 mmHg
		
		
			Partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2)
			50 mmHg
		
		
			Bicarbonate (HCO3)
			26 mEq/L
		
	


Which of the following statements BEST describes the patient's ABG findings, and what is the MOST likely diagnosis?

choices.text: The ABG indicates respiratory alkalosis, and the patient likely has a pulmonary embolism.
The ABG indicates respiratory acidosis, and the patient likely has a severe asthma exacerbation.
The ABG indicates metabolic acidosis, and the patient likely has diabetic ketoacidosis.
The ABG indicates metabolic alkalosis, and the patient likely has hyperventilation syndrome.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - The ABG indicates respiratory acidosis, and the patient likely has a severe asthma exacerbation:

  • In the provided ABG results, the pH is lower than the normal range (7.29), indicating acidosis. Additionally, the PaCO2 is elevated at 50 mmHg, which is above the normal range (35-45 mmHg), indicating respiratory acidosis. These findings are consistent with impaired gas exchange in the lungs, which can occur in severe asthma exacerbations due to airway obstruction, increased airway resistance, and inadequate ventilation.
