questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, visits her dermatologist with complaints of nail abnormalities. She has a known history of psoriasis, which primarily affects her skin, particularly the elbows and knees. Which of the following nail changes is most likely associated with psoriasis in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Onycholysis and subungual hyperkeratosis:

  • In this clinical scenario, Sarah has a known history of psoriasis affecting her skin. Psoriasis can also affect the nails, resulting in various nail changes. Onycholysis is the separation of the nail plate from the nail bed, leading to a white discoloration under the nail. Subungual hyperkeratosis is the buildup of thickened keratin debris under the nail plate. Both onycholysis and subungual hyperkeratosis are common nail changes seen in psoriasis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Beau's lines and pitting: Beau's lines are horizontal depressions across the nails caused by temporary disruption of nail growth. Pitting refers to the presence of small depressions or "pits" on the nail surface. While these nail changes can be seen in some conditions, they are not typically associated with psoriasis.

Option C - Splinter hemorrhages and Terry's nails: Splinter hemorrhages are small areas of bleeding under the nails that look like reddish-brown lines. Terry's nails refer to nails that appear white with a narrow band of reddish or brown color at the tip. These nail changes are not characteristic of psoriasis.

Option D - Leukonychia and clubbing: Leukonychia is the presence of white spots or streaks on the nails, while clubbing is the enlargement of the fingertips and nails. These nail changes are not specifically associated with psoriasis.

questions.text: A community medicine student was asked to draw some study designs. Identify the study design given in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Nested case-control study:

  • The given image depicts a Nested case-control study.
  • Nested case-control study:
  • Type of cohort Study
  • Temporality → forward-looking study
  • Only done in
    • New & Rare diseases
    • If Diagnostic tests are very Expensive.
  • It is a small case-control study that is nested in a big cohort study.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cross-sectional study:

  • Cross-sectional study:
    • Aka Snapshot study/ Prevalence study (as prevalence is calculated).
    • Done at point of time (neither forward, nor backward).
    • Based on primary data.
    • Can't calculate the strength of association.

Option B - Retrospective cohort study:

  • Retrospective Cohort Study
    • The combination of a prospective cohort study and case-control study is known as a retrospective cohort study.
    • This study gives Incidence, RR, AR, PAR, and this study also saves time.

Option C - Case-control, study:

  • Case-control study is better for rare diseases.
  • Case-control study has 2 groups
    1. Cases: Having the disease
    2. Controls: They are comparison groups not having the disease
  • We ask about the history of the same exposure in both groups & then compare both groups.

questions.text: In the emergency department, a 35-year-old male patient, previously diagnosed with tuberculosis, presents with complaints of headaches and recurrent episodes of seizures. The patient has been undergoing treatment with antituberculosis drugs (ATT) for the past 2 months. After a comprehensive evaluation of the patient's medical history and condition, the physician decides to initiate treatment with an antiepileptic drug (AED). The patient's current medication regimen consists of antibiotics, ATT, and AED. Among the medications in the patient's regimen, which one is metabolized via a liver pathway distinct from the acetylation process?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Phenytoin:

  • One of the most often administered antiepileptic medications is phenytoin (AEDs). Due to its limited therapeutic window and significant interindividual variation in clearance, therapeutic medication monitoring is frequently required.
  • Cytochrome P450 (P450) enzymes break down phenytoin principally to 5-(p-hydroxyphenyl-) and 5-phenylhydantoin (HPPH), which can then be further broken down to a catechol that spontaneously oxidises to semiquinone and quinone species that covalently alter proteins.
  • Phenytoin is converted to p-HPPH and subsequently glucuronidated and eliminated in the urine to a degree of up to 90%.
  • There is a significant interindividual difference in the relative amounts of the two stereoisomers of p-HPPH that are produced, (R)-p-HPPH and (S)-p-HPPH. The ratio of (R)-p-HPPH to (S)-p-HPPH when CYP2C19 catalyses the reaction is roughly 1: 1. However, the ratio favours the generation of the S isomer by as much as 40:1 when the reaction is catalysed by CYP2C9.
  • The formation of p-HPPH is assumed to occur via a reactive arene oxide intermediate, and the ‘arene oxide theory’ has been reported by most authors reporting cases of phenytoin hypersensitivity responses, SJS/TEN, hepatotoxicity, and other kinds of idiosyncratic toxicity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Isoniazid:

  • Despite the positive advantages of INH, INH therapies are linked to serious negative side effects, particularly peripheral neuropathy and hepatotoxicity.
  • The liver damage brought on by INH is assumed to be related to INH metabolism. Acetylation to create AcINH through N-acetyltransferase (NAT) and hydrolysis to create isonicotinic acid (INA) and Hz through amidase are the two main routes of INH metabolism.
  • The three main metabolites of INH are acetyl hydrazine (AcHz), hydrazine (Hz), and acetyl isoniazid (AcINH).

Option B - Hydralazine:

  • A direct arteriole vasodilator is hydralazine. Though the exact process is unknown, it is believed to be linked to intracellular calcium homeostasis.
  • The liver breaks down hydralazine. It experiences polymorphic acetylation. Lower medication dosages are necessary for slow acetylators. The medication is eliminated in the urine and faeces, acetylated and unmodified.

Option D - Sulfonamide:

  • Sulphonamides, sometimes known as sulfa medicines, are antibiotics that target bacteria that cause infections.
  • Sulphonamides are metabolised via oxidation and N-acetylation to potentially hazardous metabolites (mediated by a genetically polymorphic enzyme).

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with multiple small, dome-shaped papules on his abdomen. A biopsy of one of the lesions is performed and it’s histopathological finding is given in the image below. What is causative organism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A -Molluscum contagiosum:

  • The histopathological image shows the presence of Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are pathognomonic for molluscum contagiosum.
  • Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by the poxvirus. The characteristic histopathological feature of this condition is the presence of Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are large eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions within the infected epithelial cells.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Herpes simplex virus:

  • Herpes simplex virus causes herpetic skin lesions characterized by multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear viral inclusions known as Cowdry bodies.

Option C - Human papillomavirus (HPV):

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) infections are associated with the development of warts, which show hyperplastic epithelium, koilocytes, and papillomatosis.

Option D - Varicella-zoster virus:

  • Varicella-zoster virus causes varicella (chickenpox) and herpes zoster (shingles). Histopathological findings include multinucleated giant cells and intranuclear viral inclusions

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman arrives at the outpatient department, reporting symptoms of unilateral leg swelling, sharp chest pain, and shortness of breath that have been ongoing for the past day. She additionally mentions experiencing intermittent episodes of coughing, which exacerbate the chest pain. The patient has a history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. During the physical examination, the healthcare provider observes unilateral swelling of the patient's lower leg.

The physician has recommended a device to help prevent a specific disease. What disease is the device designed to prevent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - DVT:

  • In the above-given case, the clinical features of unilateral leg swelling, sharp chest pain, shortness of breath, and intermittent cough, which worsens the chest pain, suggest the diagnosis of deep venous thrombosis.
  • A pneumatic compression stocking is used to prevent DVT in patients with immobilization for a longer duration of time.
  • These are helpful in patients at moderate risk for DVT as a prophylactic measure, but these are not effective against established thrombosis.
  • It is used especially in the bariatric population and can be used in their room, operation room, or post-operative area.
  • DVT should be initially managed by heparin or low-molecular-weight heparin.
  • Long-term management is done by anti-coagulation with warfarin.
  • An inferior vena cava filter is indicated for patients not benefiting from medical treatment.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Varicose vein:

  • Most commonly, the varicose vein affects the lower extremities.
  • Varicose veins are caused by long-standing or walking.
  • Mainly, it is caused by weak vein walls and valves.

Option C - Hypothermia:

  • Hypothermia is caused when the body temperature falls to 95⁰ F.
  • Hypothermia causes body shivering, confusion, memory loss, slurred speech, and drowsiness.

Option D - Cellulitis:

  • Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection.
  • The most common bacteria causing cellulitis is Streptococcus.
  • It causes redness, swelling, and pain.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with an unusual patch of skin on his forearm. The area appears lighter and slightly paler compared to the surrounding skin. Upon examination, it is noted that rubbing or scratching the area causes the pale patch to become red and return to its normal color, while the surrounding skin does not show any significant color change. The boy's parents also mentioned that the patch has been present since birth and has not changed in size or shape. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for the observed skin change?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Nevus Anemicus:

  • Nevus Anemicus is a rare congenital skin condition characterized by a localized area of skin that appears lighter and paler than the surrounding skin. When the pale patch is rubbed or scratched, it becomes red due to the dilation of blood vessels, which is a unique feature of this condition. The surrounding skin does not show any significant color change during the process. Nevus Anemicus is typically present since birth and does not change in size or shape over time.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Vitiligo : Vitiligo is a skin disorder characterized by the loss of skin color in patches. It results in depigmented (white) areas on the skin, but rubbing or scratching does not cause a specific color change as seen in Nevus Anemicus.

Option C - Nevus Depigmentosus: Nevus Depigmentosus is a benign birthmark characterized by a localized area of depigmentation, which means the skin in that area lacks melanin and is lighter than the surrounding skin. It is a stable condition and does not show any significant color change upon rubbing or scratching.

Option D - Café-au-lait Spot: Café-au-lait spots are light-brown patches on the skin that may be present since birth or develop in early childhood. They are unrelated to Nevus Anemicus and do not show any characteristic color change upon rubbing or scratching.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male janitor working at a hospital suddenly experienced a gasping episode while cleaning a washroom, leading to his collapse. He was swiftly transported to the emergency department, where a medical officer promptly initiated CPR. In the context of providing effective tissue oxygenation during CPR, what percentage of chest compression fraction is deemed to be indicative of high-quality CPR?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - >80%:

  • High-quality CPR is the chief component in controlling survival from cardiac arrest.
  • Healthcare providers must be competent in providing high-quality CPR, and patient care teams must be coordinated in working together effectively to save more lives.
  • High-quality CPR performance metrics include:
    • Chest compression fraction greater than 80%.
    • Compression rate of 100-120 per minute.
    • Compression depth must be at least 50 mm (2 inches) in adults and no less than one-third of the anterior-posterior extent of the chest in infants and children. After compression, complete chest recoil should be allowed.
    • Minimize interruptions in compressions.
    • Rotate the compressor every 2 minutes.
    • No excessive ventilation.
    • If there is no advanced airway, a 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio.
    • Quantitative waveform capnography: if EtCO2 <10mmHg, attempt to improve CPR quality.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - >70%: The chest compression factor should be greater than >70%. However, the expert consensus is that a CCF of 80% is much more achievable.

Option C - >90%: A higher than 90% chest compression factor is not that achievable because the pauses between compressions must be at their minimum value and can also result in trauma.

Option D - None of the above: A chest compression factor greater than 80% is characteristic of high-quality CPR.

questions.text:
Which of the following is a Radiosensitive tumor?

A. Osteosarcoma

B. Ewing sarcoma

C. Osteoid osteoma

D. Simple bone cyst
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- B:

  • Ewing sarcoma is known to be a highly radiosensitive tumor.
  • Treatment of Ewing sarcoma includes:
    • Ewing's sarcoma is highly radiosensitive and melts when exposed to radiation, but it has chances of recurrence.
    • Combined therapy

Incorrect Options: 

Option B- D:

  • A Simple Bone cyst is treated with Curettage and bone graft.

Option C- A:

  • Osteosarcoma is a Radioresistant tumor and radiotherapy-induced tumor.

Option D- C:

  • Osteoid osteoma is the most common true benign tumor of the bone.
  • The patient presents with nocturnal pain which is treated with NSAIDs.
  • It is managed with CT-guided Radiofrequency ablation.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male was transported to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. Upon arrival, the patient was found to be unconscious, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8 out of 15. During the examination, a visible open wound was observed on the parietal area of the head, which was subsequently cleaned and sutured. Following the wound care, the patient underwent a brain CT scan. The results of the CT scan indicated the absence of midline shift but revealed the presence of multiple small hemorrhages within the brain.

What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Diffuse axonal injuries:

  • This is a case of diffuse axonal injury.
  • The patient sustained a head injury due to a road traffic accident. The CT brain of the patient shows multiple tiny hemorrhages in the brain.
  • These multiple tiny hemorrhages are called diffuse axonal injuries.
  • Diffuse axonal injury: -
    • Occurs due to shearing of white matter
    • This occurs mainly because of rotational acceleration
  • Shows multiple petechial hemorrhages, usually at the junction of white and grey matter
  • CT scan may be normal in some cases, so MRI is the investigation of choice.
  • A young patient with RTA→ NCCT- normal/ petechial hemorrhages→ Suspect diffuse axonal injury→ MRI (IOC for DAI).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cerebral contusion:

  • Cerebral contusion:

  • NCCT image showing hemorrhagic contusion in the bilateral basis-frontal lobe.

Option B - Cerebral laceration: A cerebral lesion is a tear in the brain tissue. On CT brain, it gives a salt and paper appearance.

Option C - Multiple cerebral infarcts: Multiple cerebral infarcts:

NCCT image showing multiple hypodense areas in the right frontal and left frontoparietal and occipital lobe s/o infarcts

questions.text: In radiology, which of the following imaging modalities uses X-rays to produce detailed cross-sectional images of the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Computed Tomography (CT) Scan:

  • CT scans use X-rays and advanced computer technology to create detailed cross-sectional images of the body. It is valuable for imaging bones, internal organs, and soft tissues, providing a more detailed view than traditional X-rays.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ultrasound: Ultrasound uses high-frequency sound waves to create images of the internal structures of the body. It is commonly used for imaging soft tissues and organs, particularly during pregnancy (ultrasound scans).

Option C - Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI): MRI uses a strong magnetic field and radio waves to generate detailed images of the body's internal structures. It is especially useful for imaging the brain, joints, soft tissues, and organs, offering excellent contrast resolution.

Option D - Positron Emission Tomography (PET) Scan: PET scans involve the use of a small amount of radioactive material (tracer) combined with a special camera to detect areas of abnormal metabolic activity in the body. It is often used in oncology and neurology to identify areas of cancer, brain disorders, and heart conditions.

questions.text:
Match the following toxins with their likely mode of action.


	
		
			A. Potassium carbonate
			1. Abortifacient
		
		
			B. Chloral hydrate
			2. Irritant
		
		
			C. Quinine
			3. Corrosive
		
		
			D. Zinc chloride
			4. Stupefying
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: 

 

Chemical Poison

Mechanism of Action

Zinc chloride

Irritant effect on the gastrointestinal tract

Chloral hydrate

Stupefying or sedative-hypnotic effect

Quinine

Abortifacient effect (induces abortion)

Potassium carbonate

Corrosive effect on tissues

questions.text: Under which doctrine is the doctor not responsible when a patient with life-threatening injuries arrives at the casualty without time for consent, and the doctor initiates life-saving procedures with utmost care, but unfortunately, the patient still succumbs to death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Doctrine of anticipation:

  • This doctrine allows a physician to take necessary action without explicit consent in emergency situations where there is a high risk of harm or death to the patient. It acknowledges that in life-threatening situations, obtaining formal consent may not be possible, and immediate intervention is required to preserve the patient's life. In this case, the doctor acted in accordance with the doctrine of anticipation by initiating life-saving procedures without consent.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Res ipsa loquitur: This doctrine holds that the occurrence of an accident implies negligence. However, in the given situation, the doctor was faced with a life-threatening emergency where immediate action was necessary to save the patient's life. The doctor acted responsibly and with all precautions, despite the unfortunate outcome. Therefore, the doctrine of Res ipsa loquitur would not hold the doctor responsible.

Option C - Doctrine of extended consent: This doctrine pertains to situations where additional procedures or interventions beyond the immediate emergency may be required, and consent must be obtained for those procedures. It is not directly applicable to the given scenario, as the doctor was focused on addressing the life-threatening injuries and preserving the patient's life.

Option D - Doctrine of conjugated consent: This is not a recognized legal doctrine in the context of medical practice. It is not applicable to the given scenario.

questions.text: A woman gives birth to twins, and the father has suspicions regarding his biological relationship with both children. Subsequently, DNA testing is conducted, and the results confirm that he is the biological father of one twin but not the other. How would you appropriately describe this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Superfecundation:

  • Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two or more ova from different acts of sexual intercourse, resulting in the conception of multiple embryos with different genetic fathers. In the given scenario, the woman gave birth to twins, but DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father.
  • This indicates that two separate acts of sexual intercourse with different partners occurred, leading to the fertilization of two different ova by two different spermatozoa. As a result, the twins have different genetic fathers, confirming the occurrence of superfecundation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Superfetation: Superfetation refers to the occurrence of a second pregnancy during an ongoing pregnancy, where a woman conceives another fetus while already pregnant. This is not applicable in the given scenario as there is no indication of a second pregnancy occurring during an ongoing pregnancy.

Option C - Suppositious child: A suppositious child refers to a child who is falsely or fraudulently claimed or substituted as one's own. In the given scenario, there is no indication of false claims or substitution of the child, as the DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father. Therefore, suppositious child is not the appropriate term for this case.

Option D - Atavism: Atavism refers to the reappearance of a characteristic or trait in an organism that is not present in its immediate ancestors but was present in previous generations. It is not applicable in the given scenario, as the issue at hand is related to the genetic paternity of the twins, rather than the reappearance of ancestral traits.

questions.text: A woman seeks medical attention due to secondary amenorrhea following a history of undergoing pituitary ablation. She now expresses a desire to become pregnant and consults with her fertility specialist. Which of the following therapeutic regimens is the most likely to induce ovulation in this patient?

choices.text: Human menopausal or recombinant gonadotropin, followed by hCG

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Human menopausal or recombinant gonadotropin, followed by hCG:

  • This Patient will not be able to produce endogenous gonadotropin, since her pituitary has been ablated.
  • Patient need to be given exogenous gonadotropin in the form of human menopausal gonadotropin (hMG), which contains FSH and LH in various ratio for follicular growth.
  • Timed administration of hCG, which takes the place of an endogenous LH surge, will be needed to complete oocyte maturation and induce ovulation.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene inhibits feedback inhibition of GnRH by estrogen action on hypothalamus to cause release of excess gonadotropins from pituitary, however here since pituitary is ablated, no amount of pituitary stimulation can cause release of LH and FSH, thus it will not help.

Option B- Letrozole: Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor, decreases estrogen and thereby reduces its feedback inhibition on hypothalamus and pituitary, causing release of LH and FSH from pituitary, however again, here Lh and FSH production from pituitary cannot happen.

Option C- Continuous infusion of GnRH: Continuous exogenous GnRH causes downregulation of pituitary receptors and thus does not help in ovulation. This action is used for treatment of endometriosis.

questions.text:
Match the following vaccine types:


	
		
			
			1. Typhoral vaccine
			
			
			a. Killed vaccine
			
		
		
			
			2. Typhim - vi
			
			
			b. Proteinaceous vaccine
			
		
		
			
			3. Pneumococcal vaccine
			
			
			c. Glycoconjugate vaccine
			
		
		
			
			4. Anthrax
			
			
			d. Polysaccharide vaccine
			
		
		
			 
			
			e. Live vaccine
			
		
		
			 
			
			f. Recombinant vaccines
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1e,2d,3c,4b: 

1. Typhoral vaccine

Live vaccine

2. Typhim - vi

Polysaccharide vaccine

3. Pneumococcal vaccine

Glycoconjugate vaccine

4. Anthrax

Proteinaceous vaccine

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presented to the clinic complaining of palpitation, dizziness, tiredness, and having tremors from the last three months. According to the patient, an unknown drug was given to him three months ago when he visited an emergency department for a sudden blood pressure rise. On examination, the vital sign is the heart rate is 122; oxygen saturation is 92% blood pressure is 150/65. Which of the following drug was given to the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Beta 1 and beta 2 agonists:

  • In the above question, the patient has palpitation, shortness of breath, and tremors.
  • The patient heart rate is increased, systolic blood pressure is increased, and diastolic blood pressure is decreased.
  • Beta 1 agonist acting on the heart because beta 1 receptor is present in the heart, and stimulation causes an increase in heart rate.
  • Beta 2 agonists are present on blood vessels and, on stimulation, cause vasodilation resulting in decreased diastolic blood pressure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Alpha 1 and beta 1 agonist:

  • Alpha 1 receptors are present on vascular smooth muscle and myocardial tissue; therefore, stimulation causes vasoconstriction and positive inotropic effects, respectively.
  • Beta 1 agonist acting on the heart because beta 1 receptor is present in the heart, and stimulation causes an increase in heart rate.

Option C - M2 and M3 agonist:

  • M2 receptors are present in the heart and, on stimulation, cause a slow heart rate.
  • M3 receptors on bronchial smooth muscle, glands and CNS on stimulation cause broncho construction, increasing secretion from glands and inducing emesis, respectively.

Option D - Alpha 1 antagonist and beta 2 agonist:

  • Alpha 1 antagonists are drugs which inhibit the alpha 1 receptor on vascular smooth muscle and myocardial cells, causing vasodilation and negative inotropic effects.
  • Beta 2 agonists are present on blood vessels and, on stimulation, cause vasodilation resulting in a decrease in diastolic blood pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about this Picture?

choices.text: When square color matches circle color or is darker, vaccine can be used for 1 hour
If the temperature is not maintained, the inner square tends to change color

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - If the temperature is not maintained, the inner square tends to change color:

  • If the temperature is maintained properly inner square always remains white.
  • If the temperature is not maintained, the inner square color doesn’t remain white, it becomes darker.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - We can use 3 and 4:

  • We cannot use vial 3 in the above-given image as the inner square is lighter than the outer circle.
  • Vial 4 in the image cannot be used as the inner square is darker than the outer circle.

Option B - When the square color matches the circle color or is darker, the vaccine can be used for 1 hour:

  • When the square color matches the circle color or is darker, the vial cannot be used.
  • The vial can be used only if the inner square is lighter than the outer circle.

Option D - We can use 1 and 2:

  • In the given image, vial 1 can be used, as the inner square is lighter than the outer circle.
  • But, vial 2 cannot be used as the inner square color matches the outer circle.

questions.text: What is the primary source of estrogen production in post-menopausal women?

choices.text: Aromatization of androgens in theca cells of the ovary
Aromatization of androgens in granulosa cells of the ovary
Aromatization of androgens in adipose tissue

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Aromatization of androgens in adipose tissue:

  • In this case, the patient has presented at menopause.
  • Androgen production from the ovary continues beyond the menopausal transition caused by the sparing of ovarian stroma and theca cells. However, due to the loss of granulosa cell function, the ovary does not contribute to estrogen production by the aromatization of androgens.
  • The most important source of estrogen is the peripheral conversion of androgens produced by the ovary and adrenals, principally occurring in adipose tissue.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Aromatization of androgens in theca cells of the ovary:

  • Theca cells produce androgens which are then converted to estrogen in granulosa cells, this production of estrogen doesn’t occur beyond the menopausal transition.

Option B- Aromatization of androgens in granulosa cells of the ovary:

  • The production of estrogen via the aromatization of androgens in granulosa cells of the ovary doesn't occur after menopause because of the loss of function of granulosa cells.

Option D- Adrenal production of estrogens:

  • After menopause, the adrenal glands alone cannot produce androgen. The adrenal glands only produce androgen.
  • The androgen from the adrenal gland goes into the adipose tissues for aromatization.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 female with A negative blood group presents for the first time in this pregnancy with absent fetal movements at 29 weeks. Her ICT test is positive with a high titre. She had a normal delivery in the last pregnancy but received no Anti D. Her ultrasound shows intrauterine fetal demise. All of the following findings may be seen at the ultrasound, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Small placenta:

  • The woman with a positive ICT and negative blood group most likely developed Rh isoimmunisation and fetal anaemia, which ultimately led to fetal hydrops followed by death.
  • A history of not receiving Anti D after previous delivery is also a high-risk factor for developing isoimmunisation in a subsequent pregnancy.
  • Fetal hydrops occurs due to excessive and prolonged hemolysis due to immunisation.
  • Characteristics of fetal hydrops include abnormal fluid in two or more sites, such as the thorax, abdomen, and skin.
  • The placenta is also markedly erythematous, enlarged, and boggy. In addition, massive hepatomegaly and splenomegaly may be present.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Polyhydramnios:

  • Polyhydramnios is one of the findings seen in patients with hydrops fetalis.

Option C- Pericardial effusion:

  • Pericardial effusion is seen on USG in hydrops fetalis

Option D- Ascites:

  • Excess accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity is a sign of hydrops fetalis

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, who recently underwent surgery for an aortic aneurysm, presents with elevated blood pressure, a pulse rate of 89 beats per minute, and dryness on the side of his face corresponding to the surgical incision. Additionally, constricted pupils are observed. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Horner syndrome:

  • Dryness of the face and constriction of the pupil on the side of the cut indicates that the thoracic sympathetic chain was cut and are suggestive of Horner syndrome.
  • The sympathetic trunk lies lateral to the vertebral bodies for the entire length of the vertebral column. The sympathetic trunk permits preganglionic fibres of the sympathetic system.
  • Horner syndrome compromises the constellation of clinical signs, including the classical triad. It results from the lesion to the sympathetic pathway that supplies the head and neck region.
  • Horner syndrome occurs due to a Pancoast tumour, birth trauma with injury to the lower brachial plexus, aortic aneurysm, and neuroblastoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Intermittent claudication:

  • Intermittent claudication is pain or fatigue in the muscles of the lower limb caused by walking and relieved by rest.
  • The distance between taking the first step and the onset of pain is called claudication distance, which is the parameter of the severity of the disease.

Option C - Facial nerve injury

  • Facial Nerve Injury, also known as Bell's Palsy, can cause facial weakness or paralysis, but it does not lead to constricted pupils or anhidrosis. The symptoms described are not consistent with facial nerve injury.

Option D - Arterial ulcers:

  • Arterial ulcers result from reduced arterial blood flow and subsequent tissue perfusion.
  • They usually occur over the toes, heels and bony prominences. They are painful and appear punched out with well-demarcated edges.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman underwent orthotopic liver transplantation from a 57-year-old cadaveric donor for end-stage liver disease caused by biliary cirrhosis. The biliary anastomosis was accomplished with a choledocho-jejunostomy. What is the role played by major histocompatibility complex proteins (MHC-1 and MHC-2)?

choices.text: Transduce the signals to T cells following antigen recognition
Present antigens for recognition by T cell antigen receptors

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Present antigens for recognition by T cell antigen receptors:

MHC presents antigens for recognition by T cell antigen receptors.

  1. MHC Class I: These molecules are present on the surface of almost all nucleated cells. They present antigens from within the cell (endogenous antigens) to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells. 

  2. MHC Class II: These molecules are typically found on antigen-presenting cells like dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells. They present antigens from outside the cell (exogenous antigens) to CD4+ helper T cells. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Transduce the signals to T cells following antigen recognition:

  • While MHC molecules are involved in antigen presentation to T cells, they themselves do not transduce signals to T cells. It is the T cell antigen receptors that initiate signaling upon recognition of the antigen-MHC complex.

Option B - Mediate immunoglobulin class-switching:

  • MHC molecules do not mediate immunoglobulin (antibody) class-switching. This process primarily involves interactions between B cells and T cells, and it is not a direct function of MHC molecules.

Option D - Enhance the secretion of cytokines:

  • Lipopolysaccharides of MHC molecules do not mediate immunoglobulin (antibody) class-switching. This process primarily involves interactions between B cells and T cells, and it is not a direct function of MHC molecules to enhance the secretion of cytokines.

questions.text:
In the outpatient department, a 10-year-old boy hailing from South America seeks medical attention due to a significant and swiftly expanding abdominal mass. Upon performing an abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan, the results indicate enlarged lymph nodes located in the retroperitoneal and mesenteric regions. Subsequent biopsy of one of the affected lymph nodes reveals a distinctive "starry-sky" appearance characterized by the presence of numerous intermediate-sized macrophages containing cellular debris.

Which of the following statements about this condition is true?

choices.text: The sporadic (Western) form is most frequently associated with EBV
Considered being a derivative of Hodgkin lymphoma
Most common cytogenetic change is t(8;14), with increased expression of c-myc
The tumour cells are derivatives of T lymphocytes

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Most common cytogenetic change is t(8;14), with increased expression of c-myc:

  • Starry sky appearance on histology usually points toward the diagnosis of Burkitt lymphoma; patient age (10 years), gender (male) and presentation of rapidly growing enlarged retroperitoneal and mesenteric lymph nodes further support the diagnosis. The specific cytogenetic change seen in it is t(8;14) with increased expression of the c-Myc gene.
  • It is an aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma most common in children and young adults.
  • Almost all endemic Burkitt lymphomas are latently infected with EBV, which also is present in almost 25% of HIV-associated tumours and 15-20% of sporadic cases.
  • The endemic (African) form is characterized by the involvement of the face, especially the maxilla or mandible associated with EBV.
  • The sporadic (Western) form usually involves the abdominal organs.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Sporadic (Western) form is most frequently associated with EBV:

  • The endemic form of Burkett's lymphoma, not western, is associated with the EBV virus.
  • It infects mature B cells, activating them to replicate uncontrollably.

Option B- Considered to be a derivative of Hodgkin lymphoma:

  • It is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • Hodgkin lymphoma is histologically characterized by the presence of Reed–Sternberg cells.

Option D- The tumour cells are derivatives of T lymphocytes:

  • Burkitt lymphoma develops mainly from B cells.
  • However, some number of t cells may be seen in it.

questions.text: In a clinical setting, a 22-year-old female patient seeks medical consultation. She has a known history of epilepsy and expresses her desire to become pregnant. The clinical query is focused on identifying which of the following antiepileptic medications carries the highest teratogenic risk and should be avoided in pregnant women.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Valproate:

  • Valproate is an anticonvulsant that increases Na+ channel inactivation, increasing GABA concentration by inhibiting GABA transaminase.
  • It is generally used for tonic-clonic seizures but can also treat partial (focal) and absence seizures.
  • It is also used for prophylaxis for migraines, myoclonic seizures, and bipolar disorder.
  • Sodium valproate is contra-indicated in children under 3 years due to the risk of hepatitis.
  • It is the antiepileptic with the highest risk of teratogenicity.
  • It is contraindicated in pregnant females as it can cause fetal valproate syndrome, which is characterised by spina bifida and other neural tube defects.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Carbamazepine:

  • Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant drug primarily used to treat epilepsy and neuropathic pain.
  • Carbamazepine treats trigeminal neuralgia and can also benefit peripheral neuropathy of diabetic origin.
  • It is also used as adjunctive therapy in schizophrenia and a second-line drug in bipolar disorder.
  • It is a teratogen and can cause cleft lip and palate spina bifida.

Option C - Phenytoin:

  • Phenytoin is an antiepileptic drug which functions by blocking Na+ channels.
  • It is mainly used in the treatment of focal (partial) seizures.
  • It is also used as the 1st line drug for prophylaxis of recurrent status epilepticus.
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome is caused by phenytoin.
  • It is caused by a toxic metabolite of phenytoin called arene oxide.
  • It occurs due to impaired DNA synthesis because of folate deficiency.
  • Features of fetal hydantoin syndrome include;
    • Hypoplastic phalanges
    • Cleft palate
    • Cleft Lip
    • Microcephaly

Option D - Lamotrigine:

  • Lamotrigine is a broad-spectrum antiepileptic drug that blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels and inhibits glutamate's release.
  • It treats partial (focal), tonic-clonic, and absence seizures.
  • Serious skin rashes, such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis, multi-organ hypersensitivity reactions and organ failure, as well as suicidal thoughts and behaviour, are the most frequent side effects of lamotrigine.
  • It has the least potential for teratogenicity.

questions.text: In a seminal fluid analysis, what is the recommended range for normal sperm morphology percentage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 4%:

  • Sperm morphology refers to the size and shape of the sperm, which are important factors in its ability to fertilize an egg. Abnormalities in sperm morphology can lead to difficulties with fertility.
  • The correct answer is b, 4%. According to the World Health Organization's (WHO) criteria (5th Edition), at least 4% of sperm in a sample should have normal morphology. This means that a man is considered to have a normal sperm morphology if 4% or more of his sperm are of a normal shape and size.
  • So, based on the most recent guidelines from the World Health Organization, if 4% or more of the sperm in a sample have normal morphology, it is considered normal. Hence, the correct answer is b, 4%.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and D is incorrect.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents with a six-week history of intermittent fever, arthralgias, myalgias, left lower quadrant abdominal pain, and a rash. He sought medical attention, and the local doctor prescribed a short course of steroids, which temporarily alleviated the rash and his constellation of symptoms. However, shortly after discontinuing the steroid treatment, he experienced a recurrence of fever and systemic symptoms. Upon examination, the patient displayed a rash characterized by scattered pink bumps on the arms, legs, and forehead, as well as a few purpuric macules on the palmoplantar surfaces. Additionally, he reported altered bowel habits and burning micturition in the past week. A skin papule biopsy has been performed, and the results are pending.  Which of the following statements regarding the underlying condition in this patient is CORRECT?

choices.text: It is a multi-system disorder characterised by necrotising vasculitis
Pulmonary artery involvement is a characteristic feature
Up to 30% of patients may show a positive test for HIV

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - It is a multi-system disorder characterised by necrotising vasculitis:

  • Polyarteritis Nodosa is a multi-system disorder that involves necrotizing inflammation all over the vessels in the body.
  • It typically affects medium-sized arteries, excluding the veins, especially at the branch points.
  • "Necrotizing vasculitis" refers to vessel wall necrosis caused by neutrophil infiltration.
  • Current evidence strongly suggests that these cells respond to the elaboration of complement cascade chemotactic factors released at the site of immune complex deposition in the vessel wall.
  • It most commonly affects greater than 50-year-old men.
  • The most common systems affected by PAN are renal, GI, nervous, and skin.
  • Treatment:
    • Necrotizing vasculitis is treated with a corticosteroid, a type of steroid.
    • This type of medication aids in the reduction of inflammation.
    • Corticosteroids are initially prescribed in high doses.
    • If the patient's condition improves, the doctor may gradually reduce the medication dosage.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Large-sized vessels are involved:

  • PAN involves medium-sized vessels at their branch points mainly. It doesn't include veins as well.
  • Severe and moderate PAN
  • Patients with moderate to severe Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) are typically treated with high-dose glucocorticoids and a second immunosuppressive drug, such as cyclophosphamide, followed by a combination of high-dose glucocorticoids and a second immunosuppressive drug, azathioprine or methotrexate for remission maintenance.
  • Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a multisystemic disease marked by necrotizing vasculitis of small and medium-sized blood vessels.

Option C - Pulmonary artery involvement is a characteristic feature:

  • The pulmonary artery is spared in PAN.
  • Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is characterized by necrotizing arteritis of medium and small arteries throughout the body.
  • Pulmonary artery involvement in PAN is thought to be uncommon.
  • The primary goal is to present lung changes in Polyarteritis nodosa patients.

Option D - Up to 30% of patients may show a positive test for HIV:

  • 30% of patients with PAN are hepatitis B positive or have rheumatoid arthritis. There is no association of HIV with PAN.
  • A granulomatous inflammation involving small arteries and veins of the brain surface and leptomeninges, known as primary angiitis of the central nervous system, is a rare vasculitis associated with high mortality as part of the immunocompromised caused by HIV.

questions.text: Among the cellular modifications experienced by DNA, one of them is DNA methylation. This chemical alteration can have an impact on DNA transcription depending on the specific sites where methylation occurs. DNA methylation is linked to several important biological processes. Which of the following processes is not associated with DNA methylation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Capping:

  • The 5' cap is a modified nucleotide found at the 5′ ends of several primary transcripts, such as precursor messenger RNA.
  • This process, known as mRNA capping, is highly controlled and essential for producing stable and mature messenger RNA capable of translation during protein synthesis.
  • Mitochondrial and chloroplastic mRNAs are uncapped.
  • 7-Methyl guanosine cap is added at the 5' end of mRNA by the enzyme Guanylyl Transferase. So, this is RNA methylation, not DNA.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mismatch repair:

  • After the mismatch repair, DNA methylation is done on the unmethylated strand of DNA which is daughter strand of DNA.
  • After the repair, the daughter strand will also be methylated.

Option B - DNA Replication:

  • DNA methylation is related to the DNA replication process.
  • After the replication process, when new DNA is formed, methylation of newly formed DNA is done to regulate gene expression.

Option C - Gene silencing:

  • DNA methylation is also related to gene silencing.
  • When methylation occurs at the promoter region of a gene, the transcription process is inhibited, thus silencing the gene.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is admitted to the hospital with the following complaints: He is experiencing vague abdominal pain and has observed the passage of black, tarry stools. During the examination, his blood pressure is measured at 110/70 mmHg, and his pulse rate is 110 beats per minute. Physical examination reveals a diffusely tender abdomen. The patient's medical history includes several months of multiple joint pain. Laboratory results indicate that he has ANCA-negative vasculitis. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Polyarteritis nodosa:

  • Polyarteritis nodosa is a vasculitis that affects medium-sized arteries.
  • The most common arteries involved are
    • Renal
    • Mesenteric
  • Usually, the pulmonary arteries are spared.
  • It is linked to the hepatitis B virus rather than the ANCA.
  • HBsAg and HBsAb combine to form complexes that accumulate in arteries.
  • The symptoms are caused by infarction of the involved arteries.
  • Ischemia is caused by a lack of blood supply distal to the involved region of the artery.
  • Morphological Features are
    • Transmural necrotising inflammation
    • Superimposed aneurysm or thrombosis
    • Infiltration of neutrophils, eosinophils and mononuclear cells in the arterial wall.
    • Fibrinoid necrosis
    • Luminal fibrosis
  • Common symptoms are
    • Myalgia
    • Peripheral neuritis

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Wegner granulomatosis:

  • Wegner granulomatosis involves ENT regions, lungs and kidneys.
  • It is associated with c-ANCA

Option B - Churg strauss syndrome:

  • It is also known as allergic granulomatosis
  • It affects small vessels.
  • It is associated with P - ANCA.

Option D - Microscopic polyangiitis:

  • It is a type of vasculitis that affects small arteries and venules.
  • It is associated with P-ANCA.

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			1) Sensitivity
			
			
			a) Ability of test to find true negative
			
		
		
			
			2) Specificity
			
			
			b) Probability that subjects with a positive screening test truly have the disease
			
		
		
			
			3) Positive predictive value
			
			
			c) Ability of test to find true positive
			
		
		
			
			4) Negative predictive value
			
			
			d) Probability that subjects with a negative screening test truly don’t have the disease
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d:

Sensitivity

Ability of test to identify correctly all those who have the disease, that is “true positive”.

Specificity

Ability of test to identify correctly all those who don’t have the disease, that is “true negative”.

Positive predictive value

Probability that subjects with a positive screening test truly have the disease.

Negative predictive value

Probability that subjects with a negative screening test truly don’t have the disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of progressive neuropathy, including sensory loss, autonomic dysfunction, and cardiomyopathy. Laboratory investigations reveal the presence of amyloid deposits in various tissues. Genetic testing is subsequently performed, and the results show a mutation in the transthyretin gene (TTR). Which of the following statements regarding familial amyloidosis is CORRECT?

choices.text: Familial amyloidosis is always associated with mutations in the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene.
The most common mutation associated with familial amyloidosis involves the immunoglobulin light chain (AL).
Transthyretin gene (TTR) mutations in familial amyloidosis typically lead to cardiac involvement.
Familial amyloidosis is an autosomal recessive disorder.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Transthyretin gene (TTR) mutations in familial amyloidosis typically lead to cardiac involvement:

  • This option is correct because transthyretin gene (TTR) mutations are indeed associated with familial amyloidosis, and they often lead to cardiac involvement. Familial amyloidosis due to TTR mutations is commonly known as hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis (hATTR). In hATTR, mutant TTR protein aggregates form amyloid deposits in various tissues, including the heart, peripheral nerves, and other organs. Cardiac involvement can result in cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias, and heart failure, making this a characteristic feature of hATTR amyloidosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Familial amyloidosis is always associated with mutations in the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene:

  • This option is incorrect because not all forms of familial amyloidosis are associated with mutations in the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene. Mutations in APP are indeed associated with familial Alzheimer's disease, but familial amyloidosis can result from mutations in various genes, including the transthyretin gene (TTR), as mentioned in the correct option.

Option B - The most common mutation associated with familial amyloidosis involves the immunoglobulin light chain (AL):

  • This option is incorrect because the most common mutation associated with familial amyloidosis is not related to the immunoglobulin light chain (AL). Instead, it is associated with mutations in the transthyretin gene (TTR), particularly in hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis (hATTR). Immunoglobulin light chain (AL) amyloidosis is a distinct form of amyloidosis where abnormal monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains are deposited as amyloid.

Option D - Familial amyloidosis is an autosomal recessive disorder:

  • This option is incorrect because familial amyloidosis is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, not autosomal recessive. In autosomal dominant inheritance, an affected individual has a 50% chance of passing the mutation to their offspring, while in autosomal recessive disorders, both parents must carry a mutated gene for the disorder to be expressed in their offspring.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male bitten by a tick presented to the hospital with headache, nausea, muscle aches, and a blackened crusted rash on the site of the bite. The physician sent him for performing an indirect immunofluorescence assay (IFA) with the R.rickettsii antigen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - RMSF:

  • Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF) is a bacterial disease spread through the bite of an infected tick.
  • Signs and symptoms can include Fever, Headache, Rash, Nausea, Vomiting, Stomach pain, Muscle pain, and Lack of appetite.
  • Doxycycline is the most effective antibiotic for the treatment of suspected rickettsial infections, including Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Epidemic typhus: Epidemic typhus is transmitted by louse.

Option B - Endemic typhus: Endemic typhus is transmitted by rat flea.

Option C - Scrub typhus: Scrub typhus and Rickettsial pox are transmitted by mites.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents to the rheumatology clinic with complaints of joint pain, purplish discoloration of her fingers, and recurrent episodes of fatigue. On examination, you notice palpable purpura on her lower extremities and several swollen joints. Laboratory tests reveal the presence of cryoglobulins in her blood.Which of the following conditions is MOST commonly associated with type II cryoglobulinemia, the type commonly seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hepatitis C infection:

  • Type II cryoglobulinemia is most commonly associated with hepatitis C infection. Cryoglobulins are abnormal proteins that precipitate from the blood at low temperatures and can cause various symptoms, including joint pain, skin manifestations (such as purpura), and fatigue. Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection is a well-established trigger for the development of type II cryoglobulinemia. The immune complexes formed during HCV infection can lead to the production of cryoglobulins, which then deposit in small blood vessels and cause inflammation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): While SLE is an autoimmune disease that can involve the production of various autoantibodies, it is not commonly associated with cryoglobulinemia. Cryoglobulinemia, particularly type II, is more frequently linked to infections like hepatitis C.

Option B - Rheumatoid arthritis (RA): Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune condition primarily characterized by joint inflammation and is not typically associated with the production of cryoglobulins.

Option D - Multiple sclerosis (MS): Multiple sclerosis is a neurological autoimmune disorder and is not commonly associated with cryoglobulinemia. The key association here is with hepatitis C infection.

questions.text: In the emergency department, a 60-year-old female patient seeks medical attention due to experiencing left-sided weakness in her body and face for over an hour. Her medical history includes hypertension and diabetes. Upon assessment, her blood pressure measures 160/100mmHg, her pulse is 90 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 95% while breathing room air. An urgent non-contrast CT scan reveals no significant abnormalities. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate initial intervention for this patient?

choices.text: Give loading dose of aspirin and clopidogrel

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Start thrombolysis:

  • An ischemic stroke is caused by atherosclerosis, clot emboli, septic emboli, etc.
  • Diabetes, smoking, atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension are important risk factors for stroke. The thickening of vessel walls causes lacunar strokes.
  • Clinical features of an ischemic stroke depend upon the artery that is occluded. Patients can present with contralateral hemiparesis, hemisensory loss, aphasia, apraxia, contralateral body neglect, or confusion.
  • Management of a patient with ischemic stroke involves:
    • A CT scan should be done to rule out a haemorrhagic stroke.
    • An unremarkable CT scan indicates an ischemic stroke.
    • Supportive treatment with airway protection, oxygen, and intravenous fluids. Oral intake should be restricted, and the head end of the bed should be elevated to 30 degrees to prevent aspiration.
    • Thrombolytic therapy with tissue plasminogen activator to dissolve the clot.
      • When the systolic blood pressure is >185mmHg or diastolic blood pressure >110mmHg, it is a contraindication to thrombolysis because intracerebral hemorrhage can occur.
      • Lowering blood pressure should be done before starting thrombolysis.
      • Cerebral perfusion pressure = Mean arterial pressure – Intracranial pressure.
      • So high blood pressure is required in cerebrovascular accidents to maintain cerebral perfusion pressure.
      • In ischemic stroke, if neurological deficits are present, then thrombolysis can be performed within 4.5 hours of symptom onset.
      • The woman in the clinical scenario above presents within an hour of symptom presentation, and her blood pressure is below 185/110, so thrombolysis can be performed.
      • If a patient has uncontrolled hypertension, is taking anticoagulants, has a history of a bleeding disorder, or has a history of recent trauma or surgery, then thrombolysis is contraindicated.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Give a loading dose of aspirin and clopidogrel:

  • Loading doses of aspirin and clopidogrel can be given in managing transient ischaemic attacks.
  • In transient ischaemic attack, symptoms resolve within 24 hours, and in most patients, within 1 hour.

Option C - Manage blood pressure alone:

  • Blood pressure should not be lowered in cerebrovascular accidents as it can lower brain perfusion. If blood pressure is >185/100mmHg, the pressure should be lowered before initiating thrombolysis.

Option D - No intervention is required:

  • An ischemic stroke requires urgent thrombolysis if no contraindications are present.

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of normal labor:
A. Flexion

B. Engagement

C. Descent

D. Internal rotation

E. External rotation

F. Extension

choices.text: C, B, A, D, F, E
B, C, D, E, F, A
B, C, E, D, F, A
B, C, A, D, F, E

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - As a first choice if not willing to use conventional contraceptives:

  • Emergency contraceptives are never indicated as the first choice of contraception.

Indications for the use of Emergency contraception are:

  • Failure to use contraception: unplanned intercourse, miscalculation of dates, rape.
  • Condom breakage or leakage, incorrect use of the diaphragm.
  • Missed pills (2 or more).
  • Expulsion of IUCD.
  • More than 2 weeks late for Injection: DMPA.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Failure to use contraceptives in unplanned intercourse: If the couples have unintentional unprotected intercourse, then emergency contraceptives are indicated.

Option B - Miscalculation of safe period: Emergency contraceptives are indicated if the female partner has miscalculated her period.

Option C - Failed coitus interrupts: Emergency contraceptives are indicated if the couple had a failure of coitus interruptus.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old female patient presents to the medical outpatient ward with a chief complaint of muscle fatigue, weakness, droopy eyelids, and exercise intolerance that have persisted for the past four months. Genetic investigation has revealed an inheritance pattern, and a pedigree chart has been examined. In this pedigree:



What mode of inheritance is exemplified by this pattern?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Mitochondrial:

  • Based on the pedigree discussed above, where all the children from sisters are affected, but all the children from sons are not affected, this is a case of mitochondrial myopathy.
  • It has a mitochondrial inheritance pattern, and the symptoms discussed point towards mitochondrial myopathy.
  • In mitochondrial inheritance, transmission is exclusively maternal; affected men do not pass the characteristics to their children, whereas affected females pass it on to all of their children.
  • Genes that code for oxidative phosphorylation enzymes are commonly involved in mitochondrial inheritance abnormalities.
  • Symptoms of mitochondrial myopathy: Muscle weakness or exercise intolerance, deafness, blindness, droopy eyelids, movement disorders, stroke-like episodes, limited mobility of the eyes, heart failure or rhythm disturbances, dementia, vomiting, and seizures.
  • Treatment: Physical therapy may increase the muscles' range of motion and increase dexterity even though there is no cure for any of the mitochondrial myopathies.
  • Disorders due to Mitochondrial inheritance include:
    • Mitochondrial myopathy
    • Leigh syndrome
    • Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy
    • Diabetes mellitus and deafness (DAD) combination

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Autosomal dominant:

  • Based on the pedigree discussed above, where all the children from sisters are affected, but all the children from sons are not affected, this is a case of the Mitochondrial inheritance pattern.
  • In the Autosomal dominant pattern, males and females are equally affected. Examples include:
    • Achondroplasia
    • Marfan syndrome
    • Ehlers-Danlos syndrome

Option B - Autosomal recessive:

  • Based on the pedigree discussed above, where all the children from sisters are affected, but all the children from sons are not affected, this is a case of the Mitochondrial inheritance pattern.
  • In the Autosomal recessive pattern, males and females are equally affected. Parents are carriers and are clinically normal. Only homozygous children are affected. Examples include:
    • Beta thalassemia
    • Glycogen storage disease
    • Cystic fibrosis

Option D - X-linked dominant:

  • Based on the pedigree discussed above, where all the children from sisters are affected, but all the children from sons are not affected, this is a case of the Mitochondrial inheritance pattern.
  • In the X-linked dominant pattern, females are more affected than men. It can manifest in heterozygous females and homozygous males. Examples include:
    • Vitamin D-resistant rickets.
    • Pseudohypoparathyroidism

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman seeks medical attention in the outpatient department because she has been experiencing bifrontal headaches and early-morning nausea and vomiting persistently for the past 4 weeks. During the examination, she appears alert and cooperative. Her blood pressure is measured at 110/70 mmHg, and her pulse rate is 80 beats per minute. Her body mass index (BMI) is calculated to be 32 kg/m². Upon fundoscopy, bilateral papilledema is observed. The patient's visual acuity is assessed at 20/20 in both eyes. A comprehensive neurologic examination reveals no abnormalities. A CT scan of the head is performed and shows no abnormalities.

What is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension:

  • This patient’s nausea, vomiting, headaches and papilledema are consistent with raised intracranial pressure (ICP)
  • Headaches are almost always present with raised ICP. They can be of a variable pattern but mostly worsen with recombinant position or while straining.
  • Although the underlying cause of this patient's elevated ICP has yet to be proved, idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) is likely, given her young age, obesity, lack of additional comorbidities, and normal CT scan of the head.
  • Differential diagnosis of headaches is given below.

Disease

Features

Craniopharyngioma
  • Presents in children and adults after 55 years
  • Features of raised ICT
  • Visual field defects like Bi-temporal hemianopia.

Idiopathic

intracranial

hypertension
  • Obese women
  • Headache and sixth nerve palsy.
  • Raised ICP causes papilledema.

Optic neuritis
  • Acute inflammatory condition of the optic nerve.
  • Causes painful eye movements and visual loss.
  • The fundus looks normal due to retrobulbar pathology.

Sagittal

sinus

Thrombosis

Setting of Risk factors

  • OCP,
  • Pregnancy,
  • Postpartum period,
  • Polycythemia

Headache, vomiting, seizures

Paraparesis.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Craniopharyngioma:

  • It presents in children and adults after the age of 55 years.
  • There are features of raised ICP.
  • Visual field defects like Bi-temporal hemianopia are common as it compresses the optic chiasm.
  • This diagnosis is unlikely in this patient as she has a normal head CT scan which rules out craniopharyngioma.

Option C- Optic neuritis:

  • Optic neuritis is an acute inflammatory condition of the optic nerve.
  • It causes painful eye movements and visual loss.
  • Fundus looks normal due to retrobulbar pathology.
  • However, the patient has signs and symptoms of raised intracranial pressure.
  • And fundus examination shows bilateral papilledema, which is inconsistent with optic neuritis.

Option D- Sagittal sinus thrombosis:

  • Risk factors for sagittal sinus thrombosis include
  1. OCP,
  2. Pregnancy,
  3. Postpartum period,
  4. Polycythemia
  • It also causes headaches, vomiting, seizures and paraparesis.
  • In this patient, the absence of any risk factor, young age, obesity, lack of additional comorbidities, and normal head CT scan makes Idiopathic Intracranial hypertension most likely.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man arrives at the emergency department, reporting ten years of heavy alcohol consumption, including morning drinking over the past year. He last consumed alcohol three days ago and denies any head injury or seizures. On examination, there are no signs of jaundice, hepatic encephalopathy, or focal neurological deficits. However, the patient displays coarse tremors, visual hallucinations, and disorientation regarding the current time.What is the most appropriate medication to prescribe for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Diazepam & thiamine:

Delirium tremens:

  • Most severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome.
  • Clinical features:
    • Clouding of consciousness with disorientation to time and place
    • Poor attention and distractibility
    • Visual hallucination and illusions which are often vivid and very frightening
    • Autonomic disturbances like tachycardia, fever, hypertension, sweating, and pupillary dilatation
    • Tachycardia, fever, and hypertension differentiate delirium tremens from alcoholic hallucinosis in which these signs are normal.
    • Psychomotor agitation and ataxia

Treatment:

  • Drug of choice is benzodiazepines like diazepam.
  • Prophylactic thiamine to prevent the development of Wernicke’s encephalopathy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diazepam & Lithium:

  • Diazepam is the treatment of choice for delirium tremens. However, lithium is a mood stabilizer used in mood disorders. Hence this option is incorrect.

Option B - Haloperidol & naltrexone:

  • This option is incorrect
  • Haloperidol is an antipsychotic drug, and naltrexone is used to treat opioid dependence.

Option D - Naltrexone & dantrolene:

  • This option is incorrect
  • Naltrexone is used to treat opioid dependence, and dantrolene is used in malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a history of progressive neurological symptoms. He reports difficulty walking, frequent falls, and night blindness. On examination, you note bilateral optic disc pallor, reduced visual acuity, and horizontal nystagmus. He also demonstrates severe muscle weakness and sensory loss in the lower limbs with impaired proprioception and vibration sense. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?

choices.text: GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FXN gene
CTG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the DMPK gene
T8993G point mutation in the mitochondrial DNA
T14484C point mutation in the mitochondrial DNA

questions.solution:
Correct Option (D): D) T14484C point mutation in the mitochondrial DNA

Explanation: The correct answer is D, the T14484C point mutation in mitochondrial DNA. This mutation is associated with NARP (Neuropathy, Ataxia, and Retinitis Pigmentosa) syndrome, a mitochondrial disorder. The T14484C mutation affects mitochondrial complex I, leading to impaired oxidative phosphorylation and energy production. This genetic abnormality aligns with the clinical presentation of progressive neurological symptoms, including muscle weakness, sensory loss, ataxia (difficulty walking and frequent falls), and retinal involvement (optic disc pallor and reduced visual acuity). NARP syndrome is one of the mitochondrial diseases characterized by this specific mutation.

Now, let's discuss the incorrect options:

Incorrect Option (A): A) GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FXN gene

Explanation: This option refers to Friedreich's ataxia, which is a different genetic disorder. Friedreich's ataxia is characterized by progressive ataxia and cardiomyopathy due to a GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FXN gene. While it shares some features with NARP syndrome, it does not involve retinitis pigmentosa or mitochondrial DNA mutations.

Incorrect Option (B): B) CTG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the DMPK gene

Explanation: This option describes myotonic dystrophy, which is another genetic disorder but not related to NARP syndrome. Myotonic dystrophy is characterized by myotonia, muscle wasting, and multi-organ involvement. It does not typically include retinitis pigmentosa or mitochondrial DNA mutations.

Incorrect Option (C): C) T8993G point mutation in the mitochondrial DNA

Explanation: This option refers to a different mitochondrial DNA mutation associated with NADH:ubiquinone oxidoreductase deficiency, leading to Leigh syndrome. Leigh syndrome primarily presents with neurodegenerative symptoms but does not usually include the characteristic triad of neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa seen in NARP syndrome.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with complaints of progressively worsening vision and frequent changes in her glasses prescription over the past six months. On examination, her best-corrected visual acuity is 20/40 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals Vogt's striae and Fleischer rings on both corneas. Corneal topography shows asymmetric bowtie patterns with inferior steepening. Which advanced diagnostic technique is most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis and evaluating the extent of the condition in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Pentacam Scheimpflug Imaging:

Pentacam is a specialized imaging technique that provides detailed corneal topography and pachymetry. It is particularly useful in diagnosing and monitoring progressive conditions like keratoconus, capturing features such as irregular astigmatism, thinning, and steepening of the cornea.

Incorrect Options:

B) Corneal Confocal Microscopy: Corneal confocal microscopy is primarily used for evaluating corneal nerve fibers and cellular structures. While it's useful in certain neuropathic conditions, it's not the primary choice for diagnosing keratoconus.

C) Anterior Segment Optical Coherence Tomography (AS-OCT): AS-OCT provides high-resolution cross-sectional images of the anterior segment of the eye. While it's valuable for various conditions, Pentacam offers more comprehensive corneal mapping in keratoconus cases.

D) Endothelial Cell Density Measurement: Endothelial cell density measurement is important for assessing the health of the corneal endothelium, but it doesn't provide the detailed corneal shape information required for diagnosing keratoconus.

questions.text:
A 1-year-old female child is brought to the outpatient department by her parents. They have noticed scaly skin lesions accompanied by purpuric rashes affecting various areas, including the scalp, abdomen, neck, and face. The child has also been experiencing a cough and appears to be tachypneic. Upon physical examination, lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are observed. An X-ray of the long bones reveals the presence of multiple lytic lesions.

What is the most probable underlying cause of these clinical manifestations?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Letterer-Siwe disease:

  • Purpuric rashes involving the scalp, abdomen, neck and face, multiple lesions of long bones and hepatosplenomegaly all indicate Letterer Siwe disease.
  • Letterer-Siwe disease mainly affects children between 1 to 3 years of age.
  • Letterer-Siwe disease is a multifocal and multisystem disease.
  • Letterer–Siwe disease is one of the four clinical syndromes of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
  • It appears as generalised hyperplasia of nonlipid-storing macrophages in the liver, spleen, lymph nodes, skin and bone marrow.
  • The disease is fatal, with a very bad five-year survival rate of 50%.
  • Letterer-Siwe disease treatment always includes supportive care.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B- Eosinophilic granulomatis:

  • Eosinophilic granulomatis are the benign form of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
  • Any bone can be involved, including the skull, mandible, spine, ribs and long bones.
  • The lesions may be asymptomatic most of the time and discovered incidentally.
  • The patient often refers to a tender, painful mass for several weeks to several months before diagnosis.

Option C- Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis:

  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH), previously called eosinophilic granuloma of the lungs.
  • It is an uncommon cystic interstitial lung disease that primarily affects young adults.
  • A disorder of myeloid dendritic cells causes pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
  • The onset peaks between 20 and 40 years of age.

Option D- Anaplastic large cell lymphoma:

  • Anaplastic large-cell lymphoma is a non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • It is a serious form of cancer that affects T lymphocytes, and they grow abnormally large.
  • Anaplastic large-cell lymphoma is rare and affects about 2% of adult non-Hodgkin lymphoma cases.

questions.text: In the outpatient department, a 54-year-old male patient seeks medical attention, reporting symptoms of dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) and hematemesis (vomiting blood). The patient has a substantial history of smoking and alcohol consumption. He has a confirmed diagnosis of advanced esophageal carcinoma and is currently undergoing palliative chemotherapy. What is the most frequent site of occurrence for esophageal carcinoma?

choices.text: The lower end of the esophagus

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Middle 1/3rd:

  • The middle part of the esophagus is the most common location for Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus(SCCE), which is the most common histology found all around the world.
  • The incidence of adenocarcinoma is significantly higher in the United States.
  • Intraepithelial neoplasia, such as dysplasia and carcinoma in situ, can lead to the development of invasive SCCE if it progresses far enough to invade the lamina propria and spreads beyond the submucosa.
  • Because symptoms appear more commonly in advanced disease, an early diagnosis of SCCE must not be based on symptoms, and as a result, screening approaches must be employed in asymptomatic persons who are exposed to risk factors.
  • Although esophageal squamous cell carcinoma can develop in the proximal and middle portions of the esophagus.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Upper 1/3rd: The Upper 1/3rd of the esophagus is not the most common site for SCCE.

Option C - Lower 1/3rd: The lower 1/3rd of the esophagus is not the most common site for SCCE.

Option D - The lower end of the esophagus: The lower end of the esophagus is not the most common site for SCCE.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presented to OPD with a complaint of experiencing post-coital bleeding over the past two months. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Colposcopy biopsy:

  • Post-coital bleeding is the → most common presentation of CA cervix
  • PAP smear is done when a patient is asymptomatic or sexually active women
  • Here, The patient is symptomatic; hence a confirmatory test is warranted to make a diagnosis.
  • Doing a four Quadrant biopsy may help, but it is more of a 'Hit and trial' method since the invasion could start in a different place away from the 4 biopsies sites. Performing a Colposcopic is the best procedure here than a Pap smear or the 4 Quad biopsy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pap smear:

  • The pap smear is used only in asymptomatic patients having a suspicion of CA Cervix, and it is also used for mass screening to determine the CIN or pre-malignant lesion. It is never used for patients having a symptomatic presentation of the CA Cervix.

Option C - Cryotherapy:

  • Cervix cryosurgery is a procedure to freeze and destroy abnormal tissue in the cervix. This procedure may be done to treat cervicitis . It is not used for the diagnosis of CA Cervix.

Option D – Hysterectomy:

  • A hysterectomy is done for proven early stage cervical cancer.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male patient presents with complaints of steatorrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. Upon conducting a duodenal biopsy, it is observed that the patient has villous atrophy with crypt hyperplasia and lymphocytic infiltration. Further investigation reveals an association with HLA-DQ2, and anti-transglutaminase antibodies are detected. Based on these findings, what is the likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Celiac sprue:

  • Gluten-sensitive enteropathy, another name for celiac disease, is an autoimmune condition affecting the small intestine.
  • The consumption of gluten by those who are vulnerable to it causes it.
  • Patients' genetics determines their susceptibility. Some celiac disease patients may not exhibit symptoms, while others may experience diarrhoea and failure to thrive.
  • Disease typically affects the mucosa of the small bowel. Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies, anti-gliadin antibodies and anti-endomysial antibodies, often reported as negative, weakly positive, or positive, are the two antibodies evaluated (by ELISA quantified numerically).
  • A duodenal mucosal biopsy is typically the following step and the gold standard for the diagnosis, which shows crypt elongation and hyperplasia, intraepithelial lymphocytosis, and villous atrophy.
  • All celiac disease patients are advised to adhere to a tight gluten-free diet.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Tropical sprue: Tropical sprue is an infectious disease most commonly caused by E.coli involving the complete small intestine resulting in a deficiency of iron, folic acid and Vitamin B12.

Option C - Crohn’s disease: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease associated with Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae Antibody (ASCA)

Option D - Familial adenomatous polyposis: Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a germline mutation in the APC gene resulting in multiple polyps in the GI tract.

questions.text:
In the outpatient department, a 37-year-old male patient presents with complaints of hematemesis. The patient has a confirmed history of peptic ulcer disease and has been receiving irregular treatment. During an endoscopic examination, the source of bleeding is identified, and electrocoagulation is performed.

According to Forrest's classification, which of the following categories is associated with an intermediate risk of rebleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Adherent clot:

  • Rebleeding risk is high in all of the above except in the case of adherent clots
