  • The Forrest Classification for Endoscopic findings and Rebleeding Risks in Peptic Ulcer Disease:

Classification

  

Rebleeding risk

Grade Ia

Active pulsatile bleeding

High

Grade Ib

Active non-pulsatile bleeding

High

Grade IIa

Nonbleeding visible vessel

High

Grade IIb

Adherent clot

Intermediate

Grade IIC

Ulcer with black spot

Low

Grade III

Clean nonbleeding ulcer

Low
  • Management:
    • Endoscopic therapy is recommended in cases of active bleeding as well as for a visible vessel (Forrest I-IIa)
    • For Forrest IIb, the clot is removed, and the underlying lesion evaluated
    • Ulcers with a clean base or a black spot, secondary to hematin deposition, are generally not treated endoscopically

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Visible vessel: A nonbleeding visible vessel falls in Grade IIa and carries a high risk of rebleeding.

Option B - Visible pulsatile bleeding: Active pulsatile bleeding falls in Grade Ia and carries a high risk of rebleeding.

Option D - Visible oozing from the vessel: A Visible oozing from the vessel carries a high risk of rebleeding.

questions.text:
In a 26-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks of gestation, a fetal echocardiography examination detected an echogenic mass within the posterior wall of the left ventricle of the fetus's heart. Subsequently, the pregnancy was terminated, and a biopsy of fetal cardiac tissue was performed, which revealed the presence of dystrophic calcification.

In which of the following conditions is dystrophic calcification seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Myositis ossificans:

  • It is a form of connective tissue metaplasia.
  • It is observed in patients who have experienced traumatic injuries.
  • The patient will most likely have dystrophic calcification because deteriorating muscle tissue is already present in the body.
  • Both metastatic cancer and sarcoidosis are characterized by a process known as metastatic calcification, and both illnesses are associated with elevated serum calcium levels.

Dystrophic calcification:

  • It is seen in dead or degenerative tissue.
  • Affected Patients will have normal serum Ca2+

Causes of dystrophic calcification:

  • TB
  • Chronic abscess
  • Infarcts
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Hematoma
  • Tumours like meningioma, mesothelioma
  • Myositis ossificans
  • Psammoma bodies

Dystrophic calcification is seen in the following:

  • RHD
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, ovary, and salivary gland
  • Myositis ossificans, Meningioma

Metastatic calcification:

  • It is seen in Living tissues.
  • Affected Patients will have Hypercalcemia.

Causes of metastatic calcification

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Hypervitaminosis D
  • Rickets

Metastatic calcification is seen in the following:

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Vitamin D Intoxication
  • Sarcoidosis, Milk alkali syndrome
  • Metastasis (Multiple myeloma)

Incorrect Options: 

Option B- Paget's disease:

  • Dystrophic calcification is not seen in Paget's disease.

Option C- Metastasis:

  • Dystrophic calcification is not seen in Metastasis.

Option D- Sarcoidosis:

  • Dystrophic calcification is not seen in Sarcoidosis.

questions.text: Congenital cataracts result from specific genetic and metabolic abnormalities, leading to the development of opacities in the eye lens. Mutations in particular genes play a crucial role in the formation of these lens opacities. Among these genetic factors, which gene is most frequently associated with congenital cataracts, especially when related to alpha-crystallin mutations?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - CRYAA:

  • Mutations in the CRYAA gene are responsible for congenital cataracts and alpha-crystallin mutation.
  • This gene is most commonly associated with congenital cataracts.
  • Congenital cataracts can be caused by mutations in various genes, and one of the genes frequently implicated in congenital cataracts is CRYAA, which codes for alpha-crystallin. Mutations in this gene can lead to abnormalities in the lens protein alpha-crystallin, resulting in lens opacity and the development of congenital cataracts.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - GLC3A:

  • GLC3A gene mutations are associated with primary congenital glaucoma.
  • It does not lead to alpha-crystallin mutation.

Option B - PAX6:

  • PAX6 mutations are responsible for aniridia, Peters anomaly, Coloboma, Microphthalmos and WAGR syndrome.
  • This gene is not implicated in congenital cataracts.

Option C - PITX2:

  • PITX2 gene mutations are associated with Axenfeld-Rieger Syndrome and Peters anomaly.
  • This gene is not implicated in congenital cataracts and alpha-crystallin mutation.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of the Demographic Cycle in the correct chronological sequence:


	Late expanding stage
	Early expanding stage
	High stationery stage
	Declining stage
	Low stationery stage
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 3→2→1→5→4:

  • High stationary → Early expanding → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining
  • This is the correct chronological sequence of the Demographic Cycle.
 

Phase I

Phase II

Phase III

Phase IV

Phase V
 

High stationary

Early expanding

Late expanding

Low stationary

Declining

Birth rate

High

High

Declining

Low

Low

Death rate

High

Declining

Declining

Low

Declining

Population

Stationary

Growing

Growing

Stationary

Decreasing

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 3→1→4→5→2:

  • This is not the correct chronological sequence of the Demographic Cycle.
  • High stationary → Early expanding → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining is the correct chronological sequence of the Demographic Cycle.

Option B - 1→3→4→1→5:

  • This is not the correct chronological sequence of the Demographic Cycle.
  • High stationary is the first stage of the Demographic Cycle.
  • The correct sequence is High stationary → Early expanding → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining.

Option C - 2→3→4→1→5:

  • This is not the correct chronological sequence of the Demographic Cycle.
  • The correct sequence is High stationary → Early expanding → Late expanding → Low stationary → Declining.

questions.text:
Match the following diameter with their respective normal measurements.


	
		
			A. Occipitofrontal
			1. 9.5 cm
		
		
			B. Suboccipitobregmatic
			2. 10 cm
		
		
			C. Suboccipitofrontal
			3. 14 cm
		
		
			D. Mentovertical
			4. 11.5 cm
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Squamous cell carcinoma:

  • Cancer of the vulva makes up approximately 5% of all gynaecologic malignancies, and approximately 90% of vulvar cancer is squamous cells
  • Other cancers, along with percentages, are mentioned in the table.

Malignant Tumors of the Vulva Based on IARC/WHO Classification

Type

percentage

Malignant Epithelial Tumors

  

Squamous cell carcinoma (Keratinizing, non-keratinizing, basaloid, warty, verrucous)

90-92%

Melanoma

2-4 %

Basal Cell Carcinoma8

2-3%

Paget disease

<1%

Bartholin gland (adenocarcinoma, squamous cell, adenosquamous, adenoid cystic, transitional cell)

1%

Tumours arising from other specialized anogenital glands (adenocarcinoma of mammary gland type, adenocarcinoma of skene gland or minor vestibular gland origin, malignant phyllodes tumour)

<1%

Adenocarcinomas of other types (sweat gland type, intestinal type)

<1%
  • Squamous cancer can develop through a “precancerous” condition, which occurs when there are changes in cells, but these cells do not always become cancerous. This is called vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN).
  • VIN is a premalignant growth of cells on the vulva and is treated differently from invasive cancer.
  • Histology slide of squamous cell carcinoma is given below:

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Columnar Cell Carcinoma:

  • Columnar cell carcinoma is not common histology in vulvar cancers.
  • This type of histology is more common in papillary thyroid cancer.
  • It consists of papillae or gland-like structures lined by columnar cells and prominent nuclear stratification.

Option B - Transitional Cell Carcinoma:

  • This type of histology is very uncommon in the vulva or vagina.
  • It is more common in the ureters and bladder.
  • Invasive urothelial carcinoma consists of irregular nests of cells invading lamina propria and muscularis propria.

Option C – Adenocarcinoma:

  • Adenocarcinomas do occur as vulvar cancers.
  • However, these are 1% of the malignancies that occur in the vulva.
  • Extramammary Paget's disease predisposes to this histological type.

questions.text: In the clinic, a 35-year-old male patient seeks medical attention due to noticeable declines in memory and increased forgetfulness. He expresses frustration over his inability to assist his children with math problems, a task that he once enjoyed, and mentions difficulties in remembering grocery lists. Following an extensive workup and evaluation, the patient receives a diagnosis of dementia pugilistica. Which of the following statements accurately describes dementia pugilistica?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - All of the above:

Dementia pugilistica

  • Dementia pugilistica is a form of chronic traumatic encephalopathy.
  • It is seen in athletes who participate in martial arts, boxing, wrestling, etc.
  • Concussive or sub-concussive blows cause it. Repeated blows to the head of the athlete over an entire career span of the boxer can lead to cortical damage and Parkinson-like features (e.g. Muhammad Ali, the greatest boxer of all time, suffered from dementia pugilistica).
  • The exact mechanism of neuronal injury is unknown but can be associated with loss of neurons, scarring of brain tissue, senile plaques, diffuse axonal injury, damage to the cerebellum etc.
  • Symptoms present over a latent period and include:
    • Personality and social instability.
    • Progressively declining cognitive ability (dementia).
    • Parkinsonism.
    • Short-term memory loss.
    • Physical tremors.
    • Loss of physical coordination.
    • Difficulty in speech.
    • Changes in gait.
    • Paranoia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Seen in boxers: Dementia pugilistica is common in athletes who play sports like wrestling, boxing and martial arts.

Option B - Difficulty in gait: Gait disturbances are common in dementia pugilistica.

Option C - Decreased cognition: Decreased cognition and memory are present in dementia pugilistica.

questions.text: In a 40-year-old female patient, there is a presentation of abdominal pain, diarrhea, anorexia, and weight loss. Laboratory investigations reveal a significantly elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Abdominal ultrasound imaging displays a "Club Sandwich" appearance of the bowel walls.What type of ulcer is observed in this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Transverse ulcers:

  • Intestinal tuberculosis occurs as a result of drinking contaminated milk
  • It is a complication of protracted advanced secondary tuberculosis, secondary to swallowing coughed-up infective material.
  • Organisms are trapped in mucosal lymphoid aggregates of the small and large intestines. Resulting in inflammatory enlargement with ulceration of the overlying mucosa in the ileum.
  • Multiple transverse small intestinal ulcers with undermined edges can be seen.
  • An abdominal ultrasound shows a “Club Sandwich appearance of bowel walls”.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Longitudinal ulcers: Longitudinal ulcers are seen in Typhoid or enteric fever.

Option C - Punched out ulcers: Punched-out ulcers are seen in herpes simplex esophagitis.

Option D - None of the above: Multiple transverse small intestinal ulcers with undermined edges can be seen in intestinal tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 26 years old female with 12 weeks of amenorrhea presents with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the cervical os is open and the uterus is of 14 weeks in size. USG shows a snowstorm appearance. The next best step in the management is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Suction and evacuation:

  • The clinical presentation with vaginal bleeding, an open cervical os, a uterus larger than expected for gestational age, and the ultrasound findings of a snowstorm appearance are highly suggestive of a complete or partial molar pregnancy. The next best step in management is suction and evacuation (also known as dilatation and curettage) to remove the molar tissue.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Medical management:

  • Medical management is not appropriate in the case of a molar pregnancy. Molar pregnancies require the complete removal of the abnormal tissue.

Option C- Follow up with beta-hCG:

  • While beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-HCG) levels are used to monitor the response to treatment in molar pregnancies, the immediate management in this scenario is to evacuate the uterus due to the risk of complications associated with molar pregnancies.

Option D- Hysterectomy:

  • Hysterectomy is not the initial management for a molar pregnancy. Conservative management with suction and evacuation is the preferred approach unless there are specific indications for hysterectomy.

questions.text: Neonatal deaths account for a large proportion of child deaths. Which of the following is the most common cause of Neonatal mortality in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Low birth weight and prematurity:

  • The most common cause of neonatal mortality in India is low birth weight and prematurity (Preterm birth).
  • Neonatal death is deaths occurring during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending 28 days completed after birth.
  • The neonatal mortality rate (NNMR) is the number of neonatal deaths in a given year per 1000 live births in that year.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Congenital malformations:

  • The congenital malformation accounts for about 15-16% neonatal mortality rate in India.
  • It is not the common cause of neonatal mortality in India.

Option B - Tetanus:

  • Neonatal tetanus is the preventable cause of neonatal mortality.
  • It is not the most common cause of neonatal mortality.
  • India declared neonatal tetanus free status by July 2016.

Option D - Diarrhea:

  • Diarrhea is not the most common cause of neonatal mortality in India.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath that has been ongoing for the past two hours. Upon examination, her vital signs are as follows: a temperature of 100°F, blood pressure of 130/90 mmHg, a pulse rate of 96 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Her oxygen saturation is 92% at room temperature. She is administered oxygen inhalation. Subsequent evaluation reveals a positive result for COVID-19 on PCR testing. Further laboratory investigations are ordered.

Upon reviewing her complete blood count (CBC), it is noted that she has leukopenia, low platelet counts, and reduced fibrinogen levels. Additionally, her peripheral blood smear reveals the presence of schistocytes. Schistocytes are associated with which of the following medical conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - DIC:

  • The case mentioned above has clinical features and investigation finding suggestive of covid-19 leading to disseminated intravascular coagulation.
  • Schistocytes are seen in DIC.
  • In DIC, the processes of coagulation and fibrinolysis are dysregulated, and the result is widespread clotting with resultant bleeding. Regardless of the triggering event of DIC, once initiated, the pathophysiology of DIC is similar in all conditions.
  • Causes of DIC sepsis trauma obstetric complications, e.g., amniotic fluid embolism or hemolysis, elevated liver function tests, and low platelets (HELLP syndrome) malignancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sickle cell disease:

  • It is an inherited disease associated with sickled RBCs.
  • Sickle-cell anaemia is an autosomal recessive condition that results in the synthesis of an abnormal haemoglobin chain termed HbS.
  • Target cells are a characteristic feature of sickle cell anaemia, not Schistocytes.

Option C - Hereditary Spherocytosis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis is the most common hereditary haemolytic anaemia in people of northern European descent.
  • It is an autosomal dominant defect of the red blood cell cytoskeleton.
  • The normal biconcave disc shape is replaced by a sphere-shaped red blood cell (spherocytes).

Option D - G6PD:

  • Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is an enzyme in the hexose monophosphate shunt that reduces nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NAPD) to NADPH.
  • G6PD deficiency is an X-linked disorder.
  • Spherocytes are seen in this disease, not schistocytes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the hematology clinic with a history of persistent fatigue, easy bruising, and recurrent infections over the past few months. On examination, he has pallor and petechiae. A complete blood count (CBC) reveals severe pancytopenia with marked dysplasia in all cell lineages, including hypolobated neutrophils and nuclear blebbing in erythroid precursors. The peripheral blood smear also shows abnormal cell morphology. A bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis of Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS).Which genetic abnormality is most commonly associated with the development of MDS?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Deletion of chromosome 5q:

  • Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS) is a heterogeneous group of hematological disorders characterized by ineffective hematopoiesis, dysplasia in one or more cell lineages, and an increased risk of progression to acute leukemia.
  • Various cytogenetic abnormalities are associated with MDS. One of the most common genetic abnormalities observed in MDS is the deletion of a portion of chromosome 5, referred to as del(5q).
  • Patients with del(5q) MDS often have distinct clinical and hematological features, including macrocytic anemia, thrombocytosis, and a favorable response to treatment with lenalidomide, making it an important diagnostic and prognostic marker in MDS.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Trisomy 21:

  • Down syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21 (trisomy 21).
  • While individuals with Down syndrome have an increased risk of developing hematological disorders, such as acute leukemia, MDS is not a typical manifestation of Down syndrome. Down syndrome is more commonly associated with acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AMKL).

Option B - T(9;22) translocation :

  • The T(9;22) translocation, also known as the Philadelphia chromosome, is most commonly associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and a subset of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
  • MDS is generally not associated with the Philadelphia chromosome. It has a distinct genetic and clinical profile.

Option D - Trisomy 18:

  • Trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome, is a chromosomal disorder characterized by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 18.
  • Edwards syndrome is not typically associated with MDS. It presents with a different set of clinical features, including severe developmental and structural abnormalities, and is not primarily a hematological disorder.

questions.text:
Please match the following colors of STI kits with their corresponding use:


	
		
			A. Lower abdominal pain
			1. Grey, Kit 1
		
		
			B. Urethral discharge
			2. Green, Kit 2
		
		
			C. Non herpetic genital ulcer
			3. White, Kit 3
		
		
			D. Vaginal discharge
			4. Yellow, Kit 6
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2:

 

A. Lower abdominal pain Yellow, Kit 6
B. Urethral discharge Grey, Kit 1
C. Non herpetic genital ulcer White, Kit 3
D. Vaginal discharge Green, Kit 2

Incorrect Options:

Option A, D and C are incorrect.

questions.text: A 27-year-old Female presents to the OPD with complaints of fever and lower abdominal pain. On per vaginal examination, there is Cervical motion and uterine tenderness present. What is the next best management for this patient?

choices.text: Ceftriaxone 1 g IV once, followed by doxycycline and metronidazole orally twice daily for 7 days
Single IM injection of ceftriaxone 250 mg with oral metronidazole and doxycycline for 14 days
Single IM Injection Ceftriaxone 500 mg, followed by oral metronidazole 400 mg for 7 days
Ceftriaxone 1 g IV once, followed by doxycycline 100 mg orally and metronidazole 500 mg orally twice daily for 14 days

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Single IM Injection of Ceftriaxone 500 mg, followed by doxycycline and metronidazole orally twice daily for 14 days:

  • This option provides the appropriate treatment for PID, which typically involves a combination of antibiotics to cover common causative organisms. Here's why this option is correct:

    • Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM: This covers potential gonorrhea, a common pathogen associated with PID.
    • Oral metronidazole: This covers anaerobic bacteria often implicated in PID.
    • Doxycycline for 14 days: This covers chlamydia, another common cause of PID.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Ceftriaxone 1 g IV once, followed by doxycycline and metronidazole orally twice daily for 7 days:

  • The duration of doxycycline and metronidazole treatment is only 7 days, which is not in line with the recommended 14-day treatment course for PID.
  • The dose of ceftriaxone is higher than the standard dose used for PID (1 g IV vs. 250 mg IM).

Option C- Single IM Injection of Ceftriaxone 500 mg, followed by oral metronidazole 400 mg for 7 days

  • The dose of ceftriaxone is higher than the standard dose used for PID (500 mg IM vs. 250 mg IM).
  • The duration of metronidazole treatment is only 7 days, which is not in line with the recommended 14-day treatment course for PID.
  • It does not include doxycycline, which is necessary for coverage against chlamydia, a common cause of PID.

Option D-Ceftriaxone 1 g IV once, followed by doxycycline 100 mg orally and metronidazole 500 mg orally twice daily for 14 days:

  • The dose of ceftriaxone is higher than the standard dose used for PID (1 g IV vs. 250 mg IM).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with G2P1 arrives in active labor pain during the 39th week of her pregnancy. Within thirty minutes of her arrival, she successfully delivers a healthy baby girl. Which is the component of the active management of the third stage of labor?

choices.text: Placenta is delivered by gravity and maternal effort

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ergometrine after anterior shoulder delivery:

  • Ergometrine is an ergot alkaloid.
  • It produces sustained tonic uterine contraction via agonist or partial agonist effects at myometrial 5-HT2 and alpha-adrenergic receptors.
  • Ergometrine or oxytocin is given in active management of the third stage of labour to minimise the risk of postpartum haemorrhage.

The third stage of labour: The time from the delivery of the infant until delivery of the maternal placenta.

ACTIVE MANAGEMENT OF THIRD STAGE OF LABOUR:

Two methods of management of the third stage of labour are as follows:

  • Physiologic ("expectant") management
    • Oxytocics are not used
    • Placenta is delivered by gravity and maternal effort
    • Cord is clamped after delivery of the placenta
  • Active Management
    • Oxytocic is given
    • Cord is clamped
    • Placenta delivered by controlled cord traction (CCT) with counter-traction on the fundus
    • Fundal massage

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Delayed umbilical cord clamping:

  • The umbilical cord is clamped early in active management while delayed in expectant management of the third stage of labour.

Option C - Placenta is delivered by gravity and maternal effort:

  • The placenta is delivered by controlled cord traction with counter-traction on the fundus.
  • Controlled cord traction (CCT) is traction applied to the umbilical cord after the uterus contracts following the birth of the baby; the placenta is felt to confirm its separation from the uterine wall, while counter-pressure is applied to the uterus until the placenta delivers.

Option D - Oxytocin is not used:

  • Oxytocin or ergotamine, or a combination of both, is used in the active management of the third stage of labour.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male pilot presents with dizziness, palpitations, and hematuria following recent primaquine chemoprophylaxis for Plasmodium vivax malaria. He exhibits signs of pallor and jaundice on examination. Laboratory tests reveal anemia with hemoglobinuria. What specific abnormality is likely to be identified through further specialized studies in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- G6PD:

  • This is the case of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, in which the patient presents with a history of dizziness, palpitations, and hematuria for four days after receiving primaquine chemoprophylaxis. Physical examination reveals signs of pallor and jaundice.
  • The signs and symptoms indicate an ongoing haemolytic crisis due to oxidative stress caused by the antimalarial drug primaquine.
  • Investigation results reveal anaemia with hemoglobinuria, which further establishes the diagnosis.
  • Special investigations include the fluorescent spot test for the screening of individuals with a family history and spectrophotometric assay of GPD activity for the confirmation of diagnosis.
  • G6PD deficiency due to genetic mutations results in reduced glutathione activity of antioxidation which leads to RBCs being more susceptible to damage when triggered by oxidative stress. This results in denatured haemoglobin and intravascular haemolysis.
  • Conditions resulting in oxidative stress are infections like pneumonia, sepsis, antimalarial drugs, antituberculosis drugs, sulfonamides, aspirin, nitrofurantoin, and some foods like fava beans.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Duffy antigen:

  • This antigen is a glycoprotein in humans found on the surface of RBCs that can function as a receptor for plasmodium vivax, resulting in the invasion of red blood cells and malaria.
  • Those individuals who are Duffy-negative do not express the receptor and are, thus, resistant to plasmodium vivax. However, it is not associated with haemolytic anaemia or G6PD deficiency.

Option C- Intrinsic factor:

  • IF is a glycoprotein produced by the parietal cells of the gastric mucosa and has an important role in the absorption of vitamin B12 by the terminal ileum.
  • Intrinsic factor deficiency results in pernicious anaemia and neurological manifestations.

Option D- PIGA:

  • Mutations of the PIGA gene result in intracorpuscular haemolytic anaemia, pancytopenia, and thrombocytopenia in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.
  • It is confirmed by flow cytometry which detects the absence of CD55 and CD59 glycoproteins encoded by the PIGA gene in PNH.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient arrives with a chief complaint of sudden onset of breathlessness following a fall from a ladder. Upon conducting a physical examination, the attending physician suspects the presence of a tension pneumothorax (TE) and promptly performs needle aspiration. Which of the following characteristics is NOT typically associated with tension pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Respiratory alkalosis:

  • A tension pneumothorax is a serious condition caused by trapped air in the pleural space under positive pressure, displacing mediastinal structures and impairing cardiovascular function.
  • Early detection of this problem can save lives outside the hospital and in contemporary intensive care units.
  • Pneumothorax caused by trauma or tension are more prevalent than spontaneous pneumothorax.
  • The most prevalent causes of iatrogenic pneumothorax are chest trauma, transthoracic needle aspiration and central venous catheters.
  • Communication between the pleural space and the lung occurs during a pneumothorax, resulting in air passage from the lung into the pleural space. It eliminates the pressure gradient that is normally present, resulting in a gradual rise in intrapleural pressure. This increase in pressure compresses the lung and reduces its capacity.
  • In extreme situations, the increased pressure might compress the heart, contralateral lung, and vascular, resulting in hemodynamic instability. It is attributed to decreased venous return and poor heart filling.
  • As a result, hypoxia, acidosis, and reduced cardiac output can result in cardiogenic shock and, eventually, death.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Decreased cardiac output:

  • The increasing accumulation of air in the pleural space results in ipsilateral full lung collapse and impingement on the mediastinum, with the heart shifting to the uninvolved side.
  • It reduces cardiac output by restricting ventricular filling.

Option C- Decreased venous return:

  • Hemodynamic instability can result from increased pressure compressing the vasculature, the opposing lung, and the heart.
  • It is attributed to decreased venous return and poor heart filling. Along with these effects, hypoxemia causes pulmonary vasoconstriction and raises pulmonary vascular resistance.

Option D- Absent breath sounds:

  • It is crucial to look for indicators of respiratory distress during an examination, such as an accelerated breathing rate, dyspnea, and retractions.
  • Pneumothorax is indicated by diminished or missing breath sounds on the ipsilateral side, decreased tactile fremitus, hyper-resonant percussion sounds, and potential asymmetrical lung expansion on lung auscultation.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old male patient seeks medical attention, reporting a recent onset of "difficulty in seeing" that has persisted for the past three days. He notes a change in his vision following an incident of eye trauma. The patient has a history of heavy smoking and alcohol consumption. On examination, the patient's vital signs are stable, except for mild hypertension with a blood pressure reading of 154/87 mmHg. The patient demonstrates full extraocular motility in both eyes and exhibits normal red reflexes. The image below depicts the pupillary light reflex of this patient:



Which of the following options is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Robert Marcus Gunn pupil:

  • This patient with difficulty seeing after trauma is most likely suffering from Marcus Gunn's pupil, characterized by a unilateral afferent pupillary defect.
  • It is abbreviated as RAPD. If a flashlight is swung back and forth between the two eyes (swinging flashlight test), the eye with the afferent pupillary defect appears to dilate in response to illumination.
  • This happens because the pupil constricts in response to illumination of the contralateral eye (an intact indirect pupillary reflex) but fails to constrict with the illumination of the affected eye (impaired direct pupillary reflex).
  • This phenomenon does not occur with bilateral afferent pupillary defects.
  • The causes include retinal detachment, retinal ischemia, optic neuritis, severe glaucoma, trauma (as seen in this patient), and an optic nerve tumour.
  • The diagnostic work-up includes perimetry, fundoscopy, CT, and MRI scans of the orbit and brain to evaluate the cause.
  • The treatment is aimed at rectifying the underlying cause.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Argyll Robertson pupil:

  • It manifests as bilateral miosis and light-near dissociation resulting from a dorsal midbrain lesion, which selectively damages the fibres that control the pupillary reflex but spares the more ventral fibres that control the accommodation reflex.
  • These features are not present in this patient so that we can exclude this option. Further, it is commonly caused by syphilis and diabetes mellitus.

Option C - Adie's pupil:

  • Adie's pupil is characterized by light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage. This disorder results in poor light but better and tonic near constriction. However, this vignette is about RAPD, so we can also rule out this option.

Option D - Horner's syndrome pupil:

  • The key sign of Horner is a decreased size of the eye pupil. It is caused by disrupting a sympathetic nerve pathway from the brain to the head and neck.
  • However, Horner syndrome is a condition that also affects the face and eyes on one side of the body. These features are not present in this patient, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: In the emergency department, a 26-year-old male patient seeks medical attention after sustaining a gunshot wound to the chest. His initial blood pressure is recorded at 92/68 mmHg. Upon examination, the patient presents with pallor and cold extremities. A chest X-ray confirms the presence of a left hemothorax. In response to this critical condition, the consulting physician orders the transfusion of two units of red blood cells. However, immediately following the transfusion, the patient develops a high-grade fever, experiences chills, complains of right flank pain, and exhibits bleeding from the venipuncture sites. What can be observed in cases of mismatched blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Hemoglobinuria:

  • Acute hemolytic reactions are usually caused by pre-formed IgM antibodies against red donor cells that fix complement.
  • Most commonly stem from an error in patient identification or tube labelling that allows a patient to receive an ABO-incompatible unit of blood.
  • Pre-existing high affinity "natural" IgM antibodies, usually against polysaccharide blood group antigens A or B, bind to red cells and rapidly induce complement-mediated lysis, intravascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria.
  • Fever, shaking chills, and flank pain appear rapidly. The direct Coombs test is typically positive unless all of the donor red cells have lysed.
  • The signs and symptoms are due to complement activation rather than intravascular hemolysis per se, as osmotic lysis of red cells (e.g., by mistakenly infusing red cells and 5% dextrose in water simultaneously) produces hemoglobinuria without any of the other symptoms of a hemolytic reaction.
  • In severe cases, the process may rapidly progress to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), shock, acute renal failure, and occasionally death.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Elevated plasma haptoglobin level:

  • Haptoglobin is the protein that in blood plasma binds with high affinity to free haemoglobin released from erythrocytes and thereby inhibits its deleterious oxidative activity.
  • The haptoglobin-haemoglobin complex will then be removed by the reticuloendothelial system.
  • In hemolysis, free haemoglobin is released into plasma by red blood cells lysis and is bound by haptoglobin to form a complex.
  • Therefore, plasma haptoglobin is reduced in hemolysis.

Option B- Negative direct antiglobulin test (DAT):

  • Direct antiglobulin test (DAT) is also called Direct Coomb's test.
  • Direct Coomb's test detects antibodies attached directly to the RBC surface
  • In mismatch transfusion recipient's antibodies bind to the donor's red blood cells causing lysis, and are measured as positive Coomb's test.

Option D- Decreased serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level:

  • LDH is present in the blood, and hemolysis causes the release of LDH in plasma.
  • Thus, serum LDH levels are increased in hemolysis

questions.text:
During a routine check-up, a 5-month-old boy, born at 37 weeks gestation to a mother who did not receive prenatal care, presents to the physician. The patient's 5-year-old sister has a history of osteosarcoma. The infant is exclusively breastfed. His vital signs are within normal limits. Upon examination, an inward deviation of the left eye is noted. Penlight examination reveals a white reflex in the left eye and a red reflex in the right eye.

What differentiating feature distinguishes the pathology of this patient from Coat's disease?

choices.text: Presence of retinal exudations in Coat’s disease
Males are affected less by Coats disease

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Presence of retinal exudations in Coat’s disease:

  • This is a case of Retinoblastoma in which a 5-month-old boy presents to the physician for a routine check-up.
  • On examination of the patient, there is an inward deviation of the left eye.
  • The patient's provisional diagnosis is Retinoblastoma.
  • Retinal exudations are present in coat's disease and absent in Retinoblastoma.

Coats disease:

  • Type of telangiectasia.
  • A d/d of unilateral leukocoria in the first decade.
  • More frequently in males.
  • Yellowish exudates around the vessels are seen.
  • Neovascularization can be seen.
  • Association with Turner syndrome seen.
  • It can cause retinal detachment. Elevated lesions are generally not present in contrast to Retinoblastoma.
  • Staging Gomez Morales & Siegelman staging (do not need to go into details)

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Leukocoria:

  • Leukocoria is characteristic of retinoblastomas.
  • It happens less likely in coats disease.

Option B- Male preponderance in RB:

  • Retinoblastoma incidence is the same in both males and females.
  • With slightly male preponderance.

Option D- Males are affected less by Coats disease:

  • Coats disease happens more frequently in males than females.
  • Unlike RB, in which male: female coincidence is the same.

questions.text: In the context of prosthetic eyes, a prosthesis is a device used to improve the appearance of individuals who have lost an eye due to injury or disease. This device is often colloquially referred to as a "glass eye" or "fake eye." It is essentially a shell that covers the structures within the eye socket. Which of the following conditions is not included as a suitable reason for utilizing this type of prosthesis shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Perforated Fungal corneal ulcer:

  • The image in the question is of a Boston Keratoprosthesis. Perforated corneal ulcer as a primary procedure requires penetrating keratoplasty and control of fungal infection so it is not a suitable indicaation.
  • A fungal corneal ulcer, or fungal keratitis, is an infection of the corneal stroma that can cause rapid vision loss and pain. Infectious corneal ulcers need to be treated as soon as possible to preserve vision. If left untreated, a fungal infection can lead to perforation of the cornea, loss of vision, and even loss of the eye.
  • Risk factors that can predispose to fungal keratitis include contact lens wear, eye trauma with the vegetative matter, previous ocular surgery, topical steroid use, and immunosuppression.
  • Patients with a fungal corneal ulcer will complain of eye pain, light sensitivity, red eyes, and possibly reduced vision. The rapidity of the onset and progression of symptoms is typically slower than what is seen in bacterial keratitis.
  • Fungal keratitis is much less common than bacterial keratitis, and the diagnosis is often made once traditional antibacterial medications fail to successfully treat an infection.
  • Indication of prosthesis: Autoimmune ocular disorders - SJS, OCP (Stage 3 or 4), TEN, Epidermolysis bullosa.

Incorrect Options:

Option B – OCP:

  • OCP (Ocular Cicatricial Pemphigoid) is considered a subtype of Mucous Membrane Pemphigoid (abbreviated MMP), and these terms are sometimes used interchangeably.
  • OCP is a type of autoimmune conjunctivitis that leads to cicatrization (i.e. scarring) of the conjunctiva. If OCP is left untreated, it can lead to blindness.

Option C - Multiple failed Penetrating Keratoplasties:

  • Graft failure - most common indication - multiple failed keratoplasties.
  • Penetrating keratoplasty (PKP), also referred to as a corneal transplant or corneal graft, is the surgical removal of a damaged or diseased portion of the cornea, followed by the implantation of healthy tissue from a donated human cornea, which is usually obtained from an eye bank.

Option D - Epidermolysis Bullosa Acquisita:

  • Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita (EBA) is an acquired, autoimmune subepidermal blistering disease with an approximate prevalence of 0,2/million people. The hallmark of EBA is the presence of autoantibodies (mainly IgG class) to anchoring fibril collagen (type VII collagen) located at the dermal-epidermal junction.

questions.text: In the context of immunology, the primary mechanism employed to defend against pathogen entry entails intricate interactions among various immune cell types, including T cells, B cells, and cells of the innate immune system. An illustration of one such interaction is provided below. Keeping immunological principles in mind, which of the following characteristics is the least likely to be associated with the depicted structure?

choices.text: Chromosome six has the genes for MHC
Genes encoding complement proteins are located adjacent to class I
Monocytes have MHC II antigens on their surface
Class III does not encode complement

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Class III does not encode complement:

  • Class III MHC code for the complement system

Class III MHC proteins:

  • MHC class III is a group of proteins belonging to the major histocompatibility complex class (MHC).
  • Unlike other MHC types, such as MHC class I and MHC class II, whose structure and functions in the immune response are well defined, MHC class III are poorly defined structurally and functionally.
  • They are not involved in antigen binding (the process called antigen presentation, a classic function of MHC proteins).
  • Few are involved in immunity, while many are signalling molecules in other cell communications.
  • They are mainly known from their genes because their gene cluster is between those of class I and II.
  • The gene cluster was discovered when genes (specifically those of complement components C2, C4, and factor B) were found between class I and II genes on the short (p) arm of human chromosome 6.
  • It was later found that it contains many genes for different signalling molecules, such as tumour necrosis factors (TNFs) and heat shock proteins.
  • More than 60 MHC class III genes are described, about 28% of the total MHC genes.
  • The region within the MHC class III gene cluster that contains genes for TNFs is also known as MHC class IV or inflammatory region.
  • In contrast to other MHC proteins, MHC class III proteins are produced by liver cells (hepatocytes) and special white blood cells (macrophages)

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Chromosome six has the genes for MHC:

  • The genes for the major histocompatibility complex are present on chromosome 6.
  • They are specifically located on the short arm of this chromosome.

Option B - Genes encoding complement proteins are located adjacent to class I:

  • The genes for the complement system are present close to the genes of MHC class I.
  • While the genes for the MHC III are clustered among other types of MHC protein.

Option C - Monocytes have MHC II antigens on their surface:

  • MHC Class II molecules are a class of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules normally found only on professional antigen-presenting cells such as dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes, some endothelial cells, thymic epithelial cells, and B cells.

questions.text: A community medicine intern was given a case of Acrodermatitis enteropathica and was asked to explain its features. Which of the following is the correct statement regarding this condition?

choices.text: Inherited disorder of excessive excretion of zinc from body
Inherited disorder of impaired uptake of zinc from body
Inherited disorder of impaired excretion of copper from body
Inherited disorder of impaired uptake of copper from body

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Inherited disorder of impaired uptake of zinc from body:

  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an Inherited disorder of impaired uptake of zinc from the body. It results from mutations in the zinc transporter gene SLC39A4, leading to improper enteral zinc absorption.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Inherited disorder of excessive excretion of zinc from body:

  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an Inherited disorder of impaired Absorption of zinc from the body.

Option C - Inherited disorder of impaired excretion of copper from body: 

  • Wilson disease is due to impaired excretion of copper, which can lead to the accumulation of copper in the body, not Acrodermatitis enteropathica.

Option D - Inherited disorder of impaired uptake of copper from body:

  • Menke's disease is an inherited disorder affecting the absorption of copper, not Acrodermatitis enteropathica.

questions.text: A patient presented with endometrium carcinoma involving > 50 %  myometrium, with the involvement of pelvic lymph nodes. Which of the following stage best describe in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - IIIC1:

  • In the FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) staging system for endometrial carcinoma:
    • Stage IIIC1 indicates the involvement of pelvic lymph nodes. In this case, the patient has endometrial carcinoma with > 50% myometrial invasion and pelvic lymph node involvement.
    • The "C" in the stage denotes lymph node involvement, and "1" specifies pelvic lymph nodes.
    • Therefore, IIIC1 accurately describes the patient's condition, as she has both significant myometrial invasion and pelvic lymph node metastasis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IIIC2:

  • This stage would indicate para-aortic lymph node metastasis in addition to other conditions, such as myometrial invasion and pelvic lymph node involvement. However, the patient's case doesn't mention para-aortic lymph node involvement.

Option B - IIIB2:

  • Stage IIIB typically involves serosal invasion or adnexal involvement, but it does not specifically mention lymph node involvement. The patient's case mentions pelvic lymph node involvement, which is not covered by this stage.

Option C - IIIB1:

  • This stage would involve serosal invasion or adnexal involvement, but it does not include lymph node involvement. The patient's presentation specifically mentions pelvic lymph node involvement, making this stage inappropriate for her case.

questions.text: The significant influence of the high-fat diet prevalent among North Americans on the occurrence of cardiovascular disease, one key factor of interest is the role of specific fatty acids. Which of the following fatty acids is considered cardioprotective?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Omega-3 fatty acids:

  • Omega-3 fatty acids reduce the incidence of Coronary Heart Diseases.
    • Omega 3 fatty acid decreases platelet aggregation.
    • It also decreases inflammation.
  • Fish oils are an excellent dietary source of omega-3 fatty acids.
  • Example:
    • Alpha-linolenic acid
    • Timnodonic acid
    • Cervonic acid

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Palmitic acid:

  • Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid.
  • It is not a cardio-protective fatty acid.

Option B - Stearic acid:

  • Stearic acid is a saturated fatty acid.
  • It is not a cardio-protective fatty acid.

Option D - Oleic acid:

  • Oleic acid is a Monounsaturated Fatty acid.
  • The richest source of which is mustard oil.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient is admitted to the hospital with acute confusion and fluctuating attention. The healthcare team suspects delirium. Which neurotransmitter abnormality is most likely responsible for the cognitive impairment observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Decreased Acetylcholine levels, impairing cognitive function:

  • Delirium, a common condition in elderly patients, is often characterized by a deficiency in acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter critical for cognitive processes. This deficiency leads to the cognitive impairments seen in delirium, including confusion and fluctuating attention.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Decreased Acetylcholine levels: Elevated dopamine levels are more associated with psychosis.

Option C - Elevated Serotonin levels: Serotonin imbalances are linked to mood disorders.

Option D - Reduced GABA (Gamma-Aminobutyric Acid) levels: GABA primarily plays a role in inhibitory neurotransmission and is not the primary culprit in delirium.

questions.text: Malnutrition refers to deficiencies, excesses, or imbalances in a person's intake of energy and/or nutrients. Which of the following correctly defines Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in India?

choices.text: Very low weight for age (below –3 Z scores of the mean WHO standards for growth), or the presence of nutritional edema
Very low weight for age (below –3 Z scores of the mean WHO standards for growth) only
Visible severe wasting, or presence of nutritional edema
Very low weight for height below –3 Z scores of the mean WHO standards for growth, or by visible severe wasting, or presence of nutritional edema

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Very low weight for height below –3 Z scores of the mean WHO standards for growth, or by visible severe wasting, or presence of nutritional edema:

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM):

1. Weight-for-height/length (Z- score below –3SD of the median WHO child growth standards).

2. Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm.

3. Presence of nutritional edema.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Very low weight for age (below –3 Z scores of the mean WHO standards for growth), or the presence of nutritional edema: Very low weight for age (below –3 Z scores of the mean WHO standards for growth), or the presence of nutritional edema and visible severe wasting also defines Severe acute malnutrition.

Option B - Very low weight for age (below –3 Z scores of the mean WHO standards for growth) only: Very low weight for age (below –3 Z scores of the mean WHO standards for growth), visible severe wasting, and the presence of nutritional edema define Severe acute malnutrition.

Option C - Visible severe wasting, or presence of nutritional edema: In addition to visible severe wasting, or the presence of nutritional edema, Very low weight for age (below –3 Z scores of the mean WHO standards for growth) also defines Severe acute malnutrition.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman diagnosed with bipolar disorder has been on lithium therapy for the past six months. She presents to the clinic with persistent nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Upon examination, her blood pressure is 148/92 mmHg, heart rate is 80 bpm, and she appears slightly confused. Laboratory tests reveal elevated lithium levels. Which of the following gastrointestinal symptoms is most commonly associated with lithium toxicity?

choices.text: Loss of Appetite and Weight Gain

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Nausea, Vomiting, and Diarrhea:

  • Gastrointestinal symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, are common signs of lithium toxicity. These symptoms can occur due to the direct irritant effect of lithium on the gastrointestinal tract and are important indicators of potential lithium toxicity, especially when coupled with confusion and elevated blood pressure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Constipation and Abdominal Pain: Constipation and abdominal pain are not typical symptoms of lithium toxicity. Instead, gastrointestinal symptoms in lithium toxicity tend to involve increased motility, leading to nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

Option C - Loss of Appetite and Weight Gain: While loss of appetite can be a symptom of lithium toxicity, weight gain is more associated with the long-term use of some psychiatric medications but not directly indicative of lithium toxicity.

Option D - Excessive Flatulence and Bloating: Excessive flatulence and bloating are not characteristic symptoms of lithium toxicity. Gastrointestinal symptoms in lithium toxicity tend to involve the upper gastrointestinal tract, resulting in nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

questions.text:
A 1-year-old male infant is presented to the emergency department by his parents due to concerns of abdominal distention. The parents additionally report observing blood in the baby's stool. Following a thorough physical examination, an X-ray is performed, revealing the following findings:



Which of the following findings are indicated in the Abdominal X-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Coiled spring sign:

  • The above-shown picture depicts a coiled spring sign, and the most likely cause is intussusception.
  • Children with classic findings of intussusception need to be investigated with an enema, which is both diagnostic (the gold standard in the diagnosis of intussusception) and therapeutic.
  • On Barium enema:
    • Claw sign
    • Coiled spring sign

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Meniscus sign:

  • A highly specific radiographic roentgen finding for intussusception is called the meniscus sign (or crescent sign).
  • This is crescent shaped-gas in the bowel lumen (intussuscipiens) that surrounds the apex of the intussusceptum (invaginated segment), creating a well-demarcated soft tissue/gas interface

Option B - Pseudo kidney sign:

  • The pseudo kidney sign is a characteristic ultrasound appearance in some cases of intestinal intussusception.
  • It refers to the longitudinal ultrasound appearance of the intussuscepted bowel segment, mimicking a kidney.

Option D - Target sign:

  • A target sign is classically defined as a CT image associated with the thickening of the intestinal wall. A lower attenuated middle layer is surrounded on each side by layers of higher attenuation.
  • The diagnosis of a small bowel target sign most commonly correlates with intussusception.

questions.text: Identify the image shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Laparoscopic Myoma Screw:

  • The laparoscopic Myomectomy screw is similar to the myomectomy screw used in open myomectomy.
  • The 'Screw' is inserted into the fibroid specimen to provide traction, which helps dissection around the fibroid to release it from the muscular grip of the uterine walls.
  • The laparoscopic Myomectomy Screw is shown below:

  • The myomectomy screw used for Open Myomectomy is shown below:

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Myoma Morcellator:

  • This device is commonly used in laparoscopic hysterectomy and myomectomy for piecemeal extraction of specimen through small ports.

  • The picture mentioned above shows the myoma morcellator

Option C - Myomectomy clamp:

  • This device is used for clamping the vascular bundles during myomectomy for temporarily devascularizing the uterus to reduce blood loss during surgery.
  • The commonly used one is a Bonney's clamp as shown below.

Option D - Bonney’s elevator/ myomectomy clamp:

  • Below is the picture of Bonney’s elevator.

questions.text: n neuronal synaptic transmission, which of the following proteins is crucial for vesicle fusion and neurotransmitter release?
questions.solution:
Correct Option 

D) All of the above

Explanation:

A) VAMP (Vesicle-Associated Membrane Protein): VAMP, also known as synaptobrevin, is a protein found on synaptic vesicles. It interacts with the proteins syntaxin and SNAP-25 to facilitate vesicle fusion with the presynaptic membrane.

B) Syntaxin: Syntaxin is a membrane protein located on the presynaptic plasma membrane. It forms a complex with VAMP and SNAP-25, enabling the docking and fusion of synaptic vesicles with the presynaptic membrane.

C) SNAP-25 (Synaptosomal-Associated Protein 25): SNAP-25 is another protein present on the presynaptic plasma membrane. It participates in the formation of the SNARE complex, which is essential for vesicle fusion and the subsequent release of neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft.

questions.text: During a laparotomy procedure for the treatment of acute intestinal obstruction, a 32-year-old male patient is placed under general anesthesia. As part of the anesthesia monitoring, the anaesthesiologist utilizes a capnography machine to observe the waveform of expired carbon dioxide (CO2). One of the capnography waveforms is presented below. What is the most likely interpretation or indication conveyed by this specific capnography display?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Curare cleft:

  • Capnometry is the measurement of expired CO2 and is the confirmation method of choice in anaesthesia for the proper placement of an endotracheal tube.
  • Most CO2 monitors include a waveform known as a capnograph.
  • The shape of the normal waveform is illustrated below.

  • Phase 0: inspiratory phase.
  • Phase 1: It reflects the inspired gas, which is normally devoid of CO2. It is the dead space.
  • Phase 2 (expiratory upstroke): a mixture of alveolar and dead space gas.
  • Phase 3: alveolar plateau, with the peak representing end-expiratory (end-tidal) CO2.
  • Several situations can cause unusual waveforms. One of them is a curare cleft, as asked in this question above.
    • Curare cleft, or notch, is seen during spontaneous ventilation.
    • Patients who are primarily partially paralyzed with muscle relaxants may make respiratory efforts at any time during the respiratory cycle with controlled ventilation.
    • As the muscle relaxant is reversed, the curve becomes normal in shape.
  • The aperture is in the last third of the plateau. It is caused by a lack of synchronous action between the intercostal muscles and the diaphragm, most commonly caused by inadequate muscle relaxant reversal.
    • The depth of the aperture is proportional to the degree of muscle paralysis.
    • The position of the cleft is fairly constant in the same patient but is not necessarily present with every breath.
  • The notch is also seen in patients with transverse cervical lesions, flail chest, hiccups, pneumothorax, and when a patient tries to breathe during mechanical ventilation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bisferiens cleft:

  • It is also a biphasic pulse and aortic waveform with two peaks per cardiac cycle. The smaller peak is followed by a strong and broad one.
  • It is a sign of problems with the aorta, including aortic stenosis, aortic regurgitation and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy resulting in aortic stenosis.

Option B - Servo notch:

  • Servo motors, or "servos", as they are known, are electronic devices and rotatory or linear actuators that rotate and push parts of a machine with precision.
  • Servos are mainly used on angular or linear positions and for specific velocity and acceleration.
  • These motors are used in CNS machinery, robotics and automated manufacturing.

Option D - All of the above:

  • The diagram in the question above reveals a “curare cleft”, which is represented by a small dip in the alveolar plateau. It indicated a spontaneous respiratory effort during mechanical ventilation.
  • The other options do not explain this capnograph.

questions.text: In a 25-year-old patient with symptoms of sore throat, cough, hoarseness, and red eyes, a doctor diagnoses pharyngitis caused by a Streptococcus species. What property is associated with the C-carbohydrate of the Streptococcus ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lancefield classification:

  • C carbohydrate in Streptococcus pyogenes contributes to Lancefield classification.
  • β-Hemolytic Streptococci are classified by Lancefield serological classification into groups based on the nature of "C carbohydrate antigen:
  • Lancefield groups (A-V excluding I, J):
    • Group A: Streptococcus pyogenes
    • Group B: Streptococcus agalactiae
    • Group C: Streptococcus equisimilis
    • Group D and so on.
  • Streptococcus pyogenes is classified into serotypes by Griffith typing: Based on M protein. More than 100 serotypes are present.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Phagocytic inhibition:

  • C-Carbohydrate antigen doesn’t have any anti-phagocytic role.
  • Tyrosine phosphatase activation and suppression of myosin buildup at the site of phagocytic synapse diminish the interaction between macrophages and target cells, and CD47-SIRP interaction inhibits phagocytosis.

Option C - Toxin production:

  • C-Carbohydrate antigen doesn’t have any correlation with toxin production.
  • Bacterial toxins fall into the exotoxin or endotoxin categories. Endotoxins continue to be produced by the bacteria while exotoxins are released.

Option D – Hemolysis:

  • Based on hemolysis, Streptococci can be divided into 3 groups:
    • α Hemolytic: S. pneumoniae, S. viridians
    • β Hemolytic: Divided further on the basis of carbohydrate C antigen of cell wall into Lancefield groups (A-V excluding I, J). E.g., S. pyogenes
    • γ Hemolytic: Enterococcus

questions.text: Identify the specific nerve most likely being monitored based on the provided figure:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ulnar nerve:

  • In principle, any superficially located peripheral motor nerve may be stimulated.
  • In clinical anaesthesia, the ulnar nerve is the most popular site; the median, posterior tibial, common peroneal, and facial nerves are also sometimes used.
  • For stimulation of the ulnar nerve, the electrodes are best applied to the volar side of the wrist.
    • The distal electrode should be placed about 1 cm adjacent to the point at which the wrist's proximal flexion fold crosses the tendon's radial side to the flexor carpi ulnaris muscle.
    • The proximal electrode should preferably be placed so that the distance between the centres of the two electrodes is 3 to 6 cm.
    • With this placement of the electrodes, electrical stimulation normally elicits only finger flexion and thumb adduction.
    • If one electrode is placed over the ulnar groove at the elbow, thumb adduction is often pronounced because of the flexor carpi ulnaris muscle stimulation.
  • An electric current is applied to stimulate a nerve. The current is usually applied transcutaneously using ECG electrodes.
  • The degree of neuromuscular blockage is monitored by applying various electrical stimulation patterns. All stimuli are 200 µs in duration, have a square wave pattern, and have equal current intensity.
  • The diaphragm, rectus abdominis, laryngeal adductors, and orbicularis oculi muscles recover from neuromuscular blockage sooner than the adductor pollicis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Radial nerve:

  • The ulnar nerve is the preferred nerve for peripheral nerve stimulation. Other nerves are the facial, posterior tibial, and common peroneal nerves.

Option C - Median nerve:

  • The median nerve can be used for peripheral stimulation of the adductor pollicis and ulnar nerve. However, the ulnar nerve is the preferred nerve.

Option D - Palmar cutaneous branch:

  • The Palmar cutaneous branch is a branch of the median nerve. However, it is less frequently used for neuromuscular monitoring via peripheral nerve stimulation than the median nerve.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology department with a complaint of progressively worsening vision in his right eye. The patient denies any significant medical history or systemic diseases. Upon close examination, the ophthalmologist notices a discreet, dense corneal opacity precisely centered over the pupil of the right eye. The surrounding eye structures appear normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Trachoma:

  • Signs and Symptoms:
    • In trachoma, the tear's pH is acidic.
    • Conjunctival congestion is seen in the upper tarsal and forniceal conjunctiva, and papillary hyperplasia seen.
    • Hallmark: sago grain follicles.
    • Conjunctival scarring - Linear scar present in sulcus subtarsalis – Arlt's line.
    • Herbert's follicles - present at the limbus, Herbet's pits seen -oval/ circular pitted scars left after healing of Herbert's follicles.
    • Pannus: Progressive (infiltration of the cornea is ahead of vascularisation) or regressive.
    • Superficial keratitis and corneal opacity may be found.
    • Corneal scarring is the main cause of blindness in trachoma.
    • Trichiasis and cicatricial entropion may be seen.
  • WHO classification (FISTO):
    1. TF : Trachomatous inflammation - follicular
    2. TI : Trachomatous inflammation - Intense
    3. TS : Trachomatous Scarring
    4. TT : Trachomatous trichiasis
    5. CO : Corneal opacity
  • Serotypes
    • A,B,C- Hyperendemic Trachoma
    • D, K- Inclusion Trachoma
  • Treatment
    • DOC: 1gm Azithromycin Single Dose.
    • Other options: Doxycycline 100 mg BD 3-4 weeks.
    • Topical therapy: Tetracycline Ointment (1 %) or erythromycin (1%) four times a day for 6 weeks.
    • Combined topical and systemic therapy - Preferred when the ocular infection is severe (TI) or when there is associated genital infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Herpes keratitis:

  • The hallmark of HSV keratitis is the presence of multiple small branching epithelial dendrites on the surface of the cornea.
  • Acyclovir is given instead of azithromycin.

Option C - Pterygium:

  • The treatment used for the pterygium is the bare sclera technique.
  • Mitomycin can be used.

Option D – Cataract:

  • A surgical extraction is the treatment of choice for the cataract.
  • Moreover, lens opacity rather than corneal opacity is found in cataracts.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath and chest pain for the past hour. She had a hysterectomy for heavy menstrual bleeding two months ago but has no other comorbid. A CT pulmonary angiogram reveals a pulmonary embolism (PE) for which she’s started on heparin and tissue plasminogen activator. Five days after treatment, she develops painful clots in both legs. Her complete blood count is as follows:

White blood cells: 8,000/mm3, Haemoglobin: 11.2 g/dL, Platelet count: 38,000/mm3. Which treatments should be started to prevent further clot formation and bleeding?

choices.text: Continue heparin therapy at the current dose.
Start warfarin therapy with overlapping heparin.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Start warfarin therapy with overlapping heparin:

  • Given the patient's history of pulmonary embolism (PE), she likely requires ongoing anticoagulation therapy to prevent further clot formation. Warfarin is an appropriate choice for long-term anticoagulation in patients with PE. However, it's essential to initiate warfarin therapy with overlapping heparin to ensure continuous anticoagulation until the international normalized ratio (INR) reaches a therapeutic range (typically 2.0-3.0). This approach minimizes the risk of recurrent thrombosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Continue heparin therapy at the current dose:

  • While continuing heparin is essential for anticoagulation, especially in the acute phase of PE, this option doesn't address the need for long-term anticoagulation, which is typically achieved with warfarin or newer direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs). Maintaining the current heparin dose without transitioning to warfarin leaves the patient at risk of recurrent clot formation.

Option C - Discontinue all anticoagulation therapy:

  • This option is incorrect and potentially dangerous. Discontinuing all anticoagulation therapy in a patient with a history of PE and current deep vein thrombosis (DVT) would significantly increase the risk of further clot formation, which can lead to life-threatening complications such as pulmonary embolism recurrence.

Option D - Initiate argatroban or bivalirudin therapy:

  • Argatroban or bivalirudin are non-heparin anticoagulants used in specific situations like heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). They are not typically used for the long-term anticoagulation of PE or DVT. In this case, the patient does not have HIT; she has a history of recent surgery and acute clot formation, making warfarin a more appropriate choice for extended anticoagulation.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy visits a physician, reporting symptoms of muscle stiffness, pain, jaw cramping, difficulty swallowing, and jerky muscle movements that have been occurring for the past eight days. Additionally, the boy has experienced intermittent fever. Upon analyzing a sample and conducting staining, microscopy reveals the presence of spores with a distinctive "drumstick" appearance. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the pathogen responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Inhibition of GABA release:

  • This is a case of tetanus in which the patient presents with complaints of stiff and painful muscles, jaw cramping and trouble swallowing.
  • The mechanism of action of toxins is the Inhibition of GABA release.
  • Tetanospasmin produced by Clostridium tetani is responsible for the above clinical condition.

Clostridium tetani produce

  • Tetanolysin: heat labile, oxygen labile hemolysin. It plays no role in pathogenesis.
  • Tetanospasmin or tetanus toxin (TT): neurotoxin responsible for the pathogenesis of tetanus:
  • It is oxygen stable but heats labile; coded by the plasmid.
  • Mechanism of action: Toxin acts pre-synaptically at the inhibitory neuron terminals and prevents the release of the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA and glycine → leading to spastic muscle contraction.

Clinical features:

  • Lock Jaw (Trismus)
  • Opisthotonus Posture (Bad prognosis)
  • ↑ Deep tendon reflexes
  • Strychnine poisoning has a similar mechanism, except that it acts post-synaptically.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Inhibition of cAMP:

  • Tetanospasmin inhibits the GABA release.
  • It doesn't inhibit cAMP.

Option C - Inactivation of Ach receptors:

  • BT (Botulinum Toxin) blocks the release of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction, which leads to flaccid paralysis.

Option D - Inhibition of cGMP:

  • In this disease, the toxin acts presynaptically at the inhibitory neuron terminals and prevents the release of GABA. Thus, it doesn't inhibit cGMP.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with swelling in his lower extremities and face. He reports that the swelling has been progressively increasing over the past month, and he has also noticed foamy urine. On examination, he appears edematous, with marked bilateral pitting edema. His blood pressure is within the normal range. Laboratory investigations reveal hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and significant proteinuria. A 24-hour urine protein collection confirms proteinuria exceeding 3.5 grams per  day. There are no other significant medical conditions in his history. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Nephrotic Syndrome due to Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Nephrotic Syndrome due to Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS):

  • Nephrotic Syndrome is characterized by a constellation of symptoms, including significant proteinuria (>3.5 grams per day), hypoalbuminemia, and edema.
  • Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is one of the possible underlying renal diseases that can cause Nephrotic Syndrome.
  • FSGS is characterized by scarring (sclerosis) in a subset of glomeruli (the filtering units of the kidneys). This scarring results in protein leakage into the urine, leading to proteinuria. Edema and hyperlipidemia are common manifestations of Nephrotic Syndrome due to FSGS.
  • The diagnosis of FSGS often requires a renal biopsy for definitive confirmation. Treatment may involve medications such as corticosteroids and immunosuppressants.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Acute Glomerulonephritis:

  • Acute Glomerulonephritis typically presents with symptoms such as hematuria, hypertension, and oliguria.
  • It is characterized by an inflammatory process in the glomeruli of the kidneys, leading to clinical features distinct from Nephrotic Syndrome. The patient in the scenario does not exhibit these typical features.

Option C - Diabetic Nephropathy:

  • Diabetic Nephropathy is a common cause of chronic kidney disease in patients with diabetes. It is associated with proteinuria, but it usually occurs in individuals with a history of diabetes.
  • The patient's medical history does not mention diabetes, and diabetic nephropathy often presents with other diabetic complications such as neuropathy and retinopathy. Additionally, the patient's age is atypical for diabetic nephropathy.

Option D - Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) Stage 2:

  • Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) typically presents with a progressive decline in renal function, often assessed using estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR).
  • The patient's symptoms of significant proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema are not characteristic of CKD stage 2. CKD is often associated with hypertension, which is not present in this case. CKD stages are based on eGFR levels, not Nephrotic Syndrome symptoms.
